dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a few lights are burning at this hour. A limo pulls into the driveway, is met by SEVERAL DARK FIGURES. A MAN gets out, goes inside. Numbers fill the screen and form a super: “1987”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is MICHAEL DEAVER (late 40’s,) once an aide to President Reagan, now a lobbyist. He looks nervous. Grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver hurries down a dark, nearly deserted hallway. The lights glimmer, casting ghostly shadows. He turns a corner, and heads down another hallway, where ARMED SECURITY GUARD who’s been waiting for him salutes. Deaver hurries on. The guard looks after him, his face filling with dislike. TWO MAIDS stand beside a linen closet, talking. They fall silent as Deaver passes, and stare suspiciously after him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another SECURITY GUARD sitting in front of the Reagan bedroom door, watching a tiny tv, with the sound low: Oliver North talking with microphones shoved in his face. As Deaver approaches, the guard stands up, salutes.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE GUARD 2
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir. They’re waiting for you. The guard knocks on the bedroom door with a gloved-hand.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE GUARD 2
dialogues.text: Mr. Deaver to see the President. MUFFLED VOICES WITHIN. THEN, A WOMAN’S VOICE (NANCY) :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him in. The Guard opens the door for Deaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark, lit only by a flickering tv. Two ghosts are sitting in front of it: RONALD REAGAN (75) in bathrob and slippers, watching tv—-his eyes hollow, and dark. On table beside him, a glass of milk and a plate of Oreos. Next to him is his wife, NANCY (63). She’s pale, gaunt. S looks up at Deaver with eyes full of silent panic.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: I got a call from John Tower..He wants to talk to you, Mr. President... Reagan is still staring into the tv. It’s a cowboy movie.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Mike. Go on. Deaver turns to Nancy, lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) They're beginning to talk about impeachment . She begins to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They’11 never impeach him. They won’t have the votes for it in the Senate.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I know but John thinks..so does George, and so do I..the evidence is overwhelming..and if the President doesn’t say something, Congress is going to start its own investigation..—d Meese and I and some of the other Republican Senators..well, we all think the President should hire a criminal practice attorney.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He‘s not a criminal. She begins to weep, silently. Deaver kneels beside Reagan and gently touches his arm. Reagan looks at him, confused 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I need an attorney?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (carefully, gently) No, you don’t need an attorney, Mr. : President, but you want to have one, that’s all. Have one to talk to. Someone to stand up for you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, we’ve got to have somebody.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We haven’t broken the law.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Nobody’s saying you’ve broken the law. It’s just there are so many questions...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Tell them to ask that bastard..that lying son of a gun, Oliver North! He’s the one who knows! Ask Oliver North who gave the money to the Contras—

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: They will, Mr. President..They will...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, listen.Listen to me..We’ve got to do something..We’ve got to stand up for ourselves, for Christ’s sake. We can’t just keep sitting here, doing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But I’m not the one who broke the law.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. President. I know.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You've got to talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I could set up a press conference— Nancy turns to Deaver, her panic flares: as”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No press conferences.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: How's he going to talk?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He‘ll talk to the people. The people. They always believe him.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: “Alright. But not before he’s gotten an attorney—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: They got Nixon, and now they think they’re going to get me. Well, I’m not Nixon. I’m not. Nancy grabs his hand. Her grip is like iron.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Everybody knows that, Ronnie. All you have to do is talk to them. Talk to the people and make them believe you. Reagan wipes the tears off her cheek, kisses her tenderly

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, Nancy-pants. Settle down. Don’t worry. I can handle this. Stop erying. (to Deaver, smiling) She cries more than any woman I know. She cries every time we send out the laundry. Deaver smiles. Nancy and Deaver get up, and go to the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nancy and Deaver come out, the Guard switches off Oliv North on the tv.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW NANCY AND DEAVER -
dialogues.text: down the hall together. She leans on his arm, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: “Dire events,” she said. Well, these are dire events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said that? Your friend?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: She said the first few months of 1987. And it’s all happening the way she said it would. Everything. Deaver is careful to keep his voice even. DEAVER . Just make sure he gets an attorney.”

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I will. And then I’11 call my friend..Find a good date for him to go on tv..We’ve got to listen to her, Mike. When we don’t listen to her, we get into trouble...

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Okay, fine. Give me a date, and I'll set it up for the networks. She looks at him, smiles shakily. NANCY . Thank you, Mike. You’re the only one we ‘ can trust, you know. It’s come down to ~ you. Out of all these people..We’re surrounded by traitors.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. It’s going to be ok. It is. Nancy squeezes his arm gratefully. He leaves. ANGLE - As Nancy returns to her bedroom door, the securit guard has changed the channel to the cowboy movie.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mrs. Reagan. It was the guard before me who turned it on...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're fired. She goes into the bedroom. The guard stares after her, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan is staring into his movie, once again. Nancy puts her arms around him from behind, kisses his ear.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: All I wanted to do was save those people. That’s all I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I know..I know..I love you..I love you. MOVE IN ON his eyes, dark and confused...

dialogues.speaker: AN IMAGE
dialogues.text: The lithe body of an expert swimmer rising to the surface of a perfect blue body of water. In slow motion, the body breaks through the water. Golden sun reflects off the wet skin and hair of this beautiful young man (a young Reagan dressed only in a 1920’s lifeguard uniform. The image of god. The perfect American hero. MUSIC FADES UP: Doris Day singing “SENTIMENTAL JOURNEY”:

dialogues.speaker: DORIS DAY
dialogues.text: (singing) Gonna take a sentimental journey Gonna see my heart's desire...

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT./EXT. REAGAN’S 1948 CADILLAC CONVERTIBLE/MOVING -

dialogues.speaker: CULVER CITY, CA
dialogues.text: Numbers fill the screen, as they will throughout: “1949” Reagan (38) drives through a gorgeous Hollywood afternoon singing along to DORIS DAY ON THE RADIO. He’s wearing glasses, and a cast on his left leg. Two crutches are on the seat beside him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS DAY
dialogues.text: (singing) Gonna take a sentimental journey Gonna take that journey home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan’s green convertible driving onto the lot. He smile and waves, as he passes ACTORS, CREW MEMBERS, etc.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR A SOUND STAGE
dialogues.text: Reagan parks and gets out, using his crutches. He limps past a COUPLE OF STARLET BELLYDANCERS. They smile at him. He smiles back. He passes TWO ACTORS IN BLACK-FACE, working on a tap-danc routine... He passes A GROUP OF ACTORS IN TUXES AND GOWNS clustered around a lunch wagon, eating as if they haven't eaten in days. He opens a stage door marked “East Side, West Side”, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The set is a NYC apartment. A FILM CREW is crawling all over it, setting up for the next take. Reagan approaches the director, MERVYN LEROY (50’s), who’s talking to his D

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Hi, Mervyn. LeRoy turns, smiles, sees Reagan’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Good God, Ronnie..what have you done to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Don’t ask. A charity baseball game. I tried to win one for the Gipper.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Thanks for coming down. I hope I’m not taking you away from anything.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It's fine. I’m not working. I mean, I have the day off. The DP leaves. LeRoy takes Reagan by the elbow, walks him towards an isolated corner. They drop their voices:

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Alright, listen. This is the thing. I’ve got this actress. Over there, see her? Leroy nods to a young woman nearby, sitting by herself. It’s Nancy, elegant, strong-jawed. She’s in costume-a pla ‘etl  secretary's dress—smoking a cigarette. She’s deep into a movie-magazine.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Her name's Nancy Davis. Just came out from Chicago. Extremely conservative. Extremely Republican, if you know what I mean. Anyway, last week, the Hollywood Reporter came out with a list of Communist sympathizers, and her name was on it.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (carefully) Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Of course she’s upset. Scared about her career, her apartment, her friends. She asked me for advice. I said I knew you, and since you were President of the Screen Actors Guild, maybe you could help. Reagan hesitates, looking at Nancy suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: So she’s not a Communist sympathizer?

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: No way. I’m telling you, she’s Republican. Father’s a society doctor in Chicago. That‘s why she’s upset, she keeps saying, if he finds out, she’s screwed. (pause) Anyway, that’s it. Think you can look into it?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Sure. Let me see what I can find out. LeRoy glances at Nancy, then back to Reagan. Lowers his voice still further:

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Do me one more favor—take her out to dinner, or something. You know, just to set her mind at ease.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (groan) Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing expensive. Just something nice. I’m telling you, she’s a wreck. Reagan glances at Nancy again. She doesn’t look like a wreck.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Yeah, well. Okay. I‘11 do it.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ronnie. You’re a pal. LeRoy starts back toward the set. Reagan pulls him back.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Mervyn..Since I’m doing you a favor?

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Cast me in whatever you’re doing next.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: (laughs) You got it. LeRoy starts toward the set. Reagan calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: As long as it’s good. No B-movie stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LEROY
dialogues.text: Gotcha. ANGLE - Nancy looking up from her movie-magazine, watchin him leave.

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: It’s an article on Reagan-pictures of the break-up betwee him and his wife, Jane Wyman. The headline reads: ‘Heart- broken Ronnie: “I’1ll Never Love Again.”

dialogues.speaker: A SHADOW FALLS ACROSS THE MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: Nancy looks up, as LeRoy whispers into her ear: Nees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mission accomplished. Nancy laughs, delighted. She has a gorgeous smile.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Mervyn, you're a peach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan’s green Cadillac pulls up outside Nancy’s modest building. INT. LIVING ROOM - NANCY’S APARTMENT - CONTINUING Nancy watches through the blinds, as he limps up the walk Checks herself in a mirror—she’s deeply insecure about he looks. The doorbell RINGS. She takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Reagan smiles, as she comes out.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s so nice of you to make time for me, you must be terribly busy...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I’m afraid we’ll only have time for a quick bite. I’ve got an early call tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Me, too. As they walk to the car..

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Mervyn told me about your leg. It looks awfully painful.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s not so bad, anymore. As long as you don't make me dance. They both laugh. INT. EXPENSIVE RESTAURANT (LARUE’S) - EVENING The WAITER hands them menus, and leaves. Nancy lights a cigarette and listens intently, as Reagan quietly explain 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here’s the deal. There are a bunch of petitions going around-trying to solicit the Supreme Court against the House Un-American Activities Committee. Your name appeared on one of those petitions, which is how it ended up in the Hollywood Reporter.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But I didn’t sign any petitions. I didn’t. I’m the least political person I know.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I made a few phone calls, and the Nancy Davis who. signed this particular petition lives over on Cahuenga Boulevard. A completely different Nancy Davis.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (sighing with relief. I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: In fact, if you want to know, Nancy Davis is a pretty popular name. There are 3 of you in Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (horrified) Three?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. If I were you, I’d think about changing my name.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (snorts) Forget it. Nancy Davis is my name. Let the other girls change theirs. He laughs, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I like your attitude. Now, let’s see if we can find anything edible on this menu. INT. LARUE’S - NIGHT The lights have dimmed. The room is thick with cigarette candles on every table. In the shadows, BEAUTIFUL 11 Nie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMEN laugh and murmur over martinis with their WEALTHY ESCORTS. Reagan and Nancy have long since finished dinner.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My mother used to be an actress. My father - is a brain surgeon, I got my hands from him. Anyway, he’s the one with political beliefs. He hates the Reds. Hates them. Reagan sighs.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I was an FDR Democrat until the war. I still believe in the Democratic party. But the Democrats..they don’t get it. They won't believe that Moscow’s trying to take over the world. They’ve taken over half of Europe. Czechoslovakia. China. And now they’re here in America, trying to take over Hollywood. I'11 tell you-anybody in their right mind ought to be scared stiff. Nancy nods, in agreement. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. When we came out tonight, all I wanted to do was show you a good time.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It's okay. You talk the way my father talks. Only nicer..Never mind. She smiles, embarrassed. He smiles, too.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Too bad you’ve got an early call.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You, too. Pause. Now it’s his turn to look embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You know, Nancy..I’ve got a little confession to make...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I don’t have one, either. They laugh. 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Sophie Tucker’s singing at Ciro’s. You want to go? EXT. CIRO’S - NIGHT Ciro's is swinging. SOPHIE TUCKER’S VOICE IS ROCKING THE STREET, as Reagan. on crutches, escorts Nancy inside. INT. CIRO’S - LATER The place is packed, as SOPHIE TUCKER sings. Everyone. is drunk, dancing. Reagan and Nancy are dancing--slowly. He' leaning on one crutch, and her.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I was finally getting some good parts when the war came along. Then I was drafted. When I got back, it was all..different. All these young actors. Suddenly I felt like I was..out of fashion. Nancy nods, sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Did you see much action during the war?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Look into my eyes. What do you see? She does. He has nice eyes. Honest.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (wryly) Contact lenses. Blind as a bat without them, kept me out of combat. I spent the war in Culver City making films for the Army. The Hollywood Commandos. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I talk too much, don’t I? That’s what Jane said, when she filed for divorce. I talk too damn much.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It's okay. I’m a Cancer. I like listening. 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. Slowly, he leans toward her..They kiss. arms tighten around him. When the kiss ends, they keep dancing. Looking into each other’s eyes. INT. DEPARTMENT STORE (MAGNIN’S, BEVERLY HILLS) - DAY In a VIP dressing room, Nancy tries on a new dress, looks at herself critically, in the mirror. It’s fashionable, expensive..but somehow all wrong.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: If you ask me, that Ronald Reagan is the best-looking man you’ve had in a while. If you don’t grab him, somebody else will.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do? Throw a rope around him? EDITH LUCKETT DAVIS (50'S), Nancy’s mother, is an earthy woman, former actress, stylish in furs and jewels.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH DAVIS
dialogues.text: No, but it wouldn’t hurt if you dressed better. God, you look awful. It’s your skin. I never saw anybody with such sallow skin. (calling) Hey! Somebody! Who the hell is out there? The SALESWOMAN peeks in the door, gritting her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Davis?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Aren’t you supposed to be helping us? Get my daughter something that’1l make her look decent, for Chrissakes. The Saleswoman is seething, as she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Mother, I wish you’d keep your voice down.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Why? You should be glad I’ve got a big voice-that’s how I made my career. And yours, too, little girl. If I wasn’t friends with Spencer Tracy, do you think 14  you'd be out here in Hollywood, with your very own contract? As Edith pulls a silver cigarette case out of her purse, and lights it, Nancy sighs:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I just don’t think Ronnie wants to get serious about me. Anybody. I mean, God, his wife threw him out. Can you imagine how humiliating that would be? Listening is not Edith’s strong suit.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I know what--tell him you want to meet his kids. Show him what a great mother you’11 make, that‘1ll get him. Nancy suddenly remembers, looks at her watch:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We're late for Dr. Loyal.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Christ. Strip off that rag-we’ve got to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A string quartet plays MOZART in the corner. Nancy sits next to her step-father, DR. LOYAL DAVIS (50’s). He’s holding her hand and stroking it, as Edith looks on, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LOYAL DAVIS
dialogues.text: Nancy, I don’t know what you see in Hollywood. As far as I can tell, it’s nothing but Communists and drug addicts.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It didn’t used to be this bad—did it, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Hell, no. When I was here, it was just wall-to-wall Jews and queers. Loyal laughs-Nancy stiffens. 15

dialogues.speaker: LOYAL DAVIS
dialogues.text: (wiping his mouth with a napkin) Well, frankly, I think we should consider heading to Phoenix early. Nancy, darling— you come, too.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I wish I could, but Dr. Loyal, you know I’m working.

dialogues.speaker: LOYAL DAVIS
dialogues.text: We're going to see the Goldwaters. You love spending time with the Goldwaters.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I really can’t. I’m sorry...

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Ask her about Ronnie Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LOYAL DAVIS
dialogues.text: Nancy, no! You’re not serious about him, are you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, not at all. Well, yes, but..0h please, Dr. Loyal. He’s the only man I’ve ever met who could hold a candle to you. EXT. NANCY’S BATHROOM DOOR - DAY The bathroom door is ajar, as NANCY’S VOICE IS HEARD:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: “Jews and queers.” You bigot, Mother. Why didn’t I tell you to shut up? But I never would, would I? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: AROUND THE CORNER OF THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Nancy is taking a bubble- bath, ranting to herself:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Because I’m a coward, that’s what. Coward. Coward, coward, coward, coward, coward— DOORBELL RINGS. Nancy glances at the clock on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh Christ! He’s early! EXT. NANCY’S DOOR - CONTINUING 16  Reagan turns, calls to TWO CHILDREN waiting in the car.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Michael, stop hitting your sister! Mermie, stay in the car! Do not-do you hear me—do not get out of the car! The door opens. Nancy's wet face, wet hair.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie..Hi...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You ready? I brought the kids, I thought we could go out to the ranch and go horseback-riding. What do you think? Nancy looks at the kids, looks at him. Puts on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Give me 2 secs. EXT. RONNIE’S RANCH (MALIBU CANYON) - DAY Nancy’s awkward on her horse, as they start out. He grabs her reins, leads her toward the gate. The two kids are following, on their horses-MAUREEN (10) and MICHAEL (5).

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Come on, Nancy. Pull in those reins, let him know who’s boss.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (barely hanging on) I think he already knows.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Mermie! Mike! Let’s take Nancy down to the pond! He spurs his horse ahead, leaving her with the kids. They pass thru a gate with an ornate metal sign: YEARLING ROW.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You kids are pretty good at this. Whoa. Whoa, Sugar. 17 Neanav?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been riding since we were 2. Have you ever won an Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (taken aback) An Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Mommy has. She won an Oscar for “Johnny Belinda”. Mike interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m special because I’m adopted. Nancy turns to Mike, even more taken aback. NANCY. You're what?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He’s adopted. Daddy wanted a boy so they adopted one. (to Mike) You’re not special. You're a brat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You’re a brat!

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Daddy! Mikey called me a brat! The argument continues. Nancy smiles weakly. They ride on

dialogues.speaker: ON A HILLSIDE
dialogues.text: A picnic under a tree. The kids play in the distance, as Reagan and Nancy lounge in the shade. He’s reminiscing:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Those were the best days of my life— sitting up high in that lifeguard chair. Watching out for all those families. In 7 years, I saved 77 lives.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Seventy-seven? 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little help from God. But it was pretty good for a scrawny kid from Dixon, Iowa, who grew up over a bank. Actually, that was as close as I ever got to that bank. They both laugh. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You never talk about your folks. What were they like? Reagan doesn’t seem to hear her. He gets up and calls:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Mermie! Mike! Time to head back! The kids run for their horses. He goes to his horse. Nanc watches him, curiously--then gets up, and heads to hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chain-smoking COSTUME LADY (50s) is flipping through Modern Screen as Nancy looks dejectedly at a rack of housedresses.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Maybe I could wear something different for this part. Something a little more—

dialogues.speaker: COSTUME LADY
dialogues.text: You/re playing a housewife, doll. Your wardrobe has to say housewife. Sighing, Nancy chooses a dress; looks at some aprons.

dialogues.speaker: COSTUME
dialogues.text: Hey, .look at this. You're in Modern Screen. Shows her a small photo of Reagan and “starlet Nancy Davi at a premiere—under a large one of him and Jane Wyman: “Ronnie Dates Again But Can’t Forget His Perfect Love.” Nancy stares at it, stung..

dialogues.speaker: COSTUME LADY
dialogues.text: Slip this on under the dress. She’s holding a bulbous rubber object— 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s your pregnancy pad. You get pregnant in act two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan walks with his agent, LEW WASSERMAN (30’s).

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: This is a mistake, Lew. I can’t afford another bad picture.

dialogues.speaker: WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: Come on--it’s a fun movie and I bet it’1l make a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We should have waited for a better offer—

dialogues.speaker: WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: The offers aren’t coming, Ronnie. The studios are drying up. But all that Red Menace crap doesn’t help, either. You know a lot of people around town are convinced you're an informer for the blacklist.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah. I keep telling you, Lew, there is no blacklist.

dialogues.speaker: WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: And thank God we’re not on it. (pause) All I'm saying is, lay off the Evil Empire talk. I can get you all the work you want in television—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Forget it. Television is for somebody who’s all washed up. I’m not washed up. At the stage door, a PUBLICIST and PHOTOGRAPHER wait.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO PUBLICIST
dialogues.text: Hey, Ronnie! How ya doin’? Ready to meet your co-star? The photographer gets ready. The publicist opens the stag door, and out bursts a CHIMP and his TRAINER. The chimp i wearing a t-shirt that says “Bedtime for Bonzo”. 20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Hey, Bonzo! Shake hands with Mr. Reagan! Big smiles, you two! Bonzo starts jumping all over Reagan. Reagan tries to tur on a smile as a FLASHBULB POPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan and Nancy are watching “Casablanca” on tv, as Reag and Nancy finish a bowl of popcorn. She’s subdued. Smokin

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (re: Bogart) That was supposed to be my part, you know. They wanted me to play it, but I was busy. Busy doing nothing..Bogart gets Ingrid Bergman, I get a chimp.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You’re still in love with her, aren’t you? The words have popped out of her mouth before she could stop them. Reagan looks at her, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Jane. You're still in love with her. You even told Modern Screen. “Heartbroken Ronnie Tries to Forget his Great Love”.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Nancy, come off it. Those magazines are a bunch of crap, you know that. (joking) Thank God they still think I’m worth writing about. He turns back to the movie. She stares at him in disbelie

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, look at me. Ronnie. He looks at her. She summons up her nerve.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I want to know where I stand with you. 21 Neves

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where we stand.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don’t know anything. We go out, we laugh, we... (embarrassed, dropping her voice) We make love..but I don’t know anything about you, about how you feel. Oh you talk plenty about everything else-politics, the industry. But not about me. Not to me. His eyes harden. He looks trapped.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t talk about those things, Nancy. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why not? You’re an actor, you play people who have feelings. Come on. Tell me about your feelings. No response. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s late. We both have early calls. Nancy takes the bowl into the kitchen. He stares moodily the popcorn in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’ve told my agent to find me something in New York. On the stage. I’ve had it with Hollywood. He gets up, follows her into the kitchen, where she’s washing the popcorn bowl.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You can’t go back to New York...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Is there some reason I should stay here? (off his silence.) No, I didn’t think so. He grabs her arm, swings her around. He’s angry.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You can’t do this to me. 22  He starts kissing her, hard. Desperate. She pulls back, surprised. He pushes her against the sink, still kissing her. The tap water run and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wealthy. Intellectual. Midwestern. Nancy sits in a chair, erying. Edie sits, opposite. They whisper:

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Well, one thing is clear—you can‘t tell Ronnie. He’s too religious, he’ll never marry you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can’t tell him?

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: But you’d better get him to marry you. And quick. You don’t have any time to lose.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can’t force him marry me, Mother. For God’s sake. She sobs hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Shh, keep it down, or Dr. Loyal will hear you— Nancy can't stop crying. Edith pats her on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: (in a whisper, anxiously) Don’t worry, honey. Don’t worry, we’ll get it fixed. I know somebody right here in Chicago, she can fix it. She’s good. She never hurts anybody. But we can never tell Dr. Loyal, you hear? Never. Never. Nancy stares at her mother, stricken. INT. SOUND STAGE - “THE NEXT. VOICE YOU HEAR” — DAY The set is a drab tenement kitchen. Nancy stands in the shadows, smoking a cigarette. She’s in costume: a house- dress with a pregnancy-pad. She looks utterly miserable. The COSTUME-LADY pushes and pulls the pregnancy-pad: 23 aaa

dialogues.speaker: COSTUME-LADY
dialogues.text: These pregnancy pads are a joke. Hold still. Hold still. (looking at her) You look sick. You sick?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: - I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (from the shadows) Okay, we’ve reset. Nancy, you ready? Nancy stubs out her cigarette, and goes to the table, sit down. Reagan appears in the shadows, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Do we have rain? What’s the matter with the rain? Hold please. Hold. Nancy settles down for a long wait.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Nancy?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (turns, sees) Ronnie? What are you doing here? Nancy gets up, crosses to him in the. shadows.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Nancy, where are you? Where the hell did you go?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (to the director) I’m talking to somebody, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Don’t leave. We'll be ready in a minute. Reagan pulls Nancy further into the shadows, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, here it is. My father was a drunk. Everywhere we lived, he’d lose his job, because of the drink..I remember when I was young, coming home from the YMCA one 24  afternoon..and there he was on our lawn, passed out drunk in the snow. It broke my heart to see him like that..He must have been in so much pain. I had to drag him inside. (pause) But my mother..she kept right on living the way she thought was right. She was always good to my father. She never held it against him, no matter how many jobs he lost, or how often we moved..She was the one who kept the family together.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I understand, Ronnie. I do.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: No, you don’t. You come from Chicago—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I had it tough, too—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But your father had money. Money is everything.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Dr. Loyal isn’t my father. My real father left, before I was born. My mother was broke, she went on the road just to make money, and stuck me with her sister for 6 years. For 6 years, I cried myself to sleep, every night. So don’t tell me I’ve never had trouble, because I have. Reagan is stunned, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I love you. I’d do anything for you. Ask me to crawl halfway across the country for you, I would. On my knees. On my knees. She’s on the verge of tears, touches him, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, don’t say that. Please..You don’t know..I’m pregnant. He looks down at her pregnancy-pad. 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you look cute as a bug, too. He puts his arms around her, picks her up. Kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Come here, Mommy. You want to marry me?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: | Ronnie, stop it..you don’t mean it...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I do. I love you, Nancy..I really do, I love you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26  INT. LEW WASSERMAN’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: ACT TWO
dialogues.text: Newco?” SUPER: “1953” Lew’s uncomfortable, awkward, as he pushes an envelope across the table to Reagan, and tries to explain: Reagan takes

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: It's not you, Ronnie. It’s Warner Brothers. Now that the Government forced the studios to sell off their theatres, they can’t afford their stable of stars.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s because my movies haven't been making enough money. That’s why they’re letting me go.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: (re: the envelope) Go on, take it. It’s your last paycheck. the envelope, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I worked for those bastards for 13 years— Ne”

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: They’d fire their own mother, if it would help them balance their books right now. (cautiously) Listen to me. I know you said you’d never do television, but I think I’ve engineered a deal with GE. They’re going to doa series and they want you to host it. A different story every week, some of them starring you. And there'd be speaking engagements, too, you’d be their spokesman—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (dubiously) A spokesman..for General Electric?

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: You’d go around the country, talking to employees and consumers. When people see GE, they’d think of you. Nao” Reagan is getting more depressed by the minute. 27

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Oh great.

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: It’s going to be a lot of money. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, and the government will take out 94% of it in taxes. I’m telling you, Lew, I don’t know why I bother working. Reagan gets up, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: Think about it. It’s a good opportunity. Keep you in the public eye. Then, when that next picture comes along..bang. Talk to Nancy, and call me. They want an answer as soon as possible... Reagan’s gone. The door hangs open, allowing a view of the SECRETARY, AND A COUCHFUL OF ACTORS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small hour, immaculate garden. The EAR-SPLITTING SCREAM of an enraged toddler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Dr. Spock’s Child Care” on the floor, covered with cerea Nancy is on the phone, with a finger in one ear, as PATTI (2) screams, and sends her bowl of cereal flying.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) We’d love to come to Phoenix, Mother, but we're a little busy right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swathed in caftan and turban, Edie takes a martini from Loyal and sips, rolling her eyes heavenward with delight.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: The Goldwaters keep asking me about you, I told them you’re married to Ronald Reagan, they can’t believe it. They’re dying to 28  meet him. You can fly down on Friday, spend the weekend—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (covering the mouthpiece, hissing) Patti! Stop it! Stop it! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: What? I can’t hear you—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh God, Mother, I’d love to come down. But...Patti!

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: --we're having a party Friday night. Dr. Loyal will make you a martini that’s out of this world—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I‘ll talk to Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I will. Bye, Mother. Nancy hangs up the phone, turns to her purpling child, an SCREAMS BACK at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hotel is surrounded by lush bougainvillea and palm trees--the watering-place for local and imported wealthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In shorts, golf shirts and deep tans, Loyal Davis, Ronnie and Arizona Senator BARRY GOLDWATER sip tall drinks and discuss politics. Reagan dandles Patti on his lap, while:

dialogues.speaker: BARRY GOLDWATER
dialogues.text: In this country we don’t make a man join a church and tithe..We don’t insist he join a fraternal order and pay dues..but union bosses like Hoffa can force that man to join the union and pay his dues, or he doesn’t work. Loyal leans over to Reagan, proudly: 29 Newie”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s what I like about Barry. He shoots straight from the hip.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But the federal government is worse than the unions. The Republicans are taking control of business. They killed the movie studios. And liberal Democrats are leading us down the road to socialism..The welfare state has done as much to destroy our way of life as the Commies. Right, Shorty?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Right. In the b.g., Edie crosses with 2 martinis to Nancy, who lies on a chaise, exhausted, sunning herself.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Those two are going to have your husband voting Republican before the day is over.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Let them try. The Reagans. have been Democrats for generations.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Well, we’ll see what happens, once he starts working at GE. I hope you take his first pay-check to hire yourself a nanny and a housekeeper. I didn’t raise you to wait table on a toddler.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: | (wincing) Oh God. I want to be a good mother. I do. Edie scoffs, pats Nancy on the arm consolingly:

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: You're no worse than I was. The only thing that’s important is you and Ronnie. Kids will come and go, but if you’re good to Ronnie, you'll have him for the duration.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY PORTRAIT
dialogues.text: The three Reagans smiling from the cover of TV GUIDE. Headline : “TV’S HOTTEST HOST: STAR OF GENERAL ELECTRIC THEATRE SAYS FAMILY IS HIS MOST IMPORTANT PRODUCT.” 30 ESTABLISHING: REAGANS’‘ NEW HOUSE - PACIFIC PALISADES - SUPER: “1954” INT. REAGANS’ HOUSE - PACIFIC PALISADES - DAY A FILM CREW is swarming all over the living room, setting up lights, cameras, etc. Reagan sits in the middle, putti on his own make-up, as he tells a joke:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Did you hear the one about the two little kids, one’s an optimist, and the other’s a pessimist? Their parents gave the pessimist a shiny new bike to teach him that things weren’t always so bad. And to teach the optimist that things weren’t always so good, they gave him a big pile of horse manure— (pause) Well, when the pessimist saw the bike, he burst into tears, sure he’d fall off and hurt himself. But the little optimist just smiled. He knew that somewhere around all that manure, there had to be a pony. The crew laughs. INT. UPSTAIRS - PATTI’S BEDROOM - CONTINUING Nancy arguing with Patti, (5), who won’t come down.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Come on, Patti. They’re all set to go.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: No. I won’t. I want to stay up here and play. Nancy grits her teeth, and takes Patti by the wrist.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No arguing. We're going down, right now.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: No! No! No! No! NO! NO! Nancy reaches out, and slaps Patti. Patti reels, holding her cheek. Nancy freezes. 31 Seca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m sorry, Patti..I’m sorry... Patti begins to cry. Nancy picks her up, and carries her out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chandelier over the table, which is set with enough linen silver and flowers to satisfy Emily Post. Beautifully dressed and coiffed, Nancy, Reagan, and Patti eat lunch a if this is the way they always live.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI, (5)
dialogues.text: Daddy, what’s ‘lectricity?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, Patti, electricity is a wonderful thing. Let’s go into the kitchen and maybe I can explain it.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW THEM AS THEY GET UP AND TROOP OUT TO THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Which is state of the art, GE’s logo prominent everywhere

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We ought to be able to find lots of electrical appliances in here. (picks up an iron from counter) What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Mommy's iron.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That’s right, it’s one of the new steam- and-dry irons.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: (overriding) I’m hungry. Can we cut now? ANGLE - the Film Crew howling with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Cut! Okay, everybody! Take ten!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (to Patti, exasperated) That’s the third time you stepped on my line. What am I going to do with you? 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hands around Patti’s neck, and laughing, pretends to strangle her. As everyone laughs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining against the windows. SOUND: THUNDER. A sign at the door says: “Meet Ronald Reagan in Person: GE'S Roving Ambassador of Good Will”. The room’s packed with GE EMPLOYEES, all male, white, in white short-sleeve shirts and black ties, listening, as:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: America is a land of unlimited opportunity—all of us here are proof of that. We’re blessed with the freedom to make of ourselves whatever we want to be. In the back of the room, a man (BEN WELDEN, 40) is quietl watching the response.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But there are people who want to take that freedom away from us—big government that rewards laziness with welfare-that wants to tell you how to pray, and what doctor you'll see, and what school you’ll send your kids to! Some employees applaud in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, you and I have a rendezvous with destiny. Will we preserve our American way of life? Or doom our children to a lifetime of tyranny?? An explosion of applause. Welden watches, impressed. INT. GE LUNCHROOM ~— LATER Welden hovers as Ronnie signs autographs, surrounded by enthusiastic employees.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Just a couple more, fellas. I got to go to Atlanta.

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: Need a lift to the train station? INT./EXT. WELDEN’S CAR - MOVING - STREET ~ DAY 33 ‘sai? The rain pelts against the windshield. Ronnie’s exhauste trying to rest. Welden talks:

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: Quite a flag-waver you gave. Company give you a script? i REAGAN | The words are mine. So are the convictions.

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: And that thing about “Rendezvous with Destiny”. That’s good.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It's FDR.

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: You a Democrat? (Ronnie nods tiredly) You sure don’t talk like one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Democrats have changed, not me.

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: My name’s Welden. Ben Welden. I work for the Republican Party. I’ve got a few friends you might like to meet.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) Why?

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: Why not? They’re people, just like you and me. People who care about their country. Besides, my friends are going to be real, real interested in you. INT. REAGANS’ PALISADES BEDROOM - LATE DAY Wearing a silk slip,. hair pin-curled, Nancy scowls at th half-dozen evening dresses spread out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie? Honey, come and choose for me, will you? No response. She crosses to the intercom by the door. 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A button for every room in the house. Nancy’s finger presses Nursery. HEAR, CLEARLY:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, saying your prayers is like talking to God..God listens. to you, like I do.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Mommy doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Mommy doesn’t listen to me. She hits me.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: She doesn’t hit you.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: She does, too. She hit me tonight, when I wouldn’t take a bath.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Listen, Shorty, maybe she spanks you, but when I was your age, I got spanked a lot, too, That’s what parents do.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: (sullenly) You’re always on her side.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Go to sleep. Close your eyes. Nancy leans against the wall, reeling with guilt. EXT. ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE’S HOUSE, BEVERLY HILLS - NIGHT A crowd of WEALTHY REPUBLICAN COUPLES milling around unde a large white tent, dancing to a small band, drinking, flirting, gossiping, etc. Ronnie is sitting with a group of PROMINENT BUSINESSMEN. The men are all half-drunk, laughing, as he says:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, you know what I always say..Big Government‘s like a baby—a big appetite at 35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: one end, and no responsibility at the other... The men ROAR with laughter. Ben Welden approaches, with ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE AND HOLMES TUTTLE.

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: Ronnie..I want you to meet two friends of mine. Alfred Bloomingdale, and Holmes Tuttle.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Hello, gentlemen. Alfred and Holmes take the cigars out of their mouths, lo enough to shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE
dialogues.text: Ben here says you’re a Democrat. That true? Holmes intervenes, with a grin:

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s a Democrat. For now. Everybody laughs. Reagan looks a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: A TABLE UNDER THE TENT
dialogues.text: Nancy is sitting with a group of women..They’re all drink and smoking. Her smile is showing signs of strain.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: I had all the kids’ horoscopes done just last year. You won’t believe what I found out.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN 2
dialogues.text: Carol? Did she do them?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: Only the best for those little monsters. Everyone laughs. Nancy leans over to the woman next to he who is bleached-blonde, tanned, face-lifted. Her name is BETSY BLOOMINGDALE.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Excuse me..is she talking about Carol Ryder,.the astrologer? 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’ve never met Carol? She’s a genius. She knows what days are good, and what days are bad. She’11 tell you when it’s okay to get on a plane, when to ask fora promotion, and even what boarding school to put your children in. WOMAN 3 leans over, whispers to both of them:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN 3
dialogues.text: Carol told me about this girls’ school in northern California. We sent our two daughters there, they’ve never been happier. And it saved my marriage. Betsy laughs. As Woman 3 returns to her drink:

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Betsy Bloomingdale.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nancy Reagan. Nancy takes a sip of her drink, then cautiously ventures:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I wonder if she could tell me whether I’m having a boy, or a girl.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Honey, don’t tell me you’re pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Only just. Ronnie wants a boy. So do I.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: So you won’t have to go through it again. I’ll drink to that. Betsy laughs, drinks. So does Nancy. She’s found a friend

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan brings in a cup of warm milk to Nancy, as she’s climbing into bed, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I liked those people tonight. They were really nice people, don’t you think? And 37 Nei”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rich. I’ve never seen so many rich people in one place.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, you’ve met plenty of rich people in Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But not like this. This is different. Texaco. Shell. Mobile Oil. And these people don’t even look tired. They look like they spend all their time on vacation. (Nancy laughs) Yeah, nice fellows. Real nice fellows. A couple of them asked me if I’d ever thought of running for Senator. Nancy stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Senator? You?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: In the spring primary. Why not? I’d be sort of like Jimmy Stewart, you know? In “Mr. Deeds Goes to Washington"?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, that’s a movie. There's alsoa little matter of them being Republicans, and you being a Democrat. Unless you’re thinking about switching parties. Are you? (off his silence) Ronnie?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Do you want me to switch?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (evasively) «Dr. Loyal would like it.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: No. No, I don’t want to be a Republican. Hell, I want to act. Acting is the only thing I ever wanted to do. And if I can just keep with this GE thing long enough— I'll get back into the movies, I will. Sooner or later. 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, every producer in Hollywood is a Democrat. If you want to be an actor, I guess you’ve got to stay a Democrat.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I know. I’m an actor, not a politician. - Say, where’s my script? Want to help me run lines for tomorrow? Reagan heads into the bathroom for his toothbrush.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Sure, but first I want to talk to you about something. One of the women at the party was talking about a boarding school for. girls, up north. She went on and on, about it. It’s supposed to be real nice.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You mean, for Patti? On the wall beside Nancy’s head, a little red light is blinking. It’s the intercom. INT. PATTI’S ROOM - Patti sits in bed in the dark, listening.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Not now, but when she gets a little older. Boarding school can be good for girls, particularly girls like Patti.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you’re right. Mermie and Michael went to boarding school. It’s up to you, Nancy-pants. You’re running the show.

dialogues.speaker: END OF ACT TWO
dialogues.text: 39 Saw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy in bed, looking up at Reagan as he holds BABY RON. the b.g., Edith and Loyal Davis, hugging Patti.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Hi, Skipper... (hugging him) I’ve got a son..a son..You're going to be a chip off the old block, aren’t you, kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “GE Theater, Episode #284; Scene 49, Take 1”. On action, Reagan (the Sheriff) begins duking it out with the Bad Gu Reagan throws a punch and the Bad Guy goes for his gun. Reagan’s faster: he draws, pulls the trigger, but—click, click-the gun doesn’t fire. Reagan deadpans to the Bad Gu

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Mind if I borrow your gun? The Bad Guy cracks up, so does the rest of the set. A.D. Oh Christ. What’s the matter with the gun? Guys, why can’t we get this right?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m giving a talk at the VFW tonight. If you don’t watch out, I'11 name you as a threat to American freedom. LAUGHTER. As they fix the problem, Lew Wassermen has been watching from the dark. Reagan crosses to him, and says:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: So, Lew..What’s with the face? Lew takes him into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: I got another call from GE--

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: My speeches make them nervous, I know.

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: They’re getting too extreme. 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Lew. The Reds are making a bomb to blow us up, and I’m being “too extreme” ? Lew pulls Reagan further into the corner. Quietly:

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: The head of GE heard you give a speech at the plant in Tarrytown. He said you sounded like some kind of right-wing reactionary nut. Democrats buy GE products, too, so lay off the Commie- thing.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’m not going out there to peddle toasters, Lew.

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: You're going to push General Electric to the wall?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: They’re not going to fire me.

dialogues.speaker: LEW
dialogues.text: But they can sure as hell cancel the show.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: And you’re going to support them against me? Silence. This is suddenly looking like a parting of the ways.

dialogues.speaker: A.D.
dialogues.text: Ready! Ronnie, we’ve got your gun! Reagan turns on his heel, and goes back to work. Lew star after him, irritably. INT. PALISADES HOUSE - BABY’S ROOM - AFTERNOON Nancy bending over Ron’s crib, making sure he’s asleep. Suddenly, the TV BLARES from the next room. Nancy stiffen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti watching tv. Nancy enters, angrily snaps it off. 41

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti, I told you 3 times. Not. While. Baby. Ron. Is. Napping. Patti turns the tv back on.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti? Did you hear me? Patti ignores her. Nancy starts to slap her, but stops.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Go to your room! Now! NOW! Patti saunters off. Nancy snaps off the tv. STAY ON NANCY, seeing herself in the mirror—an angry mom. She winces at her reflection, pats her hair into place. She doesn’t see the MAID behind the door, watching...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan pulls into the driveway, turns off the engine, sit in the car. Nancy appears in the screen’door, with Patti. She comes out, alone.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So did you do it? Reagan gets out of the car. She puts her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s over. They wanted me to stop talking, and I’m not going to.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Good. I’m proud of you. You’ll be happier making movies.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Did you talk to Lew? 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can’t even get him on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (stunned) What? nn

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Funny, isn’t it? Why am I surprised? He hates everything I stand for.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh God, Ronnie..He’s been your agent since the beginning. How can he do this to you--

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN,
dialogues.text: I don’t know—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: And now he’s betrayed you...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s over, okay? Don’t look at me like that. I'll get a new agent. And a new job. I have a family to support, don’t I? He twists away from her, and goes into the house, pushing past Patti in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: JFK's coffin in the Rotunda, as Jackie, Caroline, and Joh John stand before it. SUPER: “1963”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy, Reagan, Patti (11), and Ron (5) are watching the t

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That poor woman... As John-John salutes his father’s coffin..Little Ron grin and salutes, too. Nancy grabs him, holding him tightly:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, Ronnie, no. Don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WATCHING THRU THE WINDOW - NANCY’S POV ~ 43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan sitting beside the pool, talking to Ben Welden and blonde man (Mike Deaver) .

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Hello..is this Miss Ryder?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RYDER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My name is Nancy Reagan. My husband..my husband is—

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RYDER
dialogues.text: Ronald Reagan. The actor. Yes. ANGLE - NANCY IN HER BEDROOM On the phone. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Well, the thing is, Miss Ryder..Some people are trying to get my husband to go into politics..the Republicans..They want him to switch parties, and make speeches for Barry Goldwater, but he keeps telling them, he’s an actor, and..I don’t know..Everything’s so mixed up..I just wonder if you could just tell me whether we’re on the right path..Hello? INTERCUT WITH CAROL RYDER’S MOUTH, TALKING INTO HER PHONE

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RYDER
dialogues.text: Would you rather have a consultation on the phone, or in person? Nancy watches Reagan shake hands with Welden and Deaver. Something’s been decided. ,

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (trembling) On the phone. If you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful, starry night. The house is lit up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL REAGAN (18) drops his backpack on the sofa, as Reagan moves around the room, turning on lights. 44

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So this is it? I sleep on the sofa, like a dog?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We don’t have much room, Michael. But it’s good you came. We’re all glad you came, aren’t we, guys? Nancy, Patti, and Ron stand in the doorway, watching.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course we are. Of course. Michael glances at Nancy, uneasily, turns back to Reagan:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But Dad..did Mom tell you?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Sure. We knew you were coming. We just didn’t know it was going to be tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, not that. Did she tell you I flunked out of that stupid school?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Listen, Mike, it’s okay, I never got much in the way of grades, myself. You can try again, here. Go to the public high school. We can even get you some tutoring. Nancy can find you a tutor, can’t you, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Certainly. I'll get the linens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti and Ron follow, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: That guy is my brother? 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-brother. His mother was Daddy’s first wife. And he’s got a sister, Maureen, and the two of you had better be nice, you hear?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I have a sister, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sofa has been made up. As Mike unpacks his backpack, Patti and Ron watch.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Why don’t you live with your real mommy and daddy?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Dad is his Dad, fleabrain.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You’re a fleabrain. Is Maureen going to move in, too?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Maureen’s. married. Actually, she’s married to this really weird guy..Hey, don’t mess with my stuff! Ron’s found a copy of Playboy in the suitcase. Mike snatches it away.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It’s just naked ladies. So what? Patti and Mike laugh. Ron laughs because they’re laughing Reagan appears in the doorway, smiling:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Somebody must have told a good one. They jump. Mike neatly lowers the magazine out of view.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You guys try to keep it down, okay? Mommy’s got a headache. As he goes, Patti turns to Mike with a dark grin: 46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And we’re it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge photo of BARRY GOLDWATER—“IN YOUR HEART, YOU KNOW HE’S RIGHT”’—looks down on a room packed with well-heeled SUPPORTERS, as Reagan addresses them from a podium.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We are at war with the most dangerous enemy mankind has faced in his climb from the swamp to the stars..a war for our American way of life. If we lose that war, we’ll have only ourselves to blame... INTERCUT Deaver and Welden standing in back, checking the reaction. Deaver’s impressed.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: He’s got them hypnotized..Too bad he’s only an actor, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I wish he’d mention Goldwater. Nancy, Betsy, Arthur Bloomingdale and Holmes Tuttle are sitting at a nearby table, listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You and I have a rendezvous with destiny. We can preserve for our children this, the last best hope of man on earth, or we can sentence them to take the first step into a thousand years of darkness. The audience applauds thunderously. Betsy leans over. to Nancy, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Did you talk to Carol? What did she say? Nancy whispers into her ear. As the applause fades, A WOM stands up in the audience, calling to Reagan:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN IN AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Mr. Reagan! Mr. Reagan! Have you registered as a Republican, yet? 47

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (grin) Well,.no, I haven't yet..but I intend to.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN IN AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: It just so happens that I’m a registrar. As everyone laughs in shock, she walks down the aisle and places a registration form on the podium in front of him. He signs it.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Now, where was I? The audience rises to their feet, cheering. Reagan acknowledges them. He finds Nancy in the sea of cheering faces, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost everyone is gone. The dance band is playing one last song. Nancy and Reagan are standing near the exit, talking to ADMIRERS. Betsy is with them. On the other side of the room, Ben Welden, Alfred Bloomingdale, and Holmes Tuttle are sitting at a table, talking quietly.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE
dialogues.text: Listen, Ben. Holmes and I are ready to write checks right now...

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Goldwater thanks you both.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE
dialogues.text: We’ve already given to Goldwater. We’re talking about Ronald Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: The governor’s race is going to be wide open next year. The party in California’s in a shambles. We have a feeling that he might be the man to bring it together. Mike Deaver arrives with a beer, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: - Yeah, but can you really run an actor for Governor? 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is Mike Deaver. He can get anybody elected to anything. The excitement at the table rises, perceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Reagan’s not an actor, he’s a movie-star. Besides, it’s good that he doesn’t know anything about Government. It makes him more a man of the people.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE
dialogues.text: And since he’s a movie star, everybody knows him. Running Reagan will cost half what it would cost to run somebody that nobody's ever heard of.

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: Listen, Alfred. I’ve been talking to Ronnie about running, for years. I’ve talked until I was blue in the face. He's not interested.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Well..Maybe you’ve been talking to the wrong Reagan. They all look over at Nancy, who is pulling Reagan onto t dance floor. Silently, they watch them begin to dance. ANGLE - Reagan and Nancy dance well, together. Perfectly matched. He pulls her close, gives her a tender kiss.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mr. Republican.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (teasing) Did you pay that woman to come up and register me? Nancy laughs, slyly.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, Ronnie. I wish I had. They laugh, as they continue to slow-dance.

dialogues.speaker: ACT FOUR
dialogues.text: EXT. REAGANS’ HOUSE - PACIFIC PALISADES - NIGHT SUPER: “1964” A few cars in the driveway. Walter Cronkite’s voice reporting Goldwater’s defeat by LBJ; the worst in electio history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan watches tv, while eating jellybeans out of a jar. Nearby, are Deaver, Welden, and Betsy and Alfred Bloomingdale. Grim. The maid is emptying ash trays.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: Four more years of LBJ.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY BLOOMINGDALE
dialogues.text: He's going to double taxes, you watch.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE
dialogues.text: Yup. By the time the Democrats are done, there’1l be no corporations left, in this country. We'll all be bankrupt. (pause) Ronnie, I’m telling you. You're our only hope.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: What makes you think I could be Governor? I’ve never even played one. They laugh. EXT. REAGANS’ POOL - CONTINUING Alfred Holmes talks to Nancy in the shadows, by the pool.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Nancy, we want to put your husband in the Governor’s seat, and keep him there for 8 years. Then we’re going to put him in the Presidency for another 8 years. By the time he’s done, Communism will be dead, the Republican Party reunited, and “conservative” won’t be a dirty word, anymore. 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, he’s told you and told you..He doesn’t want to do it. He likes his life the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but do you? Nancy turns silent, wary.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Sure, it’s nice being the wife of a movie star. But think what it would be like to be the wife of the Governor of California. (pause) First Lady of California—sounds pretty good, doesn’t it? There you'll be, in the Governor’s mansion—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s a dump.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Then we’ll get you someplace nicer, somewhere right in Sacramento—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I hate Sacramento. Holmes pauses again.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES TUTTLE
dialogues.text: Nancy, listen..Ronnie’s not the only one who can unite the party. So can you. He’s the Governor, but you’re the power behind the throne. And with all that power, all that money..You’1l have your own projects, but you can also influence your husband’s decisions on the economy, the welfare state, and the future of California. You’1l be the social and political center of power. I tell you-comparatively speaking, it makes Hollywood look like Tobacco Road. She turns, without a word, and goes into the house. He slowly follows. INT. REAGANS’ LIVING ROOM - NIGHT | Everyone's laughing, as Nancy comes back into the room. sits on the arm of his chair, putting her arm around him. 51

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: How’s Ron?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: Nancy, we want to form a “Friends of Ronald Reagan” Committee. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I told them, you and I are already friends. Nancy laughs. Holmes appears in the doorway, re-lights hi cigar while the conversation continues:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It means turning everything upside down..especially your life, Nancy. Your life will never be the same. All eyes turn to Nancy. She smiles mysteriously, and give him a kiss on top of his head.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh God, Ronnie..I’m tired of fighting it, aren’t you? These people need you. California needs you. (pause) And besides, I have a very special friend who says you’d make a great Governor. Reagan turns to the others, smiling:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Isn‘t she the greatest?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (then) Okay, gentlemen. Where do we start? INT. REAGANS’ DEN - NIGHT The den is filled with NEW FACES (CAMPAIGN AIDES) making posters, stuffing envelopes, on the phone, etc. One of the aides comes out..Bumps into little Ron in the hallway, who’s dancing to his own silent music... 52 Keeps going into the kitchen, where he opens the fridge starts rummaging for food. A PUBLICITY STILL OF THE FAMIL EXCLUDING MIKE AND. MAUREEN (“VOTE FOR REAGAN!”) is taped the refrigerator door. Nearby, Nancy is trying to talk on the phone and deal wit an angry Patti at the same time:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) I know he’s about to flunk out..I’ve gotten him tutoring, but it doesn’t seem to help..

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I’m not going to boarding school, and you can’t make me.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti, I’m talking to Mike’s teacher—

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I’1l run away! I will!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti, go to your room! Now! Patti kicks the refrigerator, and runs off in tears. Nanc turns to the cupboard, takes out a bottle of Valium, take one. Holds onto the cupboard to steady her nerves.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPAIGN AIDE
dialogues.text: Do you have anymore mayo? INT. NANCY’S BATHROOM - PALISADES HOUSE Patti sneaks in, and quietly opens Nancy’s medicine cabinet. It’s full of prescription drugs. She takes down bottle, pours some pills into her hand, stuffs them in he pocket. EXT. MIKE’S SCHOOL - DAY Mike is sitting on the curb, tightly coiled, as Nancy drives up with Ron and Patti in the back seat. He climbs in. The car roars away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy turns to Mike. Her hands clenched to the steering wheel. In the back, Patti is asleep on the seat. 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t start it. The other guy hit me.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're getting a reputation. Listen, Mike..Your father and I want to help you, but we’ve come to a dead end. Either you start living up to the Reagan name, or get out.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You want me to leave?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Unless you shape up.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You don’t want me, anyway. You never did.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’m not your mother. I don’t have to want you. Go back to your real mother and your real father..whoever they were: The words are barely out of her mouth, when Nancy wishes she could stuff them back in. Too late. The damage is done. They ride, in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike slams in from outside, stomps thru the house, and ou the door to the pool. A moment later, Nancy comes in with Patti. She goes to th den, where Reagan is meeting with Deaver and Welden.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, may I speak to you for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Sure, Mommy. Reagan comes out. He’s overwhelmed, too.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Mermie called. She’s on her way here. She needs a place to stay for a few days. 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: She won’t say. But she’s leaving her husband. I told her she could help out with the campaign.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh God. Okay, and here’s some news for you-Mike got into another fight at school. And I..I said some things I shouldn’t have said. (then) I've had it, Ronnie. I really have. He’s got to go.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Where? Where will he go?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Anywhere. Home to Jane. For God’s sake, he’s old enough to live on his own.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But I like having him here—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, I can’t deal with him, and take care of Ron, and get Patti off to boarding school and besides, all these people—we don’t have any privacy, none at all—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s on the verge of tears. Reagan kisses, hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, fine, I’11 tell him. Nancy can see his reluctance.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Never mind, you don’t have to. I'll take care of it. He already thinks I'ma monster. I am a monster.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: How could you possibly be a monster? Come on, Nancy-pants. Don’t cry, it’1l put lines in your face. Smile. Smile. “She tries to smile. He kisses her. DOORBELL. Before they can move, Ron runs to the door, and opens it. 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen (24) is standing on the threshold, with a suitcas

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Hi, are you Ron? I’m your big sister Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy is getting linens out of the hall-closet. She heads towards the den... passing the kitchen, where Reagan, Welden and Deaver are sitting around. the kitchen table, talking... checking the patio where Mike sulks, while Ron and Patti are playing cards... AS NANCY PASSES, Patti turns to Ron and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: She’s getting rid of me, and she’s getting rid of Mike. The next one to get rid of is you. Little Ron’s eyes grow big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy sets the linens on the sofa. Maureen is setting up her things on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: These are for you. Since Mike’s on the sofa, I imagine you’1l have to sleep on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I want to say something here. Girl-talk. Maureen turns and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Since your father is running for public office..and you’re in the middle of a divorce..I really think it’s best if you 56  would exempt yourself from taking part in his campaign.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (astonished) Dad was divorced, too—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, but the voters already know that. Frankly, Mermie, if you want to help your father, the best thing you can do is stay away. Nancy is about to pat Maureen on the shoulder, when she sees a ferocious bruise on Maureen's upper arm. She stare at it for several moments--then turns, and walks out. Maureen stares after her, darkly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chartered bus smokes in the driveway, a banner on its side reads “Reagan for Governor”. Nancy and Reagan come o of the house, accompanied by aides carrying their suitcases. Reagan helps Nancy onto the bus. Maureen is nowhere to be seen. Welden and Deaver are talking.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: We could cover a lot more ground if he’d fly.

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: He's afraid of it. Been afraid of it since he was a kid. Deaver looks at the bus, and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s filled with CHEERING VOLUNTEERS. Reagan grins at the 57

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Until last night, I thought I was agreeing to do something that would last only until November, and then I’d go back to private life. But then Nancy said to me, “What if you win?” (mock-horror) I said, “Wait a minute! If I win this damn thing, I’m out of show business! And I’m in politics!” Everybody roars with laughter. A SERIES OF SCENES: Reagan and Nancy on the campaign trai Receptions in homes and drab hotels. Endless hand-shaking Welden and Deaver always at Reagan’s side.

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: Governor Pat Brown in a commercial, talking to a classroo of kids:

dialogues.speaker: PAT BROWN
dialogues.text: I’m running against an actor, and you know who shot Lincoln, don’t you? EXT. SMALL CALIFORNIA. TOWN -— DAY The Reagan bus stops at an American Legion Hall, where a CROWD is waiting. They burst into cheers, as an exhausted Reagan gets out, smiling and waving. He plunges into the crowd, shaking hands, bantering (ad lib) as Welden tries to keep him moving. Nancy follows, looking nervously at A GROUP OF STUDENT PROTESTORS at the edge of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT PROTESTORS
