dialogues.text: REAGAN'S A FASCIST! REAGAN’S A FASCIST! (ETC. )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An object flies out of the group, intended to hit Reagan the head. He catches it--an orange--throws it back.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: This thing isn’t ripe. And neither are you! The crowd laughs. Reagan shouts to the students: 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know what? If I had any doubts that I’m doing the right thing, I just lost. them! So when I’m your next Governor... His supporters cheer..the students boo...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: The first thing I’m going to do is clean up the mess on our college campuses! A turmoil of cheers and jeers. Supporters and students exchange angry shouts. A scuffle breaks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A posh private school for girls..Horse stables, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERY LOUD MUSIC: Rolling Stones ("19 Nervous Breakdown”) GIRLS (age 12 - 16) running in and out of their rooms, shrieking, dancing. Another night at boarding school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette smoke swirls in the student lounge, where a big hand-made sign (“Vote for Pat Brown”) covers almost an entire wall. A GROUP OF A DOZEN GIRLS IN HIPPIE GARB sit, glued. to the tv.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID BRINKLEY, (TV)
dialogues.text: And in California, Ronald Reagan has won the gubernatorial election by nearly a million votes, taking 55 of the 58 counties in that state... A GENERAL GROAN. ONE GIRL bursts into tears (Patti, 14).

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. We’re all screwed.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL 1
dialogues.text: Look out, everybody. Hitler’s just been elected Governor. A titter goes around the room. Another girl rolls over in Patti's lap, and hugs her:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL 2
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Patti. We still love you. 59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. Patti shrinks into her seat, still crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael hangs out with sailboat-racing buddies as he star at the bar tv, which is showing pictures of Reagan Headquarters filled with cheering crowds. He and his friend whoop and holler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan and Nancy holding each other, as their AIDES, including Ben Welden, slap each other on the back. Ron watches from the corner, reeking of loneliness. The death chant of VOICES CALLING (OC):

dialogues.speaker: WE WANT RONNIE
dialogues.text: RONNIE! (etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera-lights are blinding, as Reagan pulls Nancy through the crowd to the podium. He’s holding up his hand for silence, but the CROWD IS CHANTING FASTER AND FASTER:

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: RONNIE! RONNIE! RONNIE (etc.) The chanting builds almost to the point of hysteria, then

dialogues.speaker: BELL TOLLING MIDNIGHT
dialogues.text: EXT. SACRAMENTO CAPITOL STEPS —- A marble statue of the Holy Virgin looks down on a solemn ceremony waiting to begin. Reagan and Nancy stand before robed JUSTICE, heads bowed. Nancy is holding an old, tape Bible-Reagan’s mother’s Bible. A group of SPECTATORS shivers, as well as Loyal and Edith Davis, and little Ron, who’s half-asleep, being held up b Maureen. Nearby, the all-white members of Reagan’s administration—including ED MEESE, (we'll meet him later) Ben Welden, and Mike Deaver. When the TOLLING stops, Nancy hands the Bible to the Justice. Reagan puts one hand on it, and raises the other repeating after the Justice: 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, Ronald Wilson Reagan, do solemnly swear... ANGLE - Welden and Deaver watching, as the oath continues Deaver tries to restrain a yawn of exhaustion, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: For the love of Pete, why did we have to do this at midnight?

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: It’s her “special friend”. (off Deaver’s look) Some astrologer. Mommy talks to her on the phone almost every day. Welden nods to Nancy, who is standing next to Reagan, looking at him with so much adoration, it’s almost scary.

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: The astrologer said it had to be right after midnight. When Jupiter was rising. The same time they crown Kings. And one more thing—it had to be in a part of the Capital that had never been used for a swearing-in before. Deaver stares at him, wishing he could laugh. As Reagan finishes the oath, he turns to Nancy, gives her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: By the way, Mike, I’m giving you a special job. From now on, you’re on Mommy Watch.

dialogues.speaker: ACT FIVE
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: Music: the Beatles’ “Eleanor Rigby” over..LBJ grins, shows his gallbladder scar to the press. Mohammed Ali indicted for refusing to be drafted..Crowds Viet Nam protesters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “1967”. An explosion of shouts, chants, jeers from STUDENT DEMONSTRATORS. As Reagan comes out of the hall, escorted POLICE, he’s immediately met by another mob: the MEDIA.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’ve just put the Trustees of this University on notice. The people of this state are sick and tired of sit-ins and walk-outs. It’s time we had a few throw- outs!

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Go back to Hollywood, Bonzo!

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: The People put me here, son! I don’t know what drugs you’re on, but starting right now, you're going to obey the rules, or get out! Students hissing and booing. FLASHBULBS POP.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAN FRANCISCO CHRONICLE
dialogues.text: Reagan’s angry face beneath a headline: “Reagan fires Berkeley President: Vows Deep Cuts in State Spending”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mansion is a classic wedding-cake Victorian on a busy street. Traffic booms noisily past as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy follows Mike Deaver into the Governor’s mansion for the first time. The walls are peeling, the rug is torn. Dust hangs in the air. Outside, TRAFFIC ROARS PAST. 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) It certainly is historic, isn’t it? As if to punctuate this remark, ANOTHER TRUCK RUMBLES PAS EXT. REAGANS’ HOUSE - POOL - PACIFIC PALISADES - DAY Nancy beside the pool, watching Ron swim, as she talks to Carol Ryder on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s a fire-trap. We'd be asleep, the wiring would catch fire, and we'd all be burned alive.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RYDER
dialogues.text: You already know you don’t want to live there. Use your power.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But what about the press? The Governor’s family has always, always lived there...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RYDER
dialogues.text: What do they say in Hollywood? Buckle your seat-belt. It’s going to be a bumpy ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy takes a sip of her wine, and leans forward to Betsy Bloomingdale, furious:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So then Mike Deaver says, “Why don’t you fix it up? It can be your own little project, like Jackie Kennedy fixing up the White House.”

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Only Jackie Kennedy had a budget.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Exactly. I’m not going to have Ronnie living in a flea-trap. We’re going to rent a nice house, a beautiful house where we can entertain people from the industry, and ambassadors and all the rest of our friends, and anyone who doesn’t like it 63 \veisit”  can go to hell, and I don’t care how much it costs.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: You don’t?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (smile) Well, that brings me to you. Betsy smiles back, and turns to a PASSING WAITER:

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Waiter. Get me a phone, would you? (back to Nancy) Alfred and Holmes Tuttle got you into this mess. They should get you out. A PAUNCHY MAN IN A BAD SUIT is standing outside the door with a zoom lens, quietly taking pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | Two headlines (“Fancy Nancy Turns Up Her Nose at Govern Mansion” and "Nancy Eats Out, While Hubbie Cuts School Lunches”) are being prepared with a picture of Nancy and Betsy at lunch. AN EDITOR is looking at them. He picks “Fancy Nancy...”

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Go with this one. EXT. REAGANS’ RENTED. HOUSE ~ SACRAMENTO - DAY A garage door rises, and the Governor’s limo emerges from the dark, heading down the driveway. A SMALL CROWD OF DEMONSTRATORS are gathered on the lawn o the Reagans’ magnificent rented house. Nancy and little Ron are in the back seat. He’s got his school bag. Suddenly, out of nowhere, A TOMATO splats against the window. Nancy and Ron scream, and grab each other in fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO THE NEWSPAPER EDITOR'S OFFICE - as he picks a picture of a single, black Welfare mom with her children, matches it with a headline (“Welfare is a Cancer, Says Reagan”) and hands it to his ASSISTANT. 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go with this. JUMP CUT - The editor holds up a mock-up of another front page with another headline: “Reagan Issues Biggest Tax Hi in U.S. History”...

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: This one. JUMP CUT - a picture of a mental hospital stamped “Closed

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE STILL
dialogues.text: Police mug shot of a black man.

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: This is Aaron Mitchell. Convicted cop- killer on Death Row in San Quentin. Governor Brown upheld the sentence before he left office, and both the state and national Supreme Courts have denied a stay of execution. He’s scheduled to die tomorrow night. Mitchell's face projected on the wall of the Gubernatoria Cabinet Room-a dingy room with a long table, torn rug, an cigar burns on the furniture. Reagan and Mike Deaver are at the table, going through Mitchell’s file. ED MEESE, (40's), Reagan’s clemency secretary, continues:

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: He has his final mercy hearing this afternoon. After that, Governor, it’s up to you.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: Even Pat Brown said he should die. And he was against the death penalty. Reagan hands Mitchell’s file back to Meese. 65

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (grimly) Thanks, Ed. If the law says Aaron Mitchell has to die, then I agree. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: His mother is in the hallway. She’s got her attorney with her, and a helluva lot of reporters.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (nodding) It’s a sorry mess. Listen, Ed, I’d talk to her myself, but I’ve got to get on a plane in 20 minutes for a meeting in Los Angeles. Can you talk to her?

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: You might want to use the security entrance, sir. Reagan stands up, ending the meeting. Welden turns on the lights, and Mitchell’s projection disappears. As Reagan and Deaver leave, Meese turns to Ben Welden:

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: What’s the meeting in Los Angeles?

dialogues.speaker: BEN WELDEN
dialogues.text: (sigh) Academy Awards. ON MEESE’S INCREDULOUS FACE -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AARON MITCHELL’S MOTHER emerges, being held up by her ATTORNEY, sobbing in agony:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
dialogues.text: Why, Jesus, why? Why? Why? 66  MRS. MITCHELL’S ATTORNEY Ronald Reagan doesn’t care about people like us. He’s running for the Presidency... EXT. REAGANS’ RENTED HOUSE - SACRAMENTO - NIGHT Outside, AN ENORMOUS GROUP OF DEMONSTRATORS are gathered the dark, holding candles and ringing handbells, singing:

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: “We shall overcome We shall overcome...(etc.”) They hold up signs: “Ronald Reagan—No Academy Award for Legal Murder”; “California’s First Execution Since 1963”. INT. REAGANS’ RENTED HOUSE - CONTINUING Little Ron watching from his bedroom window in the dark. The door opens, and Nancy enters in her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ron. Get back into bed.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What are they singing?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s nothing. A song, that’s all. She lifts him back into bed, covers him with the blankets

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: But why are they mad at us? What'd we do?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Shhh..they’re not mad at us. Close your eyes. Sleep. Everything’s fine. Nancy kisses his forehead, smoothes his hair one last tim and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy emerges from Ron’s bedroom, passes Mike Deaver and NANCY REYNOLDS, her press secretary, hiding behind a curtain, looking out the window at the demonstrators. 67

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (hissing, furious) Tell me..What gives those..people..the right to terrify an 8-year-old boy? INT. REAGAN’S STUDY - SACRAMENTO HOUSE - CONTINUING Reagan is in his study, with REVEREND DONN MOOMAW, a born again former football star. They’re on their knees, prayi in front of a picture of a blonde, blue-eyed Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: My heart can’t be wrong, can it? If I love Jesus and follow his teachings, I can’t be wrong, can I?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND MOOMAW
dialogues.text: You're not wrong, Governor...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Aaron Mitchell is going to die, and it’s because of me. I could have saved him..

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND MOOMAW
dialogues.text: No one can save Aaron Mitchell from the sin he committed.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (anguished) Why do I feel as if it’s my fault?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND MOOMAW
dialogues.text: Let Jesus carry your burden, Governor. That’s all he asks-to carry your burden.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (choking) Why don’t they ring those bells every time there’s a murder? Moomaw begins to pray:

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND MOOMAW
dialogues.text: We pray for your will to be revealed, oh Lord... 68

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pray for your will to be revealed, oh Lord...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND MOOMAW
dialogues.text: We pray for Armageddon, when, according to your will, the dark forces of the world will be defeated by a leader from the West, who will be revealed as the Antichrist. He, too, will fall, and then Jesus Christ will triumph in the creation of a new heaven and a new earth...

dialogues.speaker: MOOMAW AND REAGAN
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PRISON BELL TOLLS as the gates of San Quentin part, allowing AN AMBULANCE to rumble slowly through A SMALL CROWD which is holding up signs (“Killing a Cop is Worse than Killing 3,000 Vietnamese Peasants?”; “Hang Down Your Head, Black Aaron—Po’Boy You Gonna Die”). AUDIBLE SOBBING as the ambulance drives off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The endless California sun is shining, as Nancy escorts journalist JOAN DIDION into the back yard.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My life began when I met Ronnie..It really did.He is my hero. She looks up, and sees Ron appear in the back door.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Skipper, you’re home! Come on down here, honey, I want you to meet somebody! Ron was sneaking away. He lamely turns, and comes out.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This is Joan Didion. She’s writing an article about us. Can you say hello?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: ‘Lo. Nancy smiles as hard as she can, painfully aware of Didion's critical stare, and continues: 69 Ne”

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: How’s Chuck’s cold?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Chuck doesn’t have a cold.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (trying) Chuck doesn’t have a cold?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No. Bruce has braces.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Bruce has braces?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Bye. With that, Ron runs back into the house. Nancy resumes walking, steering Didion toward the garden:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in being an absentee mother. I just don’t. INT. RON’S BEDROOM - CONTINUING CLASSICAL MUSIC playing loud. Ron is dancing around his room with joyous enthusiasm. Leaping, pirouetting, etc.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You lying, cheating, nasty little bitch. Worming your way into my house..Smiling at me..pretending everything’s oh-so-nice..Such a nice house..Such beautiful children..so nice to meet you, Mrs. Reagan..and your movies”..Blah Blah Blah..Talk about me having a phony smile, what about you? You’re not a writer, you’re an untalented liar. Hack! That’s what you are, a hack! REAGAN POKES HIS HEAD INTO THE BATHROOM AND SEES Nancy in the tub, up to her neck in bubbles. She startles.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie! Reagan sniffs the air suspiciously: 70

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Mmm. Bath-oil. And lots of it. You must be pretty upset.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh Ronnie..the article by that bitch Joan Didion came out today..she hates me. She positively hates me. She said I'm “living . in some daydream circa 1948”! And you know what else she said? She said the way I mother the children, it’s positively scary. She even made fun of the way I look at you! She called it “the Gaze”!

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Oh, she’s probably jealous.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That‘s what I said! I told her, she’s probably jealous! (lamely) I mean, here. In the tub. I told her. He laughs, goes out.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That‘s what I always liked about you, Nancy-pants! You’ve got guts! MOVIE - BLACK AND WHITE - “KNUTE ROCKNE; ALL AMERICAN” MUSIC: VIOLINS as Reagan (George Gipp), lies in a hospita bed, dying. His coach, Pat O’Brien (“Rock”) stands nearby

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN/GIPP
dialogues.text: Rock...ssomeday when the team’s up against it..when the breaks are beating the boys..ask them to go in there with all they've got..win just one for the Gipper.. INT. REAGANS’ DEN - CONTINUING AS MUSIC SOARS..SUPER: “1968” Nancy and Reagan are watching the movie on a screen, eati Popcorn, tears in their eyes. Reagan whispers..like Gipp:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got to do it, Mommy. 721

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | Just once. I’ve got to run for the Presidency at least once. Pause. Nancy turns to him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Some of the boys think I should run. They did a poll, they think I can get more than 60% of the conservative vote.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie..you can’t run for the Presidency. You just got elected Governor.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Do you think it’s too soon?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, I think it’s too soon. It’s way too soon. Ronnie. (he’s not listening) Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy corners Mike Deaver in his office. She’s mad.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Who told Ronnie he could win the nomination in ‘68?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (hastily) . It wasn’t me. It was the polls.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Mike, it’s too early. He doesn’t have enough experience. Not only that, he can’t possibly win. Nixon has it sewn up.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: But you’ve got to admit, he’s got a lot of people excited. Nancy looks out the door to make sure no one’s around. 72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s more than that. My friend.my friend \ says it’s not going to work. He'll lose by 7 an enormous margin.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, if it doesn’t happen, so what? He’ll still be the Governor of California. He can run again in ‘72. It’s a joke. Nancy ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Mike, you don’t get it. He'll have lost. Lost. Don’t you see? (intensely) Ronald Reagan does not lose elections. Ronald Reagan is not a loser. Her vehemence drives Deaver into. silence. EXT. ORME CAMPUS — NIGHT INT. PATTI’S DORM ROOM - CONTINUING Patti and her boyfriend, GARY (18), making out in her roo She comes up for air long enough to say:

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: If we're going to do it, Gary, we’ve got to do it now.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: But Patti, what if they come after us?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I’ve got it all figured out. My brother Mike’s working in Phoenix. I'll get him to sign me out for a weekend visit. By the time they know I’m gone, we’1ll be in Canada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speedboats are being fixed in the background, as Mike, in mechanic’s overalls, talks to Patti on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Patti, this is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT Patti at school, on a payphone: PATTI . I love him. He loves me. He'll go straight to Vietnam unless you help me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: - But you’re asking me to lie for you...

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I’m asking you to be my brother. Please, Mike. Please. Help me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... ‘ He hangs up. Worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DELEGATION-the Headmaster and his wife, faculty members students—are waiting as two cars drive in through the gat The Secret Service gets out of the first car. Reagan gets out of the back seat of the second car, leavi Nancy and the DRIVER inside. PATTI SITTING UNDER A TREE NEARBY in classic hippie drag. She gets up and crosses to Reagan, longing to hug him.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (grinning) Hi, Shorty. We just happened to be in the neighborhood...

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Oh Daddy. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It‘s alright. All’s well that ends well. Thanks to Mike. Now get in the car. I’ve got to talk to the Headmaster, and see if I can keep him from throwing you out. INT. REAGAN’S CAR - CONTINUING Nancy is in the back seat, privacy window separating her from the driver, a.c. running. Patti opens the door, and climbs in. Pause. 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me..are you pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: (a harsh laugh) You know what, Mom? We never even did it. (off Nancy's reaction) I’m still a virgin. Cross my lying little heart. Nancy struggles not to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Go change your clothes. Your father’s taking us to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I’m not changing. If he wants to take me out, then I’m going like this.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Don’t argue. Go.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: No. This is it. Take it or leave it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why do you do this to me? Why do you have to fight me?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Why do you hate me?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don’t hate you.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: You've always hated me. You’ve hated me since I was a little girl. Go on, hit me. You can’t hurt me, anymore. Nancy slaps her. Patti reels, comes back up defiant.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE CAR -
dialogues.text: The Secret Service Agents heard the slap, and exchange a glance. In the b.g., Reagan approaches. INT. REAGANS’ CAR - CONTINUING As Reagan climbs into the car, he turns to Patti: 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, did Mommy tell you the news?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: No. Nancy obliges:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They want your father to run for President.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Daddy, are you serious? You just started being Governor.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) That’s what Mommy said. At least you two agree on something. The two cars drive away, vanishing in a SWIRLING CLOUD OF DUST which becomes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “1968” More images of smoke and fire: a bonfire at an anti-war rally..tear gas swirling in Detroit as blacks riot..RFK d in a hotel kitchen..Martin Luther King iying on a motel balcony in Memphis..Smoke shrouds the Capitol Building... And A BATTERY OF CAMERAS FLASH as Reagan announces:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I seek the nomination for the highest office in our land because I have no choice. Everything we hold dear—the American ideals that have made us the envy of the world—-is under attack. It’s time to fight back. He’s standing amid a crowd on THE CAPITOL STEPS (SACRAMENTO). Nancy murmurs to Deaver and Welden, stonily

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s not his time. He’s got Saturn in his | tenth house. He’s going to lose. And it’s you people who pushed him into it. Welden steps back, mutters to Deaver, sarcastically: 76

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: Alas..Who knows what’s in the stars? Nancy doesn’t hear: she’s watching Reagan with a look of utter doom on her face.

dialogues.speaker: INF. REPUBLICAN CONVENTION, (1968)
dialogues.text: MC’S VOICE Ladies and gentlemen, the next President of the United States, Richard Milhouse Nixon. RICHARD AND PAT NIXON, TRICIA AND JULIE enter, smiling broadly. Nixon thrusts his arms into the air in victory.

dialogues.speaker: END OF ACT FIVE
dialogues.text: 77 aa NSasast”

dialogues.speaker: ACT SIX
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: Watergate hearings. Nixon and Pat leaving the White House. Gerry Ford and Betty waving goodbye to their helicopter. INT. REAGAN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT SUPER: “1973". Reagan in pjs, lying on the sofa, eating cookies. Ron (15 sits up, holding a school notebook, being “official”:

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Shoot . Ron switches on a tape-recorder. The reel begins to turn.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So, Dad. I mean Governor Reagan. As you prepare to leave office, what do you think is the biggest achievement of your administration?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Are you speaking as a reporter, or as my son?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Dad. Come on. It’s the school paper.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s see..Well, I know people hate to hear this..but the state of California has finally been forced to become fiscally responsible..which meant that, like it or not, we had to end the free lunch that a lot of our citizens had come to expect.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you closed down two-thirds of the state mental hospitals, and all those people ended up on the street. (off Reagan’s look of surprise) Dad, I’m not stupid. 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) No, you’re not. But I have much more faith in the resilience of the American people than you do. They always pull themselves up by their own bootstraps. eat

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: But you raised taxes more than any other Governor in United States history. I mean, you’re a Republican, you're supposed to be against raising taxes.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, I've got a theory about economics. If the rich have more money to spend on buying things and building businesses, it will naturally end up helping the poor people. It’s called “trickle-down”. Pause. Ron is turning cautious.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You want to run for President again, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Ron..You know me better than that. Reagan laughs. Ron doesn’t. He’s worried.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What if you turn into another Richard Nixon? Reagan is surprised. Silent for several moments.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Listen, Ron. I go to bed at night with the knowledge that I’ve done my best to see and hope that these people..that I’ve directly appointed..meet the standards that I want them to meet. But there can be someone..while I’m sleeping..doing something he shouldn't do, and it will break over my head. Silence, as Ron tries to figure this one out.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So are you saying, you are or you aren’t going to run for President in ‘76? Reagan’s eyes twinkle, as he answers:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Ron, I tell you from the bottom of my heart..I have utterly and absolutely no ambitions to be President in 1976. INT. NANCY’S BEDROOM - DAY Nancy sitting on her bed in her dressing gown. She swallo a Valium as she talks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s the strangest thing..In the midst of all this packing and leaving..and not knowing what’s going to happen to us, once Ronnie leaves office..I keep thinking about my real father. Isn’t that funny? I haven’t thought about him in so long.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RYDER
dialogues.text: Sometimes, as we get older, our childhood doesn’t fade away. It gets stronger.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. That’s it..I can’t stop thinking about him..wondering why he left..Why? Why did he leave? PAN TO A FADED PHOTO OF A MAN (1920's) on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a dance class. Ron is one guy out of two in a class full. of girls, but he’s dancing harder than anybody else He’s dancing so hard, it’s as if he’s trying to work something out—some unresolved anger. The TEACHER stops hi

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: Ron. Ron. Slow down. You’re pushing too hard. Ron tries to slow down, but he keeps dancing and pushing. 80

dialogues.speaker: DANCER TEACHER
dialogues.text: Do you hear me? You’re going to hurt yourself. Stop. Everybody stop. Ron, I want to talk to you. Everybody stops. Ron follows the teacher to the corner.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: You tell your folks you want to dance? (Ron shakes his head) Why not, are you ashamed?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (aggressively) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: You've got talent, Ron. Tell them, before you hurt yourself so badly that you can’t dance. (then) . Okay, kids. Start over. Positions. Music. The music begins again. The dancing resumes. INT. PATTI’S HOUSE (TOPANGA CANYON) - AFTERNOON MUSIC: SOMEONE COMPOSING ON AN ELECTRIC GUITAR. All aroun anti-war posters, mood lamps, incense, etc. Patti (22) is lying on the sofa, smoking a joint as she stares at the front page of the paper, which features a photograph of Gerry Ford.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Gerry Ford is a real argument for birth control. Gerry Ford..Richard Nixon..Not to mention my father. The pigs have taken over, you know? Bernie? Bernie? She goes into the kitchen, where BERNIE (24) is sitting o the kitchen counter, playing an electric guitar as he watches soup boil on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Jesus, Bernie. You’re supposed to be watching the soup.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: I am. 81 “au”  Patti turns off the stove, and puts her hand on Bernie’s strings to stop the music. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: The political machine is bent on destroying us. The only thing we can do is lay down our bodies in front of it. Sacrifice ourselves, if we have to. (pause) Even if nobody else will stand up for their conscience, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan swimming down, down through dark water. Panicky, searching. HIS HEART POUNDING. He sees a child’s hand emerging from the black. He grabs it, and pulls—it’s a CHILD’S BODY, EYES OPEN, DROWNED. Reagan SCREAMS UNDERWATER. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - TWILIGHT Reagan sits bolt upright in bed, in a terror. Nancy reach out to him:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Bad dream?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Somebody was drowning... She pulls him down again, stroking his hair, consoling hi as she has, a hundred times:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Nobody’s drowning. We’re all here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan, shirtless, chopping wood. He’s strong. He can spl a log with one chop. He pauses, wipes the sweat from his brow, looks out over the mountains. It’s so beautiful. Nancy sits on a log nearby, drinking a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think, screw politics. I was made for chopping trees..and dredging ponds..and fixing the roof... 82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’1l1 be plenty of time for that, later. After you're done being President, and we’re lying around, eating bonbons and building Presidential libraries.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You’re a troublemaker, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Me? I’m the one who's kept you from messing your life up.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Hey. Watch your mouth. He starts toward her. She runs away, laughing. INT. REAGANS’ HOUSE - REAGANS’ OFFICE - DAY SUPER: “1975” Reagan is on head-set, talking into the mic, finishing hi weekly radio address.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Status quo. That’s Latin for the mess we're in. (beat) Well, that’s it for this week, folks. Just remember: to err is human—it takes a government computer to really louse things up. See you next week. He turns off the mic and looks up, as Nancy sticks her he into the room.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Guess who's here? Mike Deaver sticks his head in, behind her.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Mike! What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Hi, Governor.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Never mind asking him to stay for lunch. I already did. 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan gets up, follows them out. FOLLOW NANCY, DEAVER, AND REAGAN DOWN. THE HALL - passing bedrooms, heading outside towards the pool.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, this radio-thing is the most fun I’ve had in years. i DEAVER More fun than running for President?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Anything’s more fun than that. They pass the kitchen, where the COOK and maid are workin

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Gilda, get Mr. Deaver a beer, would you? And add an extra place at the table. } i DEAVER Well, I got a letter from the Young Americans for Freedom, yesterday. They want to endorse you against Gerry Ford.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I can’t run against Gerry Ford, Mike. I'd be splitting the party.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: He’s the incumbent, but that’s about all.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Did you see him this weekend? He tripped, coming down the steps of Air Force One. I thought he was going to land face-first on the tarmac. Everyone winces, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: If Nixon hadn’t resigned, he’d never have gotten near the office.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That’s not the point. If Ronnie runs now, he'll be seen as a spoiler. It’1ll ruin his political career. 84

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I disagree. I do. I think this could be the Governor's year, if he wants it. As they emerge OUTSIDE, BY THE POOL:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: What's worse? Challenging Ford for the White House, or letting him sink the party? INT. REAGAN DINING ROOM — NIGHT Reagan sitting at the head. Nancy’s next to him, hands folded, looking unbelievably tense.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: ~My political advisors say the grassroots support is there, and it’s time I put myself on the line again. If I don’t, I’11 always feel like the guy who sat on the bench and never got into the game. So..I‘m announcing my entrance into the presidential race. Michael nods happily. Maureen, stunned. Ron, silent. Ny Patti is conspicuously absent.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That‘’s good, Dad. That’s great. You know I’1l support you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Dad, no. If you lose again, it’1ll be the 2° time. People will remember you as a loser. The sting of her words hangs in the air. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ron? You’re being quiet.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So are you. (to his father) You don’t need to know what I think. I’m sure your so-called political advisors have given you every angle. Seas”

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ron. Say it. 85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron and his mother exchange a look. Then:

dialogues.speaker: . RON
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad. As far as I can tell, your advisors have done nothing but get you into trouble. They’re just a bunch of nicotine-stained, wheezing, gray-toned - amoral— (he breaks off) I think you lower yourself by listening to them.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You don’t think I’d make a good President. Pause. Ron twists, uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Do you really need to be President, Dad? Really? Can't you be happy doing..something else? Reagan is taken aback. His words sound hollow. REAGAN . I can do a lot of things for America. Ron looks at him, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheering crowd is gathered, Reagan waving from a podium As he moves to his right to join Nancy, there is an upsur of movement behind him. Somebody shouts “Dutch!” and TWO SECRET SERVICE AGENTS dive onto a dark-haired man behind him. Nancy stares in horror at a gun waving above the wrestlin trio.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie! INT. AIRPORT SECURITY OFFICE — DAY Reagan is shaken, accepting a glass of water from one of the Secret Service agents, who are even more shaken.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I don't understand what all the fuss is about, I’m okay. 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we asked you to leave the podium to your left...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, but I heard somebody call me “Dutch” and I thought it was someone I knew back in Towa... Nancy slams down her glass of water and comes off her chair, furious:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, don’t forget! From now on, if they say “Go left”, go left! Do you hear me, Ronnie?! Reagan does that self-deprecating head shake, and his mou crinkles, as he says:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Aw, Mommy..Don’t be so upset. It was just a toy gun! Nancy stands there, unsure whether to shoot herself or di where she’s standing.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY GOLDWATER
dialogues.text: “As far as the Panama Canal goes..Governor Reagan’s views spring from a surprisingly dangerous state of mind that could needlessly lead this country into open military conflict...”

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Dangerous? Barry Goldwater thinks I’m dangerous? He used to be my friend... Nancy turns down the tv.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He’s betrayed you. You stumped for him, back in ‘64. You knocked yourself out to get him elected President— and now look how he treats you. Oh, Ronnie.I’m tired. This isn’t working out the way we hoped. 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to him, holds him, rests her chin on top of his head.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: The campaign is broke. Though John Sears has some idea about a fundraiser.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We can always quit and go home. Pause.”

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: No. No. I’m taking this campaign all the way to the convention in Kansas City. Even if we lose every damn primary along the way.

dialogues.speaker: THE REPUBLICAN CONVENTION
dialogues.text: A floor demonstration: Reagan supporters chanting heavily and waving signs (“Reagan in '76"):

dialogues.speaker: IN THE REAGAN SKY-BOX
dialogues.text: Reagan motions for the demonstration to stop, smiling gamely. Nancy—in a white dress with black diamonds—looks around the convention, with a doomed smite on her face...

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the current and next President of the United States..Gerald R. Ford!

dialogues.speaker: THE PODIUM
dialogues.text: JERRY, BETTY, SUSAN, STEVE arriving on the podium, and hugging each other in happy triumph. Gerry takes the mic:

dialogues.speaker: GERRY FORD
dialogues.text: Ron, will you come down..and bring Nancy! The whole convention. goes insane. As the Reagans make th way out of the skybox..the Convention Band launches into “California, Here I Come!”... INT. PATTI’S HOUSE (TOPANGA CANYON) - NIGHT 88 Patti and Bernie are watching the tv..where Nancy and Re arrive at the podium, shaking hands with the Fords. Michael, Ron and Maureen are behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Well, he lost. Now you don’t have to go to Canada.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: (dismally) He'll. run again in ’'80. My mother will see to it.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: Reagan and Nancy, arms around each other, waving to the crowd. He’s smiling, happily—ever the actor on center stage. She’s smiling, her heart breaking.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: {moving to the mic) Mr. President, Mrs. Ford... (looking out across the sea of faces) Someone asked me to write a letter for a time capsule that is going to be opened in Los Angeles a hundred years from now, on our Tricentennial. They suggested I write something about the problems and issues of the day... ANGLE - Gerry Ford realizing that his own speech has beco nothing but a warm-up speech for Reagan’s.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We live in a world in which the great powers have poised and aimed at each other horrible missiles of destruction, nuclear weapons, that can in a matter of minutes destroy, virtually, the civilized world we | live in... THE CONVENTION FLOOR - Under every red, white and blue straw hat is a face transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: And suddenly it dawned on me, those who read this letter a hundred years from now will know whether those missiles were fired. Will they look back with appreciation and say, “Thank God for those | people in 1976 who headed off that loss of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89  freedom, who kept our world from nuclear destruction? By now, many faces across the floor are wet with tears.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: This is our challenge; and this is why..we must go forth from here united, determined | that what a great general said a few years ago is true: there is no substitute for victory, Mr. President. if Reagan glides offstage. The audience breaks into a ROA POLITICIANS hurry to him, pumping his hand with respect. Mike Deaver’s on the floor, turns to the Aide next to him

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: See how smart the old man is? He gave the best speech of the entire Convention, and never even mentioned Gerry Ford. AS THE CROWD CONTINUES TO GO WILD...

dialogues.speaker: ACT SEVEN
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - Jimmy Carter talking about the ener crisis as a national catastrophe..Gas lines..In Iran, cro storm U.S. embassy and take almost 100 hostages... SUPER: “1979”. EXT. REAGANS’ PALISADES HOUSE - NIGHT A cluster of cars parked outside. SOUND: MENS’ LAUGHTER. INT. REAGAN’S DEN - NIGHT Reagan sitting in his den, holding court with Mike Deaver Ben Welden, Arthur Bloomingdale, Holmes Tuttle, and a new man, JOHN SEARS.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: So President Carter’s working late one night when old Teddy Roosevelt’‘s ghost drifts into the Oval Office. Jimmy turns down Das Rheingold, jumps up and offers him his chair. “No,” says TR, “you’re the president now, I’m just haunting the place. How’s it going?” “Not too good,” says Jimmy, “th’Iranians have imprisoned 52 of our diplomatic personnel, and having been holding them for a year.” “So you sent in the Marines, right?” says TR. “Uh no, but Ah registered a strong protest at th’ United Nations.” TR says in a cold voice, “Anything else?” “Well, uh, th’ Russians just invaded Afghanistan.” TR says, “And of course you retaliated with every weapon in our arsenal.” Jimmy says, “No, but Ah’ve withdrawn our ath’letes from th’Olympic Games.” At this, TR blows his top and shouts, “The next thing you’re going to tell me is you’ve given back the Panama Canal!” MORE LAUGHTER. Nancy speaks from the doorway, where she’s been listening:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s getting late. I’m sorry, but you’d all better go, before the Governor turns into a pumpkin. Everybody stands up, stub out their cigars. John Sears comes up to Reagan and Nancy, positioning himself for an 91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: introduction. Sears is young (30's), charismatic, good- looking.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Nancy, you remember John Sears? He tells me he worked for us back in 1976, during the second presidential campaign.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, certainly. Hello, John. Nice to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SEARS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: He's going. to be our new campaign manager.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (wryly) Really? So if my husband loses again, I’11 have you to blame? MORE LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan stands at a bank of microphones. He and Nancy are dressed in fancy embroidered cowboy outfits.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (nodding to the land around him) America was born in country like this—a big dream for a big land. Mr. Carter tells us we live in an America of “diminished expectations”—-well, those are big words for a very small dream. One of the reporters—BILL SHELBY—interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: Governor Reagan—

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: No questions. No questions.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Deaver rolls his eyes, as Shelby continues: 92

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: Your love of the land is obvious. But President Carter says your environmental policy would turn land like yours over to the polluters.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: If he’ll check the facts, he’ll find that more pollution is caused by rotting vegetation than by any so-called polluters—his name for big business, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: By “rotting vegetation”, sir, do you mean trees?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS 1 AND 2
dialogues.text: Sir! Sir! Are you saying trees cause pollution?? Deaver winces as the reporters take it down. Nancy steps forward to Reagan, and murmurs in his ear:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (whisper) I think it’s time to show you around this place.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (to the crowd, smiling) I think it’s time to show you around this place. The reporters heard Nancy’s murmur, and write that down, too. Mike Deaver is dying, as Reagan and Nancy cross to their horses and climb up.

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: (singing quietly to his buddies) “Happy trails to you...” SNICKERS AMONG THE REPORTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. A knock at the front door. Nancy opéns it, and admits Mike Deaver.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming so late. 93

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: It's okay. What’s the pow-wow? Nancy walks him toward the living room, where Reagan is talking to John Sears. She whispers to him:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s John. He’s saying things about you.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I should have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nancy and Mike enter the living room, Reagan looks nervous, avoids Mike’s gaze. Deaver crosses to the bar, fills his glass with whiskey. While there, he notices a poster on the counter: a photo a tree with the caption “CUT ME DOWN BEFORE I KILL MORE”. He crumples it, and puts it in the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Jesus, this poster is everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: It happened on your watch.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I can’t control every goddam thing, John.

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: It’s not only the poster. It’s the money. We have serious money problems.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I know we’re behind on fund-raising, but it's still early—

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: It’s not early. It’s late. We've only got 6 months until the elections. We need more money, and we need it now. You've been campaign manager until now, and you’re just not cutting it.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Is that what you think, Governor? Do you think I’m not cutting it? Reagan is examining his fingernails. Sears. takes control 94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. A campaign is like a symphony orchestra. Everybody's got to stay in their seat, and play the same music. rd

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (getting mad) What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: Mike, I’ve told the Governor it’s got to be either you or me. I can’t run a campaign when I’m being continually undermined.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But John, Mike’s been with me for more than 15 years...

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: I know, Governor. I appreciate his loyalty. But I can’t stand by, and watch you lose again. I love my country too much. Reagan turns to Nancy, who slowly nods. Mike sees it.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: No, Governor. You don’t have to make that choice. I’11 resign. Deaver walks out of the living room. Reagan follows him.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Mike. Mike. Please don’t. Don’t go. Nancy and John Sears stand alone in silence, looking at each other. Finally, she speaks, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You love this, don’t you, John?

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: I’m a patriot, Mrs. Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. That’s what they all say. OC: SOUND OF THE FRONT DOOR CLOSING. Reagan comes back in 95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The biggest man here just left the room. Sears doesn’t even seem to hear Reagan. He picks up his calendar, and starts flipping through it.

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: | Now, let’s talk about schedule. I'm going | to send you to New Hampshire on Friday. Mrs. Reagan, if you don’t mind, I think you should let the Governor go alone. Nancy’s eyes harden.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Alone? But all the other candidates’ wives—

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. At this stage of the game, you're just a distraction. The focus needs to be on the Governor, himself. Nancy turns to Reagan, curiously. He looks away. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT Reagan and Nancy lying in bed together. Moonlight on their faces

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: John Sears is the Devil.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: He’s not the Devil. But why won’t he look me in the eye. He always looks me in the tie.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Though, if anyone can get you elected, he can.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So we’re going to do what he says, no matter what?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (sigh) I’m 68. If I don't do it now, next time I'll be 72. Please, honey. Stick with me, for just one more round. Please. 96 She puts her arms around him. He puts his arms around he

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But what are we going to do without each other?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Damned if I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secret Service men in the driveway, standing around a red Toyota, which is covered with anti-nuke stickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti is doubled up on the sofa, in obvious pain. She’s pale, trembling.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I read in the paper, Dad fired Mike Deaver.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He didn’t fire him. Mike quit. He has personal problems he has to work out.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Personal problems? What kind of personal problems?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti, you didn’t drive all the way here from San Francisco to talk about Mike Deaver.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Bernie said to me, Why did they fire him? I said, Bernie you have to understand something about my parents. This is the beginning of the biggest movie my parents will ever star in, and all of us are bit players. We don’t matter. No we don’t. The movie's more important than anything else. If I ever leave, all they’1l do is call Central Casting and a new girl will be brought in to take my place. Isn’t that right, Mom? 97

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’ve been smoking, Patti, but you’d better get off it.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: No, Mom, you see that’s the problem. I haven’t been smoking anything. Oh God, I wish I were stoned right now. You don’t have any dope, do you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I‘1l take anything. Darvon. Valium. Quaaludes. Anything at all. I’m hurting so much, Mom. Nancy is beginning to get scared.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti..what have you done to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti sees the look on Nancy’s face, and almost laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: You mean, did I get an abortion? Hardly. Hardly, Mom. No, I got my tubes tied. Stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I‘1l be damned if I’11 bring any kids into this world..the world you and your kind have created. I won’t. I just won’t, you hear? (starting to cry) Because it all sucks, see? All of it. The world is one big polluted mess, and all the good guys are dead. JFK. RFK. Martin Luther King. Even Elvis. Elvis is dead. He would have made a better president than Daddy. (breaks off) Mommy, help me, please! Please! Patti sobs. Nancy is at her side in a second, putting her arms around her, holding her, consoling her... 98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh baby..baby, what have you done?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I’m so scared, Mommy..I’m scared. I asked the doctor, I said, Is it supposed to hurt this much? I mean it hurts so much, Mommy, I feel like someone stuck a knife into me... Patti is a terrified 5-year-old. Nancy holds her, rocking her back and forth, stroking her hair.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It's okay..really, baby..We’1l get you another doctor, and you'll stay here, until you get better. Everything's going to be alright, it really will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Hampshire is cold. Forbidding. No fun at all. Reagan stands outside a factory, looking for hands to shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti lies on a chaise beside the pool, reading. SOUND: LAUGHTER. Patti looks up from her book at Nancy on the } other side of the pool, in an expensive new dress, paradi back and forth in front of Betsy Bloomingdale, who claps. Patti scowls, hides in her book. INT. REAGAN’S HOTEL ROOM —- NEW HAMPSHIRE Reagan talking to Sears. In the b.g., Ben Welden and SEAR ASSISTANT.

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: I’m not saying Ed Meese is a bad person, Governor, but look at him—he’s completely out of the loop, and his briefcase is full of position papers which nobody’s even interested in! I don’t know what he’s doing here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SECRET SERVICEMEN lounging in the hallway, cupping their ears to the door, eavesdropping: 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled) You dirty rotten bastard! This is the same speech you made when I agreed to let Mike Deaver go! I’11 be goddamned if I'll stand by and see Ed Meese run out of this campaign, too! The other Secret Service agent starts clapping his hands, in obvious support of Reagan. INT. REAGAN’S ROOM - CONTINUING John Sears is furious, tight-lipped:

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: Governor, this is your campaign. You have to do what you need to do. But I can’t stay under these conditions.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you look me in the eye, you son of a bitch? You can’t even do that!

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) I’ve got another meeting to get to. We'll have to finish this conversation later. Sears nods to Reagan and Welden, and leaves. His assistan hurries after him. Reagan turns to Welden as soon as they’re gone.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Get. Me. My. Wife. Back.

dialogues.speaker: WELDEN
dialogues.text: (smile) You said it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver is on the phone. Happy, sleepy. But happy.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: What about Sears?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY ON THE PHONE IN HER BEDROOM -
dialogues.text: it NANCY We want you to come back. Will you? 100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, you won’t be able to keep me away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy disembarking from a small plane. As she steps onto the tarmac, she runs to Reagan. They throw their arms around each other. INT. REAGAN’S CAR - DAY Nancy and Reagan in the back seat. She hands him a letter

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Here. This is John Sears’ letter of resignation. Hand it to him, and tell him to sign it. Give it to him this afternoon, while people are still voting. That way, if we lose, he won’t think that’s why he’s being fired. And if we win, we won’t seem ungrateful. They smile at each other. He takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secret Servicemen are standing there, as Sears comes out of Reagan’s room with his briefcase. He’s pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: SEARS
dialogues.text: I’m not surprised. To hell with this. I quit. Sears’ assistant follows him, more pissed. Nancy appears, following them all the way down the hall to the elevator. The elevator opens. Sears and his aide step onto it. The last thing they see is Nancy’s face, smiling:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry things turned out this way, John. I do hope we won’t be enemies.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Jimmy Carter and Reagan. (ARCHIVAL TAPE)

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: You have no experience in world affairs. You would negate treaties limiting nuclear weapons. You would bring us to the brink of war by plunging us into a dangerous 101 ww

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: arms race..You would increase defense spending while eliminating medicare and social security. Can you deny any of that, Mr. Reagan? INT. PATTI‘S MODEST (LA) APARTMENT - AFTERNOON Patti and Bernie are watching the debates on tv. She’s talking to Ron on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Ron. Are you watching this farce? INTERCUT WITH RON’S TINY NYC APARTMENT - EVENING The walls are decorated with dance posters. Ron’s on his way out, holding his dance bag labelled Joffrey Dance Co.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Can’t. Got rehearsal. Doria’s watching it, though. He turns to DORIA PALMIERI, 29, a very attractive dancer, who is waiting at the door, gives her.a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Oooh, look out. I’11 tell Mom you guys are living together.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (laughs) You're too late, she already read about it in the tabloids. So what? I think she’d rather have me living with a woman than being gay. So you still living with them?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I had to move out. It was great being with Mom..for about 3 days. Then we got into a screaming match about Dad. How can you love somebody so much, and hate everything he stands for? INT. MIKE’S HOUSE (L.A.) - NIGHT Mike, 35, is glued to the tv: A CLOSEUP OF REAGAN, TIGHT- LIPPED LISTENING TO CARTER. 102

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have called Dad before it started. I could have wished him good luck— A woman with a baby appears behind him, his wife COLLEEN.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Why would you call him, Mike, when he never calls you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (rooting at the tv) Don’t let him get away with that, Dad! Let him have it! INTERCUT REAGAN WITH DEBATE TAPE OF CARTER.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Carter seems to want to depict me as some sort of warmonger. I’m a father of sons, and a grandson. I don’t want to see another generation of American boys sent to die on some foreign shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen, 41, is watching intensely from the audience. Nan : and Deaver sit nearby.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: To put this in perspective, I had a discussion with my daughter Amy a few days ago. I asked her what the most important issue was, and she said nuclear weaponry, and the control of nuclear arms... The audience TITTERS. Nancy leans over to Deaver, murmurs

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Amy is what, 12 years old?

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: The fact is, Mr. Reagan has a long- standing inclination toward the use of military power.. Reagan looks at him, shaking his head in pity.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, there you go again. 103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience bursts into laughter and applause. Deaver an Nancy smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MODERATOR
dialogues.text: Order, order!

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (jumping to her feet) Go get him, Dad! Reagan turns to the camera, to the people:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Just ask yourself this: are you better off than you were 4 years ago? Is our economy better than it was 4 years ago? Is America as strong and respected as it was 4 years ago? If your answer to these questions is yes, then it’s obvious who you should vote for. INT. PATTI’S APARTMENT - She watches as Reagan concludes:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But if you don’t think the course we've been on for the last 4 years is the one we should follow for the next 4..then I could suggest another choice that you have. The audience applauds.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: (in horror) It’s going to happen. It’s really going to happen...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. POLLING PLACE, (SANTA MONICA)
dialogues.text: It's in someone’s garage. In the driveway, a LOCAL CAMERA CREW is taping, as Patti emerges from a curtained booth.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL REPORTER
dialogues.text: Patti! Did you vote for your father?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: (thin smile) I can’t. I’m a registered Democrat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104  Nancy comes out of the bathroom, a towel wrapped around her.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can’t stand it any longer, I’m going to turn on the TV. INTERCUT REAGAN stepping into the shower.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s too early, the polls haven’t even closed.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They have, in the East. The phone rings; she answers.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Hello. ANGLE - Ronnie showering, as Nancy raps on the glass.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Honey? President Carter is on the phone...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Tell him I’m in the shower. Nancy raps on the glass again, harder.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’m joking, I’m joking. He turns off the water, wraps a towel around himself, goes to the phone in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (carefully) Hello, Mr. President. Nancy stares at him, as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You too, Mr. President. Thank you. He hangs up. Nancy waits. 105 and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) He’s conceded. He wanted to congratulate me. They stare at each other, frozen. On tv, JOHN CHANCELLOR REPORTING IT’S REAGAN IN A LANDSLIDE. Slowly, she crosses to him, and takes his hand. They turn to the tv, in their towels...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “1987” Deaver and SENATOR JOHN TOWER, riding up in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I told the President that he could be impeached. He’s scared. But he’s not too scared to listen. (pause) Senator Tower..I don’t know if he’s innocent. But all he wanted was to free the hostages. That’s all he wanted. Tower shakes his head, looks front.

dialogues.speaker: TOWER
dialogues.text: I’d like to believe that. I really would. The elevator doors pop open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver and Tower walk down the hall to Reagans’ door. The White House Guard knocks on the door with a gloved hand.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE GUARD
dialogues.text: Mr. President..It’s Mr. Deaver and Senator Tower, sir. SUPER: “TO BE CONTINUED”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “1987” Reagan in his chair, wearing his pajamas and bathrobe. He looks old. Michael Deaver sits next to him. Facing Reagan is SENATOR JOHN TOWER, head of the Tower Commission. Tower is leaning forward, intensely.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: Mr. President..as head of the Presidential Commission to investigate Iran-Contra..I’m here to tell you our findings. One year ago, you personally approved the sale of antitank missiles to Iran for the purpose of exchanging arms for hostages. You knew that Iran was on the United States’ list of terrorist nations, and you knew that Congress had enacted an embargo against Iran. Nevertheless, you defied the United States Congress, and you defied the law. Reagan's left hand twitches. Tower sees it, but continues

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: The money from the arms sales..38 million dollars..was channeled through a covert network of dummy corporations..4 million was diverted to the Nicaraguan Contras. Of the remaining 34 million, a majority wound up in private pockets. In conclusion, Mr. President, the action that you ordered has not only destroyed this country’s foreign policy..it turned us into the laughing- stock of the Middle East, and the world. Reagan looks even more shaken. He glances at Nancy, who i in the doorway, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Senator Tower..but I just..I can’t believe that anyone under me would do the things you described...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: No, sir. Not “anybody”. You, sir. You. You ) did it. You approved it. : 107

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: No, no, that’s not true. I... don’t remember anything about this...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: (grimly determined) Mr. President, I’m a Republican. You're the leader of my party. I believe in you, and I respéct you. I hope you respect me, too, which is why you hired me to carry out this investigation.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I do respect you, Senator Tower..but—

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: (overriding) I came here tonight to suggest..to urge you, sir..to hire a criminal attorney. Because what we're talking about here is impeachment. Impeachment . Nancy interrupts, breaking:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop. You can’t treat him like this. Reagan's imploding-he’s lost and frightened. Tower modifi his tone, talking to him gently, as if toa child:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: I know you don’t remember, Mr. President... but the Commission has ample evidence. We have memos, we have testimony..Whether or not you remember it now, there was a time when you knew everything. Silence. Deaver rubs his face, on the verge of tears:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ..Jesus Christ... Reagan pulls together the shreds of his dignity.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Senator Tower..I want to thank you for running the investigation the way you have..for your services to this country. 108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sir, you've got to take responsibility for what you did. You’ve got to stand up and say it to the American people..or else you’1l be impeached. Deaver leans forward to Reagan. Quietly, gently:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DEAVER
dialogues.text: Your speechwriter can write it for you, sir..whatever you want to say..You can say it in your own way.

dialogues.speaker: TOWER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sir. I’m so sorry. Reagan turns to Nancy. They hold each other in their gaze across a gulf of desperation.

dialogues.speaker: INAUGURAL PARADE -
dialogues.text: SUPER: “1981”, over ARMY BAND MUSIC (“YANKEE DOODLE”) . Reagan and Nancy walking down Pennsylvania Avenue, smilin waving to the CROWDS..Everywhere, POLICE..SECRET SERVICE AGENTS on the rooftops..Reagan is beaming, playing the ro of President. Nancy is smiling, too, but glancing at the crowd nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy is being zipped into her dress, by ADOLFO’S TWO ASSISTANTS, as ADOLFO himself supervises. She looks fabulous. Strong, glamorous.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLFO
dialogues.text: Something’s wrong with the hem. Peter, I want you to measure it again. TONY THE HAIRDRESSER and HIS ASSISTANT MARTY are blow- drying her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY THE HAIRDRESSER
dialogues.text: Perfect. Perfect. Like goddam Marie Antoinette, if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Please, Tony. Can you compare me to 109

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: somebody else?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: There was nothing wrong with Marie Antoinette, Mrs. Reagan. And she never said that thing, let ‘em eat cake, either. Her only problem was, she wasn’t French. He runs a finger dramatically across his throat.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Tony, stop. The SOCIAL SECRETARY and the PERSONAL SECRETARY arrive:

dialogues.speaker: PERSONAL
dialogues.text: Can we hurry this along, please? We have a photography session in 5 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan, I’ve made up your schedule for each of the ten inaugural balls...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Is somebody going to wake up Ronnie?

dialogues.speaker: PERSONAL SECRETARY
dialogues.text: They're doing it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan, still in his inauguration suit, lying on top of h bed. Dead to the world. Deaver and the VALET are standing over him in the dark, trying gently to wake him up.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Sir..Sir..Sir..Mr. President. Reagan opens his eyes, groggy.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Do I have to get up? The valet pulls him to his feet, starts adjusting his tie

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I dreamed I was back in Illinois..I was talking to my mother..she was saying something important..but I can’t remember what it was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110  The Reagan children have gathered for the Inaugural portrait: MAUREEN (40), tight, controlling; MICHAEL (35) playful and needy; his wife, COLLEEN, and their baby boy, CAMERON; PATTI (28) resentful; and RON (22) sweet and irreverent. As they banter, the WHITE HOUSE PHOTOGRAPHER AND HIS ASSISTANT are nearby, setting up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen is all over the room, collecting match-boxes. She shows them to everybody:

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: “The President’s House”. I’ve collected 18 of them, so far.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Maureen, that’s stealing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: It’s not stealing. It’s Dad’s house, now. Besides, we pay for them with our taxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael turns to Colleen, hurt:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’ve been here for 24 hours, and he hasn’t even spoken to me. Neither has she.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Michael, you’re a glutton for punishment,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Shut up, Patti. It’s only their inauguration. They’re a little bit busy.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Please, everybody. Don’t fight. Not today.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: You call this a fight? This is nothing. Wait till you see the seating chart.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You’re stoned, aren’t you? My God, you came to Dad’s inauguration stoned.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I’m not stoned. How dare you say that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I need a drink. 111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dig it. Let’s all get drunk.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (singing, low) “Y’say you want a rev-o-lu-tion..” Nancy arrives, followed by ADOLFO (the designer), ADOLFO’ 2 ASSISTANTS, and TONY, THE HAIRDRESSER.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (tense, smiling) Maureen, aren’t you wearing any make-up? Michael, that tie is horrendous. The only one who looks .nice is Ron. Tony. She nods to Patti’s hair, and he descends on her with a blow-dryer.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti, I’m telling you-there will be no more blue jeans permitted in this White House. Women will not wear pants of any kind. We do not wear clogs. We represent our country.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Stop. I like my hair the way it is—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan and Michael Deaver hurry down the hall, along with Reagan’s secretary, HELENE VAN DAMME (30’s, pretty):

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: As soon as the hostages land, we have to bring them over to the White House. And we'll give them a party. A big celebration. With medals.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Medals, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, forget the medals. But they’re American heroes. We need heroes.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Especially after the last 4 years. Poor Jimmy Carter. No President deserves to be humiliated like that. It’s a lesson to us all, Mike. A lesson to us all. As DEAVER FOLLOWS REAGAN INTO THE PARLOR - Michael comes over, grinning, hugs Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Dad..Dad, I’m so proud of you—

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Mr. President, Mrs. Reagan, could you sit down please..Could I have all the children behind you and Mrs. Reagan? What’s the grandchild’s name? Who's going. to hold him?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Cameron, come here. The others take their places. As Nancy and Reagan make their way to theirs seat, she murmurs to him, happily:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ten inaugural balls, Ronnie. Ten. How can we possibly go to them all? MUSIC: “HAIL TO THE CHIEF”

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: Everyone is smiling, civilized. An image of the perfect American family.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: MUSIC: “HAIL TO THE CHIEF” as Reagan and Nancy slowly descend the stairs to the first Inaugural ball..to the white-gloved applause of the crowd..Edith and Loyal Davis..POLITICOS AND SOCIALITES, each one more magnificen dressed than the last..The entire effect is utterly regal Versailles. 113

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Good evening. I’m speaking to you tonight to give you a report on the state of the nation’s economy. I regret to say that we're in the worst economic mess since the Great Depression... DISSOLVE TO: ANOTHER INAUGURAL BALL..This one in a downto ballroom, but just as regal, just as opulent..WAITERS cruising with trays of caviar and champagne..WOMEN DRIPPI WITH JEWELS...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But make no mistake about it—we’re going to go to work and turn this around. DISSOLVE TO: YET ANOTHER INAUGURAL BALL..As Reagan and Na waltz (STRAUSS) to the soft applause of the CROWD..They dance so beautifully together..Then, they’re joined by DOZENS OF OTHER DANCING COUPLES...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: .We are special among the nations of the earth. Our government has no power except that granted by we, the people. It must work with us, not over us; stand by our side, not ride on our back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flanked by American flags, Reagan's at his desk, looking directly at the camera..at us.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We can lecture our children about extravagance, or we can simply cut their allowance. We’ve let spending get out of control. It’s time for Judgement Day. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT Nancy and Reagan lying on top of their bed, in their Inaugural ball clothes..holding hands..fast asleep. Exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wintry day. Snow on the White House lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Deaver coming down the hall, talking to JIM BAKER (50’s), Chief of Staff, and Ed Meese (50's), Special Counsel. The three of them are known as “the Troika”.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (to Baker) One more thing, Jim. He’s hard of hearing. - If you want him to hear you, stand right in front of him, and raise your voice.

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: And if you want him to get something in particular, dress it up, give it a little sex appeal. Metaphors, analogies. Compare it to a movie he’s seen. He’s an actor. Never forget he’s an actor.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: He’s an actor, but he’s deceptively smart. They stop at Helene Van Damme’s desk. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HELENE VON DAMM
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Deaver. Mr. Baker. Mr. Meese. (in. a whisper) They’ve already started. It was General Haig. He insisted. Deaver, Baker, and Meese look at each other. Sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver, Baker, and Meese enter, and stand by the door, waiting for their eyes to adjust to the darkness. AL HAIG, '(50s), Secretary of State, is standing with a pointer beside a grainy, black-and-white documentary, pointing to the figures of 2 men, as they move in and out of the frame.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: (in a loud voice) «This is Brezhnev. And this is Libyan leader Moammar Qadaffi.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (to Meese, muttering) Jesus, what is this? “Sesame Street”? 115 Nee?” ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soviets are funding the Libyan regime. Selling them jets, missiles, tanks, etc. At the same time, Brezhnev has recently approached us about resuming talks on a nuclear freeze. Reagan is doodling on a note-pad, as he watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freeze, huh? Haig peers into the dark, sees Deaver, Baker, Meese:

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
