dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Ah. I see the “troika” has finally arrived. Are you going to just stand there, or are you going to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: } Deaver, Baker, and Meese feel their way to the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s like Armageddon, isn’t it, Al? The Bible says Russia will be. defeated by a leader from the West, who will be revealed as the Antichrist. He, too, will fall, and then Jesus Christ will triumph in the creation of a new heaven and a new earth.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: (joking) Well, sir—if. it’s Armageddon you want, give me the word, and I’1l pave over the | USSR, Libya, and Cuba, too.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Can you pave them over, put parking stripes on them, and be back in time for the Fourth of July? Haig and Reagan laugh. Deaver, Baker, and Meese look at each other nervously. Haig sees their nervousness, and tries to stop laughing.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But far as the public is concerned, we’ve got to tone down the rhetoric. With all due respect. 116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t give a damn about rhetoric. I want those Reds to know, this place is under new management. The film comes to an end. As the PROJECTIONIST turns off the equipment, and hits the lights, Haig pulls a letter o of his briefcase:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. In light of that, I've written an exploratory letter to Brezhnev. You just need to sign it. He hands it to Reagan. Reagan hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: That’s great, Al. But I write my own letters. Haig is thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me sir, but I’m the Secretary of | State, so it’s my job to-

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You’re a great Secretary of State, Al. But I’m going to write to Brezhnev personally. I think we need a summit, to talk about all this. But I don’t want to freeze nuclear weapons, I want to eliminate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig lurches.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: What the hell--? We can’t eliminate nuclear weapons!

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We can, if we build a new weapon that scares the hell out of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) And what exactly would that be? Reagan holds up the drawing he’s doodled: a missile marke “USA" zooming out of space to hit another missile marked with the hammer and sickle of the USSR. 117 Ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call it “mutual assured survival”. It’s going to change the course of human history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig exits the Oval Office, hurries off, looking stricken | followed by Deaver, Baker, and Meese who look almost as | stricken.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Great. A summit to talk about weapons in outer space.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Has he talked to you guys about this missile-thing before?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: I'd better go get Haig, and catch him | before he takes a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy’s at the China Closet with a dignified WHITE HOUSE BUTLER (70). She’s examining a plate, chipped and stained

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: These are the plates Bess Truman bought..and Lady Bird..and Rosalyn Carter. There’s been a bit of breakage over the years, as you might expect.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But they're all different.,Didn’t anybody think of trying to match them? How am I going to serve a State dinner? We might as well use paper plates. Mike, thank God you're here. She’s just noticed Mike Deaver sticking his head in.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Can I speak to you a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy and Deaver stand looking at all the rich furnishin as they arrive: ornate tables, sofas, artwork, etc.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can’t redecorate the entire White House - for 50 thousand. Forget it. I’m going to need a million, at least.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: But do you see how it looks? The President is talking about cut-backs—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (overriding) | I know how it looks, but it won’t cost the tax-payers a penny. It will all come from Betsy and her friends.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (grimly) And they’1l all take a nice big fat tax write-off, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing’s wrong with it. (pause) Times hard hard, Nancy. We've cut back a lot of sacred cows..after school programs, school lunches, welfare. And it doesn’t help when one of our own people tries to re-classify catsup as a vegetable in school cafeterias. Nancy gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This is the White House, Mike. In the next 4 years, at least 80,000 dignitaries, politicians, and ambassadors are going to come here. (pause) Anyway, who cares what the press says? They're going to criticize me, no matter what I do. I no longer give a damn. An AIDE interrupts: 119

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan. I have a phone call from your son.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mike. She starts to leave, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: And you know what else? Marie Antoinette never said, let them eat cake. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - EAST WING/WHITE HOUSE ~- NIGHT Nancy lying in bed, as Reagan undresses. She sneezes. Sneezes again.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe he got married without us. Why would he do that to us? God, it’s dusty in here.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, he probably didn’t want it to turn it a circus. That’s what it would have been, if we’d gone.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But Ronnie, he’s your only son. Don’t you care?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Sure, I do, but we’re going to go see him in New York next week. We'll get to spend time with him, then. Nancy’s still miffed.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Think of it. Our son marrying the daughter of an Italian house-painter. He steps over the torn rug, and climbs into bed.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know whether we’re any better. A couple of ham actors..worse, movie-actors..living in the White House. He tickles her. She laughs, pushes him away. He tickles h again. 120  INT. HALLWAY -— CONTINUING The White House Guard is sitting, watching tv. He hears t REAGANS’ LAUGHTER. Smiles. Settles back into his show. MOVIE - BLACK AND WHITE (“MURDER IN THE AIR”) Vintage 1940: a large shiny ray-gun; an Admiral speaking someone OS:

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL
dialogues.text: The Inertia Projector is the most potent weapon ever invented. It can paralyze electrical current, thus destroying all enemy planes in the air. INT. BILL SHELBY’S APT. - DAY Shelby is watching the movie on a VCR, as he dials the phone:

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL
dialogues.text: It not only makes the United States invincible in war, but in doing so, promises to become the greatest force for world peace ever discovered. The film cuts to Young Reagan, listening intently. Shelby picks up the video cover: Murder in the Air, starring Ronald Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: Hey, Deaver—I got something for comment. Think I know where Ronnie got the idea for Star Wars. Ever seen Murder in the Air? INT. DEAVER’S OFFICE (INTERCUT SHELBY) Deaver feels sick.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Yeah, great flick. Is this the old, “He can’t movies from reality” thing? No comment .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A performance of the Joffrey Ballet. Ron in a graceful pa de-deux, as... 121

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan and Nancy watch the dancing, riveted. Ron’s wife, Doria, beside them. In the b.g., one Secret Service agent turns to another, and makes a limp-wrist gesture.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STAGE
dialogues.text: Ron does a perfect leap, lifting his partner, whirling he

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BALCONY BOX
dialogues.text: Doria checks the Reagans’ for a reaction-he’s shaking his head, in wonder. Nancy is shining with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secret Service move Nancy and Reagan THRU A CRUSH OF DANCERS, MEDIA, WELL-WISHERS: toward the men’s dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s backstage at the Moulin Rouge. Mirrors, shadowy lights..MALE DANCERS in various states of undress, showering, getting dressed for a night of parties, as the Secret Service explodes into the room to check it over.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER 1
dialogues.text: Hey! What’s this? Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: DANCER 2
dialogues.text: Don't touch my stuff! ANGLE - Ron, still in tights and full stage make-up, peeling his shirt off, suddenly realizes:

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh Christ. Sorry, everybody—it’s my parents. Suddenly the door opens, and the Reagans are whooshed int the room. The dancers freeze, in genuine awe. Reagan trie to cover his discomfort:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It's okay, boys. It’s only us, and God knows, we’ve seen plenty of dressing rooms. Don’t be embarrassed. But the dancers are embarrassed, especially as the room fills with PHOTOGRAPHERS AND REPORTERS, catching Nancy as 122  she runs over to Ron, and plants a big kiss right on his lips:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, Ron! You were so wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mom. Reagan stares uncomfortably at Ron’s make-up (reds, green yellows, a la Nureyev) and sticks out his hand, man-to-ma

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. You were always a natural athlete. Football, basketball. (loudly) You're all. boy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (gushing) Ron, we had no idea--did we, Ronnie--we had no idea how great you were!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No, I’m not great. I started too late. But I love it. Mom. I do.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Fred Astaire, Gene Kelly. There was nothing wrong with them, either. Strong. Stronger than most fullbacks. Did I ever tell you about the time I had dinner with Gene?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Doria! Come in! Ron's talking to Doria, who has appeared in the doorway. She smiles, shyly.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER HEADLINES -
dialogues.text: Newspaper photo of Reagan, Nancy, Dora, and Ron all smili broadly, arms around each other. The headline blares: “He Not Gay, Says Proud Papa”. The newspaper spins, and becomes another front page: Headline: “Reagan Passes Largest Tax Cut in History!” The newspaper spins, and becomes another front page..A ph of Reagan’s drawing of the missile. The headline screams, “Countdown to Star Wars!” 123

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Presidential motorcade—3 limos-moving through traffic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan rides alone, looking over a speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver rides with JAMES BRADY (40’s) Press Secretary, REAGAN’S DOCTOR, and an ARMY COLONEL holding “the Football”: a briefcase which contains orders in case of nuclear attack.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: We're tight today, Jim, he’s got 2 appointments this afternoon, so let’s keep him moving. Don’t let him stop for any questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police and Secret Service have cordoned off a CROWD OF MEDIA AND ONLOOKERS as the motorcade pulls up and unloads As Reagan gets out, onlookers applaud—except for a group boisterous TEAMSTERS DEMONSTRATING, chanting:

dialogues.speaker: TEAMSTERS
dialogues.text: We want job! We want jobs! We want jobs! Cameras click and whirr, reporters shout questions, as Reagan cups his ear and keeps moving, smiling at one and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign by the door says “ANNUAL LUNCHEON: AFL-CIO”..and a CONTINGENT OF UNION LEADERS are standing nearby to greet Reagan as he arrives.

dialogues.speaker: AFL-CIO LEADER
dialogues.text: Welcome, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Always glad to see union men. I was president of the Screen Actors Guild for 6 terms, you know. We fought off the Communist take-over of Hollywood. 124

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still fighting, sir. Reagan whispers irritably, to Deaver as they head in:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t somebody tell me this was lunch? I’ve already eaten.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I thought I did. Sorry, sir—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (an angry sigh) Well, it won’t be the first time I’ve pushed chicken around on a plate, but somebody needs to tell me these things! Deaver falls back to Brady:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I told him.

dialogues.speaker: BRADY
dialogues.text: He's forgetting a lot of things nowadays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A limo pulled up beside the door; a detail of Secret Service, waiting. One of them, AGENT GEORGE OPFER (30's) on a walkie-talkie, using Nancy’s code-name:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE OPFER
dialogues.text: (to the others) Zephyr’s coming out. The others spring into action, blocking pedestrian traffi opening the limo door. Nancy hurries out of the restauran nervous, on edge.

dialogues.speaker: OPFER
dialogues.text: That was a short lunch, Mrs. Reagan

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Something’s wrong. Take me-back to the White House.

dialogues.speaker: OPFER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? 125

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. But something’s wrong. Quick. She gets into the limo, and it speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The demonstrators have gone. The media is still here though, as Secret Service Agent TIM McCARTHY (30) gets on his walkie-talkie, using Reagan’s code-name:

dialogues.speaker: MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Rawhide’s on his way. The agents go into alert mode: the 3 limos start their engines. TV cameras start rolling. Reporters get ready. Agent JERRY PARR (50) emerges from the hotel with Reagan, followed by Deaver, Brady, more Secret Service.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: Mr. President! Mr. President! Reagan continues to his limo, smiling, cupping his hand t his ear, as if not hearing them.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (to Brady) Tell them there’s no statement. Go! He shoves Brady toward the reporters as... A SERIES OF POPPING SOUNDS—6 of them. Brady crumples, and falls. Deaver dives to the pavement, as... Reagan looks toward the sound, hand raised in a wave, his smile frozen... Agent McCarthy jumps in front of him. McCarthy goes down, shot in the stomach. Agent Jerry Parr grabs Reagan, shoving him into the limo, diving on top of him.As Reagan hits the floor:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Ow. A voice is shouting in his ear: 126

dialogues.speaker: PARR
dialogues.text: (to the driver) Haul ass! Let’s get out of here! He feels the car lurch forward..hears the TIRES SQUEAL... POLICE SIRENS SCREAMING...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver jumping into the Control Car, looking back to see. McCarthy and a WASHINGTON COP writhing on the sidewalk. J Brady lies motionless, bleeding from a severe head wound. Nearby, a KNOT OF POLICE AND SECRET SERVICE wrestle someo to the ground—a blond young man with a cherubic face (JOH

dialogues.speaker: HINCKLEY, JR.
dialogues.text: INT. REAGAN’S LIMO/MOVING FAST - CONTINUING Agent Parr is lying on top of Reagan on the rear floor. Reagan is coughing and choking with pain.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Get off, you sonofabitch..I think you broke my ribs...

dialogues.speaker: PARR
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. President. Let me check to se if you were hit. Parr climbs off, helps him onto the seat, begins to exami him, feeling him all over. Suddenly he sees thin, watery blood dribbling from Reagan mouth. He stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: PARR
dialogues.text: (to the driver) Go to Washington Hospital. Seventeenth Street.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (rattled) Where? We’re going to the White House—

dialogues.speaker: PARR
dialogues.text: Washington University Hospital, dammit! Go! Go! Go! ‘The driver makes a screeching turn. 127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy’s paging anxiously through her calendar. She comes March. Certain days have been crossed out in red—today, March 30°, has been crossed out, too.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh God. No. No. She looks up, as a Secret Service agent appears in the door.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE AGENT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Something's happened to Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE AGENT
dialogues.text: There's been a shooting. Other people were wounded, but the President wasn’t hit—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Where is he.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE AGENT
dialogues.text: He’s fine, he’s been taken to the hospital for observation— Closing her calendar, grabbing her purse:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Which hospital! Take me there. Now.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE AGENT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, ma’am. My orders are to keep you here. There could be more than one shooter, out there—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Take me to my husband! Now! If you won’t take me, I'll walk, do you hear? I’11 walk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMERGENCY PERSONNEL are waiting as President’s limo arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan is pale, and having severe difficulty breathing. 128

dialogues.speaker: PARR
dialogues.text: We're here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Don’t help me. I’m going to get out by myself, okay? Reagan wipes the blood from his mouth, and as the door is opened by EMERGENCY PERSONNEL, climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver is getting out of the control car, and sees..Reaga walking into the ER, smiling and waving, as if nothing ha happened. Deaver hurries after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instantly, as Reagan’s through the door, his knees buckle and his eyes roll up. The doctors lunge to catch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHAOS: D.C. police, Secret Service, Media roaring up in mobile vans and cars. Deaver’s waiting on the sidewalk. a Nancy’s limo pulls up, unescorted. She jumps out to a barrage of shouted questions:

dialogues.speaker: MEDIA
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan! Mrs. Reagan! Is the President alright? Is he wounded? She almost runs to Deaver, who quickly takes her into... INT. EMERGENCY ROOM — Even greater chaos, here: a frightening cacophony of loud voices, shouts; scurrying doctors; dazed patients; panick policemen. Deaver raises his voice over the noise:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Nancy, he took a bullet--but he’s okay, he’s going to be fine—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They told me he wasn’t hurt--

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: They didn’t know. But he’s okay, he’s going to be fine—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’ve got to see him, Mike—they don’t know how it is, with us. He’s got to know I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver escorts Nancy through the chaos. They see a strick woman being helped through the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Sarah Brady’s here.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh my God..Is Jim alright? 130

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver shakes his head. The trauma room doors open—Nancy goes through them alone. He stays outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy enters a scene of horror: bloody bandages, tubes scattered on the floor, empty blood bags, the remains of Reagan's suit tossed in a corner, and... «on a bed, Reagan's naked body, hooked to machines--4 Ivs pumping blood into him--surrounded by DOCTORS AND NURSES. For several moments, they talk, unaware that she’s standi there. One of the doctors is DR. AARON (48):

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR AARON
dialogues.text: How much blood has he taken?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE 2
dialogues.text: Almost 2 and a half quarts. He’s losing 300 cc’s every 15 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE 3
dialogues.text: Blood pressure still falling—52 over 40. Nurse 3 looks up, sees Nancy. They all fall silent, and make room for her to approach. Nancy looks down at Reagan’s pale face, his dazed, frightened eyes, his lips caked with dried blood under a clear plastic oxygen mask. She reaches for his hand. He tries te speak. She leans closer to hear:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (muffled, under the mask) Honey..I forgot to duck. Fighting tears, she leans down and kisses him. Dr. Aaron gently leads her away.

dialogues.speaker: DR. AARON
dialogues.text: The bullet is very close to his heart. We need your permission to operate immediately. She can only stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan is being wheeled to the OR. Nancy beside him, clutching his hand. A phalanx of doctors, nurses, and 131 Secret Service pulling on surgical gowns moves with them As they move down the hall, Nancy sees... another man on a blood-soaked gurney. His head seems to have exploded. It's Jim Brady. Nancy fighting for control, continues with Reagan until t i doors of the OR open. She bends down and kisses Reagan | the forehead, looks into his dazed eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I love you more than anything in the whole wide world. He’s wheeled inside. The Secret Service follows them in. Nancy stares at the doors, as they close after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secret Service, CIA and FBI are jockeying for positions, as the doctors prepare to operate.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET SERVICE
dialogues.text: Fat lot of good you guys did.

dialogues.speaker: CIA AGENT
dialogues.text: Hey, come on. I’m CIA, move over.

dialogues.speaker: DR. AARON
dialogues.text: Come on, you guys. Back off, we've got to work here. Aaron leans in to Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: DR. AARON
dialogues.text: We're going to put you to sleep now. Reagan looks up at the green figures leaning over him.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (faintly) Please tell me you’re Republicans. The doctors chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: DR. AARON
dialogues.text: Today we’re all Republicans, Mr. President. 132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footage of the shooting: Reagan smiling and waving; then being pushed into the limo; bodies on the sidewalk; the melee as Hinckley is mobbed.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY STARES AT THE TV
dialogues.text: hypnotized, unable to look away. Deaver is beside her, watching Brady on the pavement. He changes the channel.

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: A White House press conference, live: Deputy Press Secretary LARRY SPEAKES taking questions from REPORTERS:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1, (OS)
dialogues.text: Have the Armed Forces been put on alert?

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKES
dialogues.text: Not that I’m aware of.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2, (OS)
dialogues.text: What about Vice President Bush? Has he assumed the Presidency?

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKES
dialogues.text: The Vice President is flying to Washington as we speak. There is no plan at this time— Suddenly a man shoves in beside him—Al Haig, flushed, panicky.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I have to clarify that. No military alert has been ordered. I repeat—we are not on alert.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: But who’s running the Government?

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Constitutionally, gentlemen, you have the Presidency, the Vice President, and the Secretary of State, in that order—

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: For God’s sake! He’s got it wrong, wrong! It’s the Speaker of the House! 133

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: As of now, I am in control here—pending the return of the Vice President—

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Haig’s gone nuts! I’ve got to find a phone! He hurries out the door. Nancy keeps staring at Haig’s crazed face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan swimming underwater, wearing his lifeguard uniform Swimming frantically, looking this way and that. Searchin Searching. Suddenly, something grabs his leg. A HAND. He explodes with fright, SCREAMING. Starts clawing his wa toward the surface. But the surface is too far up. He can get there. His lungs are about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEAD -
dialogues.text: Reagan jerking away in his Recovery Room bed, gasping, trying to rise up, pulling at the respirator tube in his throat. Nancy’s beside him, panics:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, he can’t breathe! Nurse, he can’t breathe! Help him! TWO RECOVERY NURSES are here, too.

dialogues.speaker: RECOVERY NURSE
dialogues.text: It’s okay, the machine is breathing for him. (to Reagan) Let it breathe for you. You’re okay, Mr. President. Trust me. He looks around, realizing he’s in the Recovery Room, surrounded by machines. An EKG monitor, a respirator, lin and tubes connected to his body. Beyond the equipment, Agent Parr, as well as the CIA and FBI agents. He tries t settle down. Nancy stays close to him, stroking his hand, anxiously:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They took out the bullet..the doctor said you’re strong..strong as a man half your age, that’s what he said.but I wasn’t 134  surprised, we knew it all along, didn’t we, my darling... Agent Parr approaches:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT PARR
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan. We need to think about getting you back to the White House.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No. I’m going to stay here. I can sleep in one of these beds. Dr. Aaron steps in.

dialogues.speaker: DR. AARON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan, if you stay all night, it will look like he’s worse than he is. You need to go home.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No. I’m staying with my husband.

dialogues.speaker: DR. AARON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but I’m not going to allow that. You will leave this hospital now. Nancy looks at him, ready to explode.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT PARR
dialogues.text: He’s right. You can come back in the morning. Please, Mrs. Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: A yearbook photo of John Hinckley, Jr. So innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti, Maureen, Michael, Ron and Doria having breakfast, they watch tv. In the b.g., Michael’s wife, Colleen, is feeding their 2 small children. Ron is surfing via the remote:

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Stop changing the channels, Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (imitation of Al Haig:) a As of now, I am in control here. 135

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Give me that thing. Patti wrestles the remote away from him. Michael turns to Maureen, muttering:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Jody Foster? He shot Dad in order to impress Jody Foster?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Wait till Dad hears he was shot by a deranged movie fan. He’ll love it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: That’s not funny, Ron.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I think it’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | Maybe now he’1l change his mind about gun control.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Gun control? You think gun control would | have stopped this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh great. Blame the victim.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Back off, you guys. Doria’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: : You guys ought to read the newspaper once in a while. Maybe then you’d wake up, and ditch this hippie crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As her family continues to argue, Patti buries her head i her hands.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: What kind of family is this? Even a bullet can't bring us together. INT. NANCY’S DRESSING ROOM - SAME TIME Tony the hairdresser is doing Nancy’s hair. She’s on the phone: 136

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) It's my fault he was shot, Carol. You told me it was going to be a bad day, and I wrote it down in my calendar, but I forgot to tell Mike Deaver, and so they scheduled him to go out..it’s all because of me. Nancy listens, reaching for her purse, pulling out her calendar, as she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh thank you, thank you, Carol..If I didn’t have you, I don’t know what..Yes, tell me. I’ll write them down. She searches for a pen—has to empty the entire contents o her purse on the counter: comb, tiny make-up pouch, etc., and finally, that essential part of any woman’s wardrobe. A SMALL SILVER PISTOL. TONY STARES AT THE PISTOL, as Nancy starts crossing out days on her calendar, in red ink:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) The 3rd..the 5 and 6th..11"..18"..22"...28".. thank you, Carol. Thank you so much. Yes, I’11 call you tomorrow. Same time. Nancy hangs up, and sees Tony staring at the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie made me take it. Honestly, I don’t even know how to shoot it— She picks the pistol up, points it at Tony. He backs off.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey. Watch it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s alright, the little thing, thé thing that keeps you from shooting it is on. I think. Is that on, or off?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Put it down. Put it down. 137

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Okay, I’11 put it down. Here, I’11 put it back in my bag. Does that make you feel better? You’re so sweet, Tony. I wish all my children were as sweet as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan still hooked to machines, unable to speak. He’s shadow of his former self. He scrawls slowly on a note-pa as Nancy, Patti, Ron, Maureen, and Michael sit nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You look good, Dad. Don’t you think he looks good, Michael? I mean, considering?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (trying) Yeah. You look really good, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: How are the nurses? Are they pretty? Reagan hands Nancy his note-pad. She reads:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: “All in all, I'd rather be in Philadelphia.” They all laugh, feebly. Reagan tries to laugh, fumbles with his respirator.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: He’s scared, Mom...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s fine, Ronnie. The respirator’s working just fine.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It’s like when you taught me how to scuba- dive, Dad. When you put that mask on me, I thought I was going to suffocate. You've just got to let the machine do its job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ever-present Secret Service guards the door, includin Opfer and Parr. Nearby, gitting in chairs, Troika—Deaver, Baker, and Meese are waiting, briefcases in their laps. 138

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, if he lives through this, we've got to keep Al Haig away from him for the rest of his term. He’s out of his mind, talking about paving over Moscow and Libya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He only talks like that, for effect.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, it had an effect on me. It scared the crap out of me. Because he brings out the dark side in the old man. He does. They’re interrupted by Patti and Ron coming out, whisperi to each other. As soon as Patti and Ron see them, they fa silent. Deaver, Baker, and Meese stand up, and smile.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Hi, kids. We’ve got some paperwork for your dad to sign.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Now? In Intensive Care?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: The country needs to know that he’s still in charge.

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: Besides, it’s good for him. He needs to know that he’s still in charge, too, don’t you think? FOLLOW PATTI AND RON down the hall, looking back over the shoulders, as the Troika go into Reagan’s room:

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Those guys scare me. INT. REAGAN’S HOSPITAL ROOM - DAY Nancy is putting some last minute. rouge on Reagan’s chee as the PHOTOGRAPHER gets set up, and Deaver, Baker, and Meese position the papers for Reagan to sign. 139

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, I’m just going to give you a little color...

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (to the photographer) See? The President’s fine. Fine. Nancy puts the pen in Reagan’s hand, and holds it, slowly writing his name. Reagan smiles for the camera. FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOB OF MEDIA outside. The Presidential limos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual phalanx of Secret Service clears a path through Hospital Personnel, who break into cheers, as... Reagan appears, walking with difficulty, leaning on Nancy and Agent Parr’s arms. Reagan’s wearing a bright red cardigan. They’re all smiling. As he approaches the exit door, Dr. Aaron and the medical team are waiting to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: DR. AARON
dialogues.text: Take it easy, now. Try not to overwork. You sure you don’t want a wheelchair?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He refuses. He absolutely refuses.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Every KGB agent in the Kremlin is going to be watching, to see if America has an invalid for a President. Well, they’re in for a disappointment. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Reagan emerges, smiling cheerfully, like a man in perfect health, the reporters start shouting questions:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: How are you, Mr. President? How are you feeling? (etc.) 140

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to go back to work, and give you fellows something to write about! As he and Nancy head for their limousine, the Media start to applaud. Among them is Bill Shelby, looking critically at his colleagues, as they continue to cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO US AIRFORCE JETS shooting down two Libyan Jets. They burst into flames, and crash into a calm blue sea (the Gu of Sidra). FADE UP: THE TICKING OF A CLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT The clock on the bedside table is ticking: 4:24 a.m. Reag and Nancy are fast asleep, when the phone rings sharply, and loudly. Reagan sleeps through it. Nancy opens her eye reaches over his sleeping body to pick it up:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. INTERCUT BETWEEN REAGANS’ BEROOM AND ED MEESE, IN HIS WHI HOUSE OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: Nancy, it’s Ed. I'm sorry to wake you up. We have a little bit of a crisis. i j i Nancy covers the mouthpiece with her hand, nudges Reaga

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie. It's Ed Meese. Something’s happened. Ronnie, wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ! She puts the phone in his hand. He opens his eyes, blee

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir, I would have woken you up earlier, but I knew you were tired, and well..Wwe, um, we were just attacked by two Libyan jets. We fired back, though—shot them down. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Is that it? 142

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: It happened about 5 hours ago. As I say, I would have woken you up, but..Everything’s been handled.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Well..thanks for handling it. He hangs up, and goes back to sleep. Nancy’s wide-awake.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Nothing. Ed’s taken care of it. He goes back to sleep. Nancy stares at him, alarmed. Afte a moment, he begins to snore. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: JOHNNY CARSON ON “THE LATE SHOW”.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY CARSON
dialogues.text: There are only two reasons you wake up Ronald Reagan. One is World War III. The other is if “Hellcats of the Navy” is on the late show. AUDIENCE LAUGHTER. INT. DEAVER’S OFFICE - DAY Nancy slams the Washington Post down on Deaver’s desk, furious.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: And it’s not just Johnny Carson. Look at what Art Buchwald wrote. And Jack Anderson. Everyone in the entire country is laughing at Ronald Reagan! Deaver winces. From the corner, Jim Baker admits:

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: It doesn’t make Ed Meese look too good, either.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s not just Ed Meese, it’s you. One of you should have woken him up when it happened. Not 5 hours later. 143

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (to Deaver) Maybe we should take Ed off foreign policy. It’s not his strength.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, take him off foreign policy. And from now on, whenever anybody asks if the President has been informed of something, no matter what it is, tell them, “The President is aware of it.” “The President is aware of everything.” Got it? Deaver and Baker look at each other, and nod. Nancy starts out. Pause. Turns back to the men.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s not easy for him. He has so much to do..to think about. It would be too much for any man... She's about to say something more, but decides not to. Sh turns, and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan on a chaise, legal tablet on his lap, pencil in hand, staring out the window at the rain. Nancy looks in.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I thought you were taking a nap. He comes to. Speaking slowly, thoughtfully:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I was thinking about that boy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What boy?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: The boy who shot me. He was a nice boy. Just a little mixed-up.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, he tried to kill you. 144

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried to kill me, but God let me live. God spared me, for a reason. And I think I know the reason. } Nancy comes in, and sits down beside him. Lays her head gently on his shoulder. He continues:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: God spared me, because he wants me to lead our country out of the cold war with Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Ronnie..You don’t need to get shot, in order to end the cold war.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I know..but I’ve been praying about it..And God told me—-he wants me to end the cold war. Pause. A shadow of worry crosses Nancy’s face.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY 5
dialogues.text: | And that’s why he saved your life? }

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (nods) And that’s why I’ve got to forgive that | boy. Because he was part of God’s plan. Nancy nods.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Okay. But even if you forgive him..I won’t. I’‘ll never forgive him. Ever. He takes her hand, kisses it tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: ‘And that’s your burden, isn’t it, Mommy? You can’t forgive people for being..people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not when it comes to you. | REAGAN . : I thank God I have you. You see people so ) much more clearly than I do. If I didn’t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145  have you, I could end up in a lot of trouble, you know that? She laughs. He pulls her close, and kisses her cheeks, he nose, her lips, as:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: When I woke up in the hospital, and saw your face..I said to God, Please God don’t ever make me face a day without her.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I love you, Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I love you, too, Mommy. More than anything in the whole wide world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s silent, crude. Latin American guerrillas in a jungle unloading crates of ammo and weapons.

dialogues.speaker: CRATE BEING OPENED, GUNS BEING REMOVED
dialogues.text: Reagan in a darkened room, watching the movie, as WILLIAM CASEY, (60's) head of the CIA, mumbles next to him:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM CASEY
dialogues.text: This is Nicaragua. These are the Contras, they’re fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan dictator. The dictator is supported by the Reds. All we’ve sent the Contras so far is a bunch of guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan nods, grimly.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Except for last week, when somebody in California sent the Contras a helicopter. One lousy helicopter. (pause) It’s the same in Afghanistan. And Cuba. The dictators are supported by Moscow. Moscow sends them everything they need. Deaver, Baker, and Meese are sitting nearby. — - 146

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I can’t understand a word Bill Casey is saying.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: All those CIA guys mumble. I think they learned it from Bill. Al Haig interrupts from a few seats away, irritably:

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Why is everybody whispering? REAGAN. Bill Casey’s saying they need more helicopters in Nicaragua.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Christ, it’ll be Vietnam all over again.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with that? Maybe this time we'll win. The movie ends. The projectionist turns off the film, and raises the shades. Outside, it’s raining.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Bill. You get those Contras whatever they need.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, sir. He can’t do that. He can’t just—he needs an executive order—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I just gave him an executive order.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: But I haven’t even made up a foreign policy statement—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You make up a statement, then. Write it up, so we can give the Contras anything they need. Haig is about to have an apoplectic fit. Reagan doesn’t notice, turns to Bill Casey, who is packin his briefcase, and heading out. 147 ‘aaa?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Oh, and Bill—tell the State Department, good work on the movie. Though it was a little long.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Yes, sir. I will, sir. Casey goes. The troika is about to follow him, when Reaga takes a letter from his desk, and hands it to Al Haig.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Al, one more thing. I want you to take a look at this letter I wrote, over the weekend. I’m going to send it to Brezhnev. Haig emits a thinly-veiled snort of disdain.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: So you did write a letter? Haig starts reading it. Reagan explains to the troika:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I told him we should get the ball rolling on arms talks, but I’m still going ahead with the missile defense system. Haig throws the paper down on Reagan's desk.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: No, sir. No. No, we're not having any summits—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’m not saying right away, Al. I’m laying the groundwork—

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Sir. I’m the Secretary of State, this is my job! And~and-this will never work.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Why not? Haig is about to explode. 148

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because-—because for one, your letter sounds like it was written by a rank amateur. Deaver, Baker, and Meese glance at each other. Haig sees it:

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: There you go again, you 3, looking at each other. You’re always looking at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Al, come on-

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: You’ve been undermining me, ever since I started this job! You won’t even let me be alone with the President!

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: That’s not true— Haig turns on Reagan, in a fury.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Frankly, Mr. President, I can’t put up with this any longer. Either I’m the Secretary of State or you are. And well, if this pattern continues..I will be forced to submit my resignation. Silence. The troika cock their heads at Reagan: here’s yo chance. Reagan freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy comes down the hall, carrying her calendar. She sto at Helene’s desk, outside Reagan’s office:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Helene, what do you know about the Gridiron Club?

dialogues.speaker: HELENE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s the Washington press club. Every year they have a roast for the President and the First Lady. It’s a little rough, but they don’t mean anything by it. 149 ‘ute?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, that explains everything.

dialogues.speaker: HELENE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, some of the staff suggested I should do a little something of my own.

dialogues.speaker: HELENE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan looks intensely uncomfortable, reaches for his jar of jellybeans.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Gee, Al..I don’t want you to resign.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: I don’t want to resign either, but...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Have a jelly bean.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: The purple ones are good. And the black ones. As Haig puts the jelly beans in his mouth, he seems to relax, slightly.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Listen, sir. Why don’t we send your letter, along with another letter that I’ll draft for your signature.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: That sounds good. What do you boys think? This to Deaver, Baker, and Meese, who try not to look at each other, this time.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: What’s your letter going to say, Al? 150

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’1l have to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy looks up, as Al Haig comes out of the Oval Office eating jelly beans, and muttering angrily.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Hello, Al. He doesn’t hear Nancy. He storms off, mumbling to himself Nancy opens the door, and enters Reagan’s office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nancy enters, Reagan’s raging to Deaver, Baker, and Meese.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: “Rank amateur”! Who does that sonofabitch think he is? I’m the goddam President of the United States, I’m his boss!

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you say that to him?

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: He keeps putting his head on the block, sir. You've got to chop it off.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: George Shultz would make a great Secretary of State. Sir. Sir? Reagan is heading for another door.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: If it’s alright with you, this administration has to pee. He slams into the bathroom. Baker, Meese, and Deaver noti Nancy standing there.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Has he ever fired anybody face-to-face?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nope. 151 i!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy sitting in front of her mirror, in her nightgown, brushing her hair. Reagan is in bed, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie, Al Haig has got to go.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: | Al’s not such a bad guy. He gets a little | worked-up, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, Ronnie. No. You know what he did, while you were in the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I heard, he thought he was going to take control, but that’s not so bad—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That’s not so bad? Ronnie, he wants to control everything you do. And you're the President of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I know, but—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He doesn’t like your process. He doesn’t agree with your agenda. He wants total control over foreign policy. Ronnie, he’s not a peacemaker. He’s not. He groans, picks up the remote and switches on the tv. It Johnny Carson. Nancy sits on the bed, blocking his view o the tv.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: If you don’t get rid of him, it’s going to look like you’re afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of him—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: : But that’s how it looks. To your staff. To everybody in the Cabinet. You can’t afford 152

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to be afraid of anyone. They’ve got to know, you’re running the show.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Nancy—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Jim Baker thinks you should get George Shultz. He told me so. George Shultz is a peace-maker. Get rid of Al, Ronnie, or you’re never going to end the cold war. He suddenly explodes:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Alright, okay, I get the message. I hear you. Now get off my goddam back, okay? Pause. She gets up from the bed, and heads into the bathroom to brush her teeth. Reagan stares sullenly at Johnny Carson, as he delivers a big, easy golf swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot day. Outside the fence, THREE HOMELESS GUYS lying o a blanket. Their signs read: “Homeless Because of Ronald Reagan”; “Homeless Vet”; and “Will Work for Food”. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - CONTINUING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan getting dressed. Nancy hands him a letter. He glances at it, tucks it into his jacket. They exchange a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Haig steps out of the elevator and heads down the corridor toward the Oval Office..passing Deaver, Meese, a Baker..who stop talking, and stare after him until he disappears into Reagan’s office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan stands, as Al Haig enters.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Al. 153 ‘eit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly) Mr. President, I’m here to deliver 2 letters. The first one concerns the repeated interference that I have endured in my conduct of foreign affairs. The second is a memo concerning my differences with certain Cabinet members, who have made it their business to make my job as Secretary of State impossible. Reagan passes his hand over his brow-he’s sweating.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) I see. Well, Al..as it happens, I have a letter for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: (surprised) You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan hands him Nancy’s letter, and turns away, shufflin through his desk, as if looking for something. Haig reads the letter. It’s short.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: (stunned) What...?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I just want you to know, Al..This country will always be grateful to you for your services.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: But..but I haven't resigned, yet.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (nodding to the letter) Yes, you have.

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: If you want, you can go back to your office, and write your own letter. 154

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Can’t we talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Um.I have a couple phone calls to make... Haig is suddenly on the verge of tears, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: HAIG
dialogues.text: ~ But I don’t want to do it, I want to stay.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Sure, Al..but um.would you mind if I asked you to keep working until the Senate can confirm your successor? A SEQUENCE OF IMAGES -— Hospital after hospital being boarded up. Signs saying “Closed” . A LINE OF HOMELESS PEOPLE in front of a soup kitchen. A FAMILY living in their car. A FORMER MENTAL PATIENT sitting in the rain, on the sidewalk, laughing, smiling, talking to the air, catching the rain in her hands, and drinking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain falls against the windows, as MOVERS are crating in large wooden crates. Nancy’s unpacking one of them, helpe by the Butler and Betsy Bloomingdale. Tearing through the packing, she pulls out an elegant gol colored plate, bordered with Imperial Blue.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Oh my God..it’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They’d better be. The set cost more than $200,000.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: What shall I do with the old dishes, Mrs. Reagan?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Straight to Goodwill, darling. 155

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Don’t listen to her. See if we can donate them to the Smithsonian. Nancy continues pulling out cups, saucers, etc. A woman enters—ANNE ROGERS (34), attractive, ambitious.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mrs. Reagan. May I ask what we're doing? Betsy throws Nancy a curious glance.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Anne, this is Betsy Bloomingdale, an old friend of mine. Betsy, this is Anne Rogers—my new PR person. (wryly) Her job is to make people like me. Anne Rogers doesn’t think this is so funny, turns to Bets

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bloomingdale, am I to understand that you and your husband donated this new china?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Yes, you are, darling. It’s our gift to the nation. Anonymous.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You'll be wanting a tax write-off.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Well... Anne turns to Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I'll need to know the cost of each item—at your convenience, of course. I’1ll be back. She goes. Betsy turns to Nancy:

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Where’d you get Miss Bitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secret Service has cordoned off the GLITTERING GUESTS as the Presidential limousines arrive. Neil” Reagan and Nancy emerge—he’s in black tie, she’s stunning and smiling. They head for the club entrance..passing a SMALL GROUP OF HOMELESS ACTIVISTS who are waving signs:

dialogues.speaker: COORDINATOR
dialogues.text: What do we want?

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS ACTIVISTS
dialogues.text: Homes!

dialogues.speaker: COORDINATOR
dialogues.text: When do we want ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS ACTIVISTS
dialogues.text: Now! ONE OF THE DEMONSTRATORS tries to rush up to Nancy, but i stopped by a POLICEMAN.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS ACTIVISTS
dialogues.text: Let ‘em eat cake, Queen Nancy! Let ‘em eat cake! A LEGLESS MAN ON A CART scoots his way to the front of the crowd, trying to push past the Secret Service:

dialogues.speaker: LEGLESS MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Nancy! The cost of your dress would feed me for a month! Nancy tries to ignore them. Reagan smiles and waves at them, continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan and Nancy are sitting on the dais, flanked by Edit and Loyal Davis, VICE PRESIDENT BUSH AND BARBARA BUSH, AMBASSADORS..Deaver, Baker, Meese, GEORGE SHULTZ, THE NEW

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY OF STATE, AND DON REGAN, SECRETARY OF THE
dialogues.text: TREASURY (we’ll meet them later). The EMCEE stands behind a podium, addressing the audience of journalists, politicians, and glitterati.

dialogues.speaker: GRIDIRON EMCEE
dialogues.text: The Gridiron Dinner has been an annual event in Washington for more than a ) hundred years. Tonight, the Washington press corps prepares to roast the most 157

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: powerful person in town..and I’m especially happy, because she brought her husband with her... AUDIENCE LAUGHTER. Nancy smiles uncomfortably. Reagan is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: GRIDIRON EMCEE
dialogues.text: Keep in mind, if you would, our motto is “We may singe, but we never burn.” MORE AUDIENCE LAUGHTER. Reagan puts his hand on Nancy’s knee, smiling:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, Mommy, I do believe this is going to be the most elegant lynching we've been to in a while.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: MALE REPORTER DRESSED UP AS NANCY IN A DESIGNER GOWN.He’s pushing a rack of dresses onto the stage, singing (badly) to the tune of “Second Hand Rose”: MALE REPORTER/”NANCY” (singing) Secondhand clothes I give my secondhand clothes To museum collections and traveling shows. They were oh-so-happy that they got ‘em. Won't notice they were ragged at the bottom. Goodbye, you old, worn-out mess, I never wear a frock more than once. Nancy stands up, abruptly, and leaves the dais. Reagan se her go, glances at the audience. Edith leans over to Reagan, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Where the hell’s she going?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Don’t know. The ladies’ room, probably. Nancy passes behind Deaver, who mutters, smiling:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Go get ‘em, tiger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nancy arrives backstage, Tony and his ASSISTANT grab her, and whisk her away.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MALE REPORTER ONSTAGE
dialogues.text: Doing a strip-tease, as the audience roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER/"NANCY"
dialogues.text: Calvin Klein, Adolfo, Ralph Lauren, and Bill Blass. Ronald Reagan’s mama’s going strictly First Class. Rodeo Drive, I sure miss Rodeo Drive in frumpy Washington. Secondhand rings. Donate those old, used-up things. Designers deduct ‘em. We're living like kings. So what if Ronnie’s cutting back on welfare? , I’‘1l1 still wear a tiara in my coiffed hain... The reporter is down to a tagged corset and torn stocking as... A FIGURE COMES ONSTAGE in a bizarre costume: Donald Duck boots, a white feather boa, strings of pop-it beads, a floppy plumed hat, and a red and yellow Hawaiian skirt he together with safety pins. For a moment, the entire audience hesitates, confused. Th they realize it’s Nancy, and issue a COLLECTIVE GASP. People jump to their feet and start to applaud, as Nancy swings into her lyrics:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (singing) Secondhand clothes I’m wearing secondhand clothes. They’re all the thing in spring fashion shows. IMAGE - A PAIR OF HOMELESS WOMEN OUTSIDE, sitting on the dark sidewalk, wearing a pair of tin foil antennas. Her friend is going thru a shopping cart of Goodwill clothes, trying them on. 159

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (singing) Even my new trench coat with fur collar, Ronnie bought for ten cents on the dollar. The china is the only thing that’s new. BACK TO NANCY, strutting her stuff back and forth on the stage, having a laugh-riot:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (singing) Even though they tell me that I’m no longer queen, Did Ronnie has to buy me that new sewing machine? Secondhand clothes, secondhand clothes, I sure hope Ed Meese sews. The laughter is tearing the roof off the place, as Nancy grabs a plate that has been painted to look like her Whit House china, throws it on the floor, and shatters it. As she kicks up her yellow rubber boots and takes a bow.. JOURNALIST IN THE AUDIENCE calls to her from the wings:

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST IN AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Washington loves you, Nancy! Nancy smiles, perfectly aware that it’s only a “Washingto compliment”, then looks to the dais, where Reagan is cheering with the others, watching her proudly. She winks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMS WITH A REALLY LOUD, TRASHY 4-PIECE BAND BANGS OUT A
dialogues.text: HOT TANGO as incredibly good-looking GREGORY HARRISON (20's), whirls and struts on stage, in nothing but a stockbroker’s shirt, tie, and a shiny gold G-string. The WOMEN IN THE AUDIENCE are screaming with delight, as Harrison whips off his tie, and flings it into one woman’ lap..followed by his cuff-links, which land in another woman’s lap, and his shirt, which lands in the lap of.. shy, demure Patti, who’s sitting at a stage-side table with her GIRLFRIENDS. As Harrison steps off the stage, heading towards Patti, h girlfriends fall into hysterics. Patti freezes like a dee in the headlights of... HARRISON’S BULGING G-STRING AS IT COMES CLOSER AND CLOSER Harrison arrives at Patti, and yanks her to her feet, and starts dancing with her. Patti freezes with mortification as he vibrates against her. Then she melts, and starting dancing with him. THE CROWD SCREAMS LOUDER. Patti and Harrison are moving as one—it’s so tacky, it’s almost pornographic. INT. RON AND DORIA’S WEST VILLAGE APT. - NIGHT Ron and Doria transfixed, watching Patti and Harrison on their tiny tv.. INT. MAUREEN’S TEXAS APT. - TWILIGHT Maureen watches Patti’s movie as she eats dinner with her new husband DENNIS. She nearly chokes on her taco. INT. MICHAEL’S LIVING ROOM - TWILIGHT Michael, Colleen, and their two young kids watching Patti movie, in their suburban living room. As Harrison starts bend Patti backwards and stick his tongue down her throat..Michael grabs the remote, and changes the channel REAGANS’ COLOR TV - Harrison frenching Patti as the CROWD SCREAMS. 161

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. My. God... Reagan and Nancy are sitting in chairs, in front of their tv dinners, staring at the tv--their forks frozen, halfwa to their mouths. As Reagan slowly puts his fork down:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i | Well, you've got to admit..she’s talented...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Talented? You call this talent? This is pornography! And you’re the President of the United States! How can she do this to you?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Oh now. She’s just doing it for attention. And who knows? Maybe it’1l help get her a start in show-business... Nancy SCREAMS WITH FURY. Reagan LAUGHS EVEN HARDER. INT. PATTI’S APARTMENT - NIGHT | Patti lying in bed with her boyfriend, PAUL GRILLEY. He yoga instructor. Spacey, but sweet. They’re watching Patti’s move on tv.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL GRILLEY
dialogues.text: So what are your parents going to say, when they see this?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I only see them on tv and in magazines. As far as I know, they don’t even exist, anymore.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL GRILLEY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Well, one of these days I’1l have to meet them.if only to ask their permission.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Oh, Paul..We don’t need their permission to get married. 162

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure we do. I want them to like me. After all, they're going to be the grandparents of our children. He’s nuzzling her neck and ear. She turns skittish.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Children?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL GRILLEY
dialogues.text: I’m real sentimental, that way. I want a little house with a picket fence, and at least 5 screaming brats. Patti laughs a little. Her face filling with guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti and Nancy, in Nancy’s bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So you want to marry this man..who grew up in a trailer park..and have children by him.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: God, Mom. I love him.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But he’s a yoga instructor. What are you two going to live on?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I work, you know. I have my career.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You mean, the movies?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Yes. Nancy tries to sweeten her voice.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Have you told him you can’t have children?

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: -No. I just..I don’t want to put him through that. I want to... She comes over to Nancy, and kneels beside her: 163

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mom. Please try to understand this-I want to be perfect for him. I want to give him the kids that he wants and...and I want to be the woman he wants..isn’t that pathetic? Nancy strokes Patti's brow resignedly, with a trace of bitterness:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, my darling. It's not pathetic. We all want to be perfect for our husbands.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: L..I talked to a doctor, he said I could probably get my operation reversed..it’s major surgery..it’s very expensive.but I could have children again. (reluctantly) Only I’d have to come clean with Paul..

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. Tell him something else is wrong. There are other reasons women have surgery. Patti stares at her mother, incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: You mean, you want me to go through a major operation, and not tell him why?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: If you want your father to pay for it. PATTI. Mom, would you do that? Would you keep such a big secret from the man you were going to marry? Nancy changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patti, you hate everything your father stands for-but now, when you need his money, you come back and ask him to rescue you. 164

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: I never asked to be rescued. I only asked to be, loved—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: And we do love you. (pause) If you want us to pay for your operation, it will be our doctors..ocur way. You will tell no one. Not the press. Not your friends. Not even Paul. Those are our terms. Patti stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: Why do I do this? Why do I come back to you, over and over, when it always turns out the same way?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Should I assume you’re going to wear white to the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are dark, and the shades are pulled. Reagan, Baker, Deaver, Meese, and George Shultz are watching a State Dept. documentary on Iran. The room is thick with tension.

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE -
dialogues.text: It’s a grainy, hand-held picture..Khomeini standing on a balcony over a crowd of CHANTING IRANIANS. An American fl burning. A dummy of Reagan being hung, from a street-lamp Bill Casey stands in the picture, narrating, as Iranian rioters flicker across his face:

dialogues.speaker: BILL CASEY
dialogues.text: This is Beirut..There’s Khomeini...

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (from the dark) When is that guy going to die? He must be 90 years old. George Shultz leans over, whispers to Deaver: 165

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when did we start showing movies in the Oval Office?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Not bad, huh? State Department makes ‘em. (nod to Reagan) He doesn’t like to read, and he gets bored listening. Anyway, State love making them, and he loves watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The documentary ends with a projection: the face of a whi American male (WILLIAM BUCKLEY, 50), pale. Scared. He hol the front page of a Lebanese newspaper against his chest.

dialogues.speaker: BILL CASEY
dialogues.text: This is William Buckley, our CIA station chief in Beirut.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Louder.

dialogues.speaker: BILL CASEY
dialogues.text: (mumbling louder) This is William Buckley, our CIA station chief in Beirut. He was kidnapped 3 days ago by Lebanese terrorists who are being supported by Iran. We don’t think they want to kill him. But we are extremely concerned that he will be forced to reveal the names of other CIA agents in the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan stares at Buckley’s photograph, stricken. Nearby, George Shultz, Jim Baker, and Mike Deaver.

dialogues.speaker: BILL CASEY
dialogues.text: We've been flooded with calls from Iranians and Iranian exiles. offering to provide us with intelligence..Very fancy intelligence..internal political information..in return for weapons. Reagan has stopped listening.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: What about Buckley’s family? Have we talked to them?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: They know he’s been kidnapped, sir. 166

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ll have to call them. They must be out of their minds with worry. Jim Baker leans over to Deaver: Reagan continues to stare at Bill Buckley’s photograph,

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Don’t let him call the family. If he talks to them, this whole thing will become about liberating a hostage. the voices around him rise to a level of near-panic:

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Maybe we could set up some kind of prisoner exchange—we give them one of their terrorists, in return for Buckley—

dialogues.speaker: SHULTZ
dialogues.text: No. No prisoner exchange. This administration does not negotiate with terrorists.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: But the Iranians want stuff from us. They want weapons, anything, for their war on Iraq—

dialogues.speaker: SHULTZ
dialogues.text: No. Iran is a terrorist nation. We do not negotiate with terrorist nations.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: But if Buckley gives them the names of other CIA agents, we’re all screwed—

dialogues.speaker: SHULTZ
dialogues.text: You negotiate over Buckley, you know what will happen? We’ll get more kidnappings. More Americans, more CIA agents.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But what about Buckley? What are we going to do-screw him? We’re just going to leave him there? And what the hell are we going to say to his family? 167 as Seas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An explosion of bubbles, as Reagan dives into the water, his lifeguard suit. He swims down...down...searching..HIS THUMPING... Suddenly Bill Buckley’s face looms up in front of him, li a white ghost. Eyes wide open. Drowning. Reagan grabs Buckley under the arms, and starts swimming toward the surface..but Buckley's body is heavy, awkward. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT Reagan is moaning in his sleep. Nancy leans over him:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, honey..Ronnie wake up..you’re having a bad dream..Ronnie. She touches him arm. He jumps, opens his eyes. In a panic

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Where am I? Where am I? Bill!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're here, honey..you’re with me..it's okay..It’s okay...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I've got to get him out..But he’s so heavy..I can’t lift him.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Shhh...It’s okay, honey..Lie down..Lie down... She coaxes him into lying down, snuggles close, using the warmth of her body to comfort him:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: There, there..Everything’s going to be okay..Everything’s going to be just fine...

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: MENDELLSOHN’S WEDDING MARCH..Doria in a matron-of-honor dress, coming down the grassy aisle.flanked by DOZENS OF WEALTHY SMILING FACES..Everything is covered in flowers.. behind trees and flowered trellises, the bland, sun-glass faces of Secret Service agents are peering, watching... 168

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patti appears, resplendent, in a gorgeous white bridal gown, orange blossoms in her hair. Trying to smile, trembling on her father’s arm. ‘nse? She passes the Betsy and Arthur Bloomingdale, the Tuttles all her parents’ California friends. They’re all smiling benevolently. So is Mike Deaver. She passes Nancy, who’s in the front row wearing a glamorous suit, smiling broadly. Next to her, Ron is smiling even more broadly.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (whispering to Nancy) Mom..Where’s Michael and Maureen?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (shakes her head, murmurs) They didn’t get their invitations until too late. A frown flickers across Ron’s face. ANGLE - Patti and Reagan arrive at Paul, who is dressed i all white, wearing love beads. He’s a smiling flower-chil of love. Together they all turn and look up at the Reverend Donn Moomaw, who is enormous in his celebrant’s robes, holding Bible, and beaming down at them like God, Himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reception is underway. On one side of the garden, a group of INDIAN MUSICIANS are playing traditional music o sitars, as Paul and Patti (now in yoga clothes) lead THEI FRIENDS through a series of yoga exercises and meditation PATTI’'S FRIENDS Shanti, shanti, shanti..ommmmmm... ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE GARDEN, the string quartet is playing some light Bach. WAITERS cruise with trays of hor d'oevres and champagne. Nancy and Betsy Bloomingdale are heading indoors.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, at least she’s not living in sin, anymore. ee;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy and Betsy are in the ladies room, fixing their make up.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Look at you. “Her daughter got married today in a yoga ceremony, but tonight, her hair still looks fantastic.” Nancy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s Tony’s assistant. We brought him out for the wedding. He’s not Tony, but he’s good enough. Betsy smacks her lips in the mirror, as:

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Yes, well. Nobody’s Tony. Not even. Tony’s Tony, anymore.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Oh, Nance. Didn’t you know? He’s dead. (lowers her voice) Died last week..of you-know-what.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Come on, honey. You knew he was gay.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, but..I didn’t..He didn’t tell me..

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Everybody on earth knew. I mean, we've all been having a bad hair day for months.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My God. My God..Tony is dead..When is the funeral? Betsy sighs, with a flicker of genuine sadness. 170

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don’t think there’s actually going to be a funeral, do you? (pause) His parents are burying him. Nobody knows where. Come on. You need a nice, big glass of champagne. Betsy drags Nancy out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Presidential limo moving slowly down the palm-tree studded boulevard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy and Reagan sitting in back. She’s staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He was sick for months, but I never knew. Nobody ever told me. Reagan pats her hand, consolingly.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Try to remember what the Bible says.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: They that live in sin shall die in sin. Nancy looks at him. He reaches over to the bar, unscrews bottle of water, and pours himself a glass.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie..I want you to do something. Anything. All these young boys, all these children, drug addicts, they’re dying of AIDS, but nobody’s..nobody’s doing anything about it. Nobody even wants to talk about it. Reagan takes a sip of his water, and looks out the window Impenetrable.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Say something. 171

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits..and waits..no response. She’s dying inside. TIGHT SHOT - A 17-YEAR-OLD GIRL. She has the pimples of. teenager, but she talks like an old woman. Flat, dead:

dialogues.speaker: 17-YEAR-OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: I didn’t start out a drug addict. My mother was a single mom, she worked in a mental hospital. When the hospital was closed down, we went on unemployment, but unemployment only lasts so long. So when my mom ended up on welfare, and gave me to my aunt and uncle. I didn’t see her for like 6 years. But my cousin was into crack. She gave me some. Sometimes we'd turn tricks-not a lot, just enough to buy stuff. But then I started doing it more and more. I got so I was doing crack in the daytime, and wetting my bed at night. Finally my aunt and uncle found out, and they were going to put me in rehab, so I ran away. Man. Living on the street.. you’d better be doing drugs, or you'll lose your mind. The girl laughs, bitterly. The others laugh, too. PULL BACK TO REVEAL A CIRCLE OF RECOVERING DRUG ADDICTS. Nancy, her assistant KATHY OSBORNE, and the DIRECTOR OF T REHAB PROGRAM. In the b.g., several Secret Service agents

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (visibly moved) I don’t understand..Wasn’t there anyone else you could talk to? Your relatives? Your teachers? Your minister? Your doctor? Somebody? The kids laugh. Nancy flushes, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR OF THE CLINIC
dialogues.text: There used to be hospitals. Clinics. After-school programs. That’s all gone, now. Government cut-backs. Nancy is speechless. The director stands up:

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR OF THE CLINIC
dialogues.text: Thanks, guys. Let’s take a break and have something to eat. Can we thank Mrs. Reagan for coming today? 172  Everyone claps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy standing on the balcony overlooking a crowd of cheering, healthy TEENAGERS—not one of these kids has a problem in the world. They’re all wearing “Just Say No” buttons. Tons of media. Tons of Secret Service.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (calling down to the kids) What do we do, when someone offers us drugs? The crowd yells back, as one, along with her:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY WITH KIDS
dialogues.text: Just! Say! No! She’s laughing happily, as she fires the next question:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What do we do, when someone asks us to help them sell or carry drugs?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY WITH KIDS
dialogues.text: Just! Say! No!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What do we tell our friends to say, if one of them is offered drugs?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY AND KIDS
dialogues.text: (louder than ever) dust! Say! Noooooccce! A flurry of multi-colored balloons saying “Just Say No” i released into the air. Nancy clasps her hands together, s proud, as she watches them fly up into the blue sky. ANGLE - Bill Shelby on the ground, turning to one of his FELLOW-JOURNALISTS, with a cynical grin:

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: Gee. Why didn’t I ever think of that?

dialogues.speaker: END OF ACT ELEVEN
dialogues.text: 173 Sua?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY'S FACE AGAINST THE BLUE ARIZONA SKY -
dialogues.text: Nancy, wearing sunglasses and a solicitous smile:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: - Mother? It’s me. It’s so nice to see you, Mother...You’ re looking wonderful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy settles into a chair next to her mother Edith, who is hunched over in a wheelchair, her eyes fixed on the brightly-colored blanket that covers her lap.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
