dialogues.text: (brightly, trying) Ronnie and I are in Tucson for the re- election campaign, so I thought I’d just drop by. She reaches out, and smoothes Edith’s blanket.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You like your blanket? I picked it out just for you, back in New Hampshire..It’s more than 150 years old. Oh, and look what else I brought. Pictures. Nancy digs into her purse, pulls out photographs:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This one’s of Ronnie and me in the White Mountains. What a godawful place. I was covered with mosquito bites. Covered. (more pictures) Here we are, at Gettysburg..And here’s us the Grand 01’ Opry, that was fun..0h, and here’s Ron and his wife, Doria. You’ve met Doria, she’s not so bad. They’re the only ones campaigning with us, this time. Michael’s got the grandkids, and Maureen’s working. Oh God, Patti’s writing a book, did I tell you? From somewhere deep inside Edith, comes a low groan. Nanc laughs.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You can say that again. Ronnie and I always said to each other, Someday she’s 174

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: going to write a book. We just hoped it wouldn’t be until after we were dead. Edith’s index finger is slowly twitching its way around t circumference of a blue flower. Nancy falters.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie would have come with me to see you today..but the campaign is keeping him so busy..and, and... She picks up Edith’s hand, and begins stroking it, confidentially, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He’s not well, Mother. He’s tired, but it’s more than that. I’m going to talk to his doctor. I think this job is killing him, I really do. All the tension about Nicaragua, and Soviet Union, and this poor man who’s been kidnapped in Lebanon...Every night, when he’s sleeping, I whisper in his ear, “Peace...Peace.” But it’s too much for him. It would be too much for anyone. And some of those men in his Cabinet... Vipers, Mother. Vipers. I just pray to God I can get him out of the White House in one piece. She notices her assistant, Kathy, signaling to her from t lawn, and pointing to her watch. SEVERAL SECRET SERVICE AGENTS get up from the grass. With a great effort, Edith swings her gaze up to Nancy’s face, searching in it for something recognizable:

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Who are you? Nancy gasps, but this isn’t the first time this has happened.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’m Nancy, Mother. Nancy. Your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) No. I haven’t got any daughter... 175

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you do.Me. Right here, in living color. A shadow falls across the two of them. It’s the ATTENDANT

dialogues.speaker: NURSING HOME ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: We’re taking her in for lunch, Mrs. Reagan. Would you like to come? Nancy glances at her assistant, then looks at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I guess not. I should get back to Tucson. She stands up, and plants a kiss on her mother’s brow.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mother. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: NURSING HOME ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan..is there any chance your husband could send us an autographed picture? The staff would be so thrilled. We show “Bedtime for Bonzo” at least 3 times a year around here...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’11 speak to the President.

dialogues.speaker: NURSING HOME ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: That would be super. Good luck in the election. This is Reagan country, you know.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes..thank you..Goodbye, Mother... Nancy watches the nurse wheel her mother away.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY MONTAGE: the 1984 campaign: the “Morning in America” ads..Walter Mondale and Geraldine Ferrarro, hand joined and raised in triumph...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISSOLVE TO Reagan speaking in a CROWDED HALL...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: a “My friends, we live in a world that’s lit by lightning...” 176  In back, COPS are wrestling PROTESTORS out as they sing:

dialogues.speaker: . PROTESTORS
dialogues.text: (singing) “All we are saying Is give peace a chance...” SHOUTS. PROTESTS. EVERYONE BOOING EACH. OTHER. DISSOLVE TO: Reagan speaking to a crowd of aerospace engineers on the tarmac at NASA...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: “American has always been greatest when she dared to be great. I’m convinced we will be leaders, because the American people would rather reach for the stars than reach for excuses why we shouldn’t..” PURE, UNADULTERATED CHEERS. DISSOLVE TO Reagan addressing a crowd of FARMERS in Iowa..The farmers are hardbitten, cynical. One sobs.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: “My friends, ours is the land of the free because it is the home of the brave. America’s future will always be great because our people will be free, united, one people under God, with liberty and justice for all...” He certainly is the Great Communicator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “1984” Nancy at the podium:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, I want you to meet my husband, the next President of the United States..Ronald Wilson Reagan! She turns to a huge, huge projection screen, which covers the entire back of the stage. A enormous live-image of Reagan appears on it, smiling. Nancy is a speck in front it, waving to him, blowing a kiss..AS THE CROWD GOES WILD

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: 177 Sowa”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Cronkite:

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE
dialogues.text: “And we have President Ronald Reagan, carrying 49 states, receiving 525 electoral votes..to Walter Mondale’s 10..President Ronald Reagan has won 59 percent of the popular vote...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan standing with Nancy, being sworn in, his hand on h mother’s old, taped Bible...

dialogues.speaker: THRU THE WINDOWS OF THE WHITE HOUSE BALLROOM
dialogues.text: The windows burn brightly in the dark. Hundreds of dancin couples moving smoothly around the floor..a swirl of colors..candle-light and burnished silver...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cardboard boxes on the sidewalk house the same three homeless guys, shivering in the icy cold. The headlights the passing traffic sweep over them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver standing in the snow, surveying a small cemetery i the woods. All the graves are under a recent blanket of snow. His TRANSLATOR is talking to CHANCELLOR KOHL’S ASSISTANT. Deaver interrupts them:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (shivering) What’s he saying?

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: (German accent) He says the Chancellor Kohl thinks this is the prettiest of the cemeteries. It will look good on the television.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I agree. Tell him if Kohl likes it, then the President likes it. We can set up a stand right here..the President can make a little speech about World War Two..lay a 178  wreath..It’ll be very touching. Jesus, it’s freezing. Come on, let’s get a drink. They all laugh, and hurry towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Shultz, Jim Baker, and Mike Deaver are riding up i the elevator, along with DON REGAN (50), THE NEW SECRETAR OF STATE, and his cohort ROBERT (BUD) MCFARLANE (late 40's), NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER. Regan is cocky:

dialogues.speaker: DON REGAN
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, Jim-you’re going to wish you never switched jobs with me. Being Secretary of the Treasury is a whole lot harder than being Secretary of State.

dialogues.speaker: JIM BAKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, right, Don. Life in the Oval Office is one big bowl of cherries.

dialogues.speaker: DON REGAN
dialogues.text: All you’ve got to do is manage the economy. I’m going to be CEO of. the entire White House. Everybody in this building is responsible to me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE SHULTZ
dialogues.text: Including the President? Regan and McFarlane laugh. The others smile, exchange a glance. The elevator doors bang open. Jim Baker heads right. Everyone else heads left toward the Oval Office. Regan sidles up to Deaver, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: So, Deaver—tell me. You've known Madame Fuhrer a lot longer than I have. How the hell do you manage to put up with her? Mike Deaver looks at him, stunned. Before he can think of an answer, the journalist Bill Shelby appears out of nowhere, catches his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: Hey, Mike. Read the German papers today? 179 ‘al?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Come on, Shelby, I got no time for this—

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: Der Spiegel’s saying that the graveyard the President’s gonna visit in Bitburg has 20 SS buried in it. You know, the guys who gave us Auschwitz? Deaver feels sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan, George Shultz, Don Regan and Robert McFarlane are sitting in chairs, listening as Deaver explains:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: (humiliated) It had snowed, I couldn’t see what was on the tombstones. I screwed up, I take full responsibility. Don Regan interrupts, scornfully:

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: That’s no excuse. We’re trying to unify Europe, and you've got the President laying flowers on Nazi-graves. And you learned this from the media?

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: It‘1l break tonight. Six o’clock news.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, damage control. We call the Germans, find a new site for the ceremony—

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: I’ve already called them. Chancellor Kohl won’t change the site. He says every graveyard in Germany has a few bad apples. We have to put that behind us. (to Reagan) I’m sorry, Mr. President. I blew it. I'll resign as soon as I can write the letter.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: What for? I agree with Kohl. The war’s over. More important, I think I’m meant to go. Deaver is silent. Regan turns on the President, dumfounde 180

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Every Jewish organization in the country will be at our throats—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Because God wants me to bring peace to Europe. If he didn’t, he’d have left me dead on the street with a bullet in my chest. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portrait of FDR looks down on a JEWISH DELEGATION, led ELIE WIESEL, 70, Holocaust survivor and Jewish leader.

dialogues.speaker: ELIE WIESEL
dialogues.text: I have seen the SS at work, Mr. President. I have seen their victims. They were my friends, my parents. They were children. (pause) I tell you, Mr. President. You should not go to that place. That place is not. your place. Your place is with the victims of the Ss. . Nancy, Don Regan, and Deaver watch from nearby, as the President frowns very seriously:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, as you know, Mr. Wiesel, I’ve added a visit to a concentration camp, Bergen- Belsen... The Delegation winces. Nancy listens, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: The Holocaust was the greatest tragedy in human history. I saw some of it, first hand, as an Army photographer during the war, when I filmed one of the camps. I’11 never forget those horrible images— Nancy gasps—what’s he saying? Regan whispers to Deaver.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: I thought he stayed in Hollywood during the war.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: He did. 181

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overriding) The war made victims of everybody, Mr. Wiesel. Even though they wore Nazi uniforms, the young men buried in that cemetery are victims of Nazism just as surely as the victims in the concentration camps. END ON WIESEL’S INCREDULOUS REACTION:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GERMAN HONOR GUARD snaps to attention; a drum rolls as Reagan and a U.S. GENERAL step slowly to the monument, together, carrying a wreath, accompanied by two US MARINE As Reagan and the General lay the wreath and stand at attention, a BUGLER plays the German version of “Taps”. A GROUP OF DIGNITARIES watches: CHANCELLOR KOHL, GERMAN POLITICIANS, AMERICAN GENERALS, Don Regan, and Robert McFarlane. Nancy stands with Deaver. As they whisper, the keep their eyes focused on Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Nancy..I’ve decided to resign. (she glances at him, alarmed) I offered before, and he turned me down. But I’m doing it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Mike, you can’t..he needs your protection...

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: He'll be fine. He’s the Teflon man. This will slide off him. But me..I don’t think so. I don’t think I can live with this. (she looks at him, concerned) This job is taking it out of me. My health is shot. I barely know who my wife and daughter are, anymore. I need.a life. She looks at him sadly. The Honor Guard raises its rifles and FIRES a salute, as Reagan snaps a crisp salute, in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver hands Reagan his letter of resignation. A sadness hangs over them ‘both. 182

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: You’1l see me around. I’ve gotten a job as a lobbyist. I can’t believe the number of people who want to be friends with me, now that I’ve worked with you. They both laugh. Silence. Neither of them can say goodbye Suddenly Reagan pulls him in, and gives him a big hug. ANGLE - The look of surprise on Deaver’s face. EXT. WHITE HOUSE - A SUMMER’S DAY Establishing. INT. REAGANS’' SUITE - OUTSIDE THE BEDROOM - CONTINUING DR. HUTTON, the White House physician, comes out of the bedroom to talk to Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: (quietly) He’s getting dressed. I want to talk to you, first..Has the President been having any abdominal pain, that you know of?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No..No, I don’t think so...

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: I’m going to recommend a series of tests. He has a mass in his lower abdomen, and I want to check it out.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (turning pale) What do you mean, “Check it out”? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The media is camped out on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan is in bed, looking pale and a bit groggy, but clearly glad to see Michael, his wife Colleen, AND THEIR SON, CAMERON (5). The room is full of flowers. On the bedside table, several jars of jellybeans..and Patti’s ne book, Home Front. It has a picture of Patti on the cover. 183 \ cen”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jar of jellybeans is being passed around, as everyone talks and laughs:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I think Patti’s book is more therapy than anything else. You'll see. Three months on the circuit, and it’1l disappear into oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay by me. She was always an argumentative kid. Hell, she should have been a politician. Michael and Colleen laugh. Colleen can see how tired Reag is.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: It's late, Michael, we should go. Cameron. Pick up your toys. Michael stands up, reluctantly. Cameron starts to gather his toys.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It was good to see you, Dad. We don’t see each other enough, y’ know? Michael leans over, and they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy talking to Dr. Hutton:

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: The good news is, we caught it at an early stage. Now all he needs is a little radiation, and he should be fine. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Doctor..do you think this could explain why Ronnie..I mean, some of his behavior...

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: What behavior?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: His.his forgetfulness..and he’s..he’s tired, all the time... 184

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be forgetful and tired, if you were President of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes..but he’s not the same..something’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Mrs. Reagan. If something were wrong, we’d know about it. Say, that “Just Say No” program of yours is getting a lot of play, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Doctor, I’m trying to tell you, Ronnie’s not well...

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: Of course he’s not well, he’s just had surgery for cancer. Once he gets back on his feet-maybe a little vacation--you’1l see. He’ll be fine. He’s a warhorse.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (trying to believe him) Thank you, Doctor. He gives her arm a squeeze, and heads down the hall. Nanc stands there, trying to collect herself. Kathy Osborne comes up to her with a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY'S ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Here’s your tea. It’s a little strong, but you can add some more milk to it, and it will be fine. Nancy turns to her, bitterly:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Everybody keeps saying that. It’s fine. Everything’s fine, they tell me. (pause) Well, everything is not fine. It’s not fine. It’s not. Kathy stands there, looking confused. Nancy heads down the corridor to Reagan’s room. As she arrives, Michael, Colleen, and Cameron are emerging. 185

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We're leaving now. They're interrupted by Don Regan and Robert McFarlane, standing up from their seats, nearby. They’re holding briefcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ingratiatingly) Mrs. Reagan, I just want to thank you for letting Bud and me come to the hospital today...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (curtly) I'll be back in 15 minutes. Make it short. She walks Michael and his family to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy, Michael, Colleen and Cameron are visible in the lobby, talking. She stoops, and gives a hug to Cameron. PANNING UP THE SIDE OF THE HOSPITAL... ARRIVING AT REAGAN'S WINDOW... «which is open a few inches..Reagan.is visible in bed, talking to Don Regan and Bud McFarlane. SLOWLY ENTERING THRU THE WINDOW..their voices become audible:

dialogues.speaker: DON REGAN
dialogues.text: His name’s Father Jenco. He was a Catholic aid worker in Beirut, they kidnapped him last week. He’s still alive. Or at least he was, as of yesterday. Reagan’s head comes off the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: For God’s sake, another kidnapping? What the hell’s happening? Bill Buckley, what about him? Is he still alive? Regan turns to McFarlane, who clears his throat:

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: We don’t know, sir. There’s a rumor— 186

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: (flustered) McFarlane, sir. Robert McFarlane. I’m:one of your National Security Advisors, sir. You’ve already met me. Several times.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Really? McFarlane and Regan look at each other, uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Apparently Buckley had a lung infection of some kind..But we can’t get any hard information..I mean, Beirut, you know. It’s a country, it’s a state of mind--

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (alarmed) He’s dead? Is that what you’re telling me? Bill Buckley is dead?

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: It’s only a rumor, sir—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, Jesus..Bill Buckley is dead...

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: We don’t know if he’s dead. Right now, all we have is rumors. But Bud here has a proposal, we want you to listen to it—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I couldn't save him..He was an American citizen, and I couldn’t save him.

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: The Iranians need weapons for their war against Iraq—

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: They want missiles—

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: If we give them 100 TOW missiles, it could open up communication with the kidnappers— 187

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: We wouldn't be negotiating—

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Talking, that’s all we’d be doing. We’d be talking—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (almost desperate) Will it save Father Jenco? Regan and McFarlane stop.

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: (carefully) These people..the people we give the missiles to..they might have an influence on the kidnappers.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: We're not negotiating. All we’re doing is opening up communications...

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: We have a Marine, Colonel.Oliver North..he and I can go to Tehran, and set the whole thing up...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: You’re going to go to Tehran?

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: It’s 100 measly antitank missiles.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: But we can’t..We can’t sell weapons to Iran, they’re a terrorist nation..and we’re supporting Iraq...

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Iran’s not going to win the war with that. All they’11 do is raise a little a little dust. Reagan is so groggy, he’s having difficulty absorbing the information.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Believe me, sir. All we’re doing is opening up communications. 188  Reagan looks from Regan to McFarlane, and back to His voice has the slightest tinge of dread:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Open ‘em up.

dialogues.speaker: END _OF ACT TWELVE
dialogues.text: 189 Regan.

dialogues.speaker: ACT THIRTEEN.
dialogues.text: MUSIC: Band Aid’s Christmas recording (“DO THEY KNOW IT’S CHRISTMAS?”) in aid of Ethiopian famine relief..OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the death of CIA station chief Bill Buckley in Beirut..A airliner is hijacked by Iranian terrorists..newspaper pho of the pilot talking to negotiators on the ground..a body the tarmac..The Achille Lauro adrift in the Mediterranean terrorists visible on deck... The world seems to be teari itself apart. MUSIC FADES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “1985” It’s freezing. Reagan is walking slowly around the lake with GENERAL SECRETARY MIKHAEL GORBACHEV. They’re both bundled up. Talks are going badly:

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: (Russian accent) This missile defense system of yours— weapons in space—who can control it? It opens up an arms race in space—

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: How do we know you won’t use your weapons against us?

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Because we won’t. I’m saying to you, we won't. Why don’t you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you believe me, when I say that all I want is a shield?

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: (irritably) Please answer me—what is your answer?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (just as irritably) I am answering, Secretary Gorbachev—-with a question for you. The vein in Gorbachev’s forehead is throbbing with fury. 190

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am too heated and emotional not to show you my sincerity. I beg you..Stop this arms race before it gets started. INT. FLEUR D’EAU (CHATEAU) - DAY Nancy and Raisa sit, having tea. Raisa speaks in Russian. Her TRANSLATOR sits beside her:

dialogues.speaker: RAISA/TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: I read books by your American women. They say American women are downtrodden...They are paid less than American men..and they have no rights in work-place. Nancy glances uneasily at the SMALL ARMY OF ASSISTANTS AN MEDIA scattered around the room. Cameras FLASHING.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That’s not completely true, Mrs. Gorbachev—

dialogues.speaker: RAISA
dialogues.text: (overriding) And Malcolm X. He says American blacks can not get work. They are treated like slaves.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They're not slaves—

dialogues.speaker: RAISA
dialogues.text: (overriding) In Soviet Union, everyone has job. Everyone is treated same— Nancy interrupts with a steely smile:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Please, Mrs. Gorbachev. Would you like some more tea? EXT. FLEUR D’EAU (CHATEAU) - NIGHT The place is ablaze with lights. A fairy castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom door is slightly ajar. From behind it, Nancy voice: 191

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: “In the Soviet Union, everyone has job. Everyone is treated same.” Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Is that why you have the gulag? So you can make sure everybody’s working? Is that why Andrei Sakharov can’t get his wife any medical treatment?

dialogues.speaker: COMING AROUND THE CORNER OF THE DOOR -
dialogues.text: Nancy is visible in the tub, blowing off steam:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: «God help me if I come down with a cold when I’m in Moscow, I’1l1 be damned before I‘1l see any of your so-called doctors! And no wonder your husband always looks so bored—because he’s married to you, you Stalinist— She’s interrupted by a WOMAN’S VOICE, outside the door:

dialogues.speaker: CHATEAU MAID
dialogues.text: (French accent, timidly) Madame Reagan? I’m just turning down the bed. Is there anything you need?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No. No, thank you. That will be all. Nancy shrinks down into the water, mortified. INT. LIBRARY - FLEUR D’EAU -— CONTINUING In front of a blazing fire, Reagan and Gorbachev are sharing cigars, and brandy. They’re laughing and talking:

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: (Russian accent) So tell me, is Olivia de Havilland as beautiful as she looks in the movies?

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: More. Much more. We were on a committee together for the Screen Actors Guild. One night we were all standing around after a meeting, and I said, “You know, Olivia, I 192  always thought you might be a Communist.” She said, “Me? I thought you were one of them!” Gorbachev laughs and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Okay, I’ve got a joke for you. This is a story of a commissar who visited a collective farm. He stopped the first farmer he met, and asked about life on the farm. And the man said, “It’s wonderful. I’ve never heard anyone complain about anything since I’ve been here.” And the commissar said, “Well, what about the crops?” “Oh,” said the farmer, “the crops are wonderful.” “What about the potatoes?” “Oh, sir,” he said, “the potatoes, there are so many that if we put them in one pile they would touch the foot of God.” And the commissar said, “Just a minute. In the Soviet Union, there is no God.” And the farmer said, “Well, there are no potatoes, either.” They both break up, laughing. NEWSPAPER PHOTO: Reagan, Gorbachev, Raisa, and Nancy standing together at the end of the summit. Everyone’s smiling. Headline: “USA and USSR pledge to seek 50% Reduction in Nuclear Arms”. ANGLE - Reagan and Nancy back in their White House bedroo looking at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (bitterly) It means nothing. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s a pledge. You’ll meet again next year, in Washington. You’1]l make peace then. You must. You’ve got to. (pause) If only so that I don’t have to have tea with her, ever again..! He laughs, pulls her close for a hug and a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: AIR FORCE BOMBER
dialogues.text: 193 Bombs dropping on Tripoli..It’s a huge air attack, as do of US planes drop more than 90 2,000 pound bombs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan reads from the tele-prompter. He’s tired. Not well But he still projects utter optimism and ease:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Today, Americans can stand tall. American forces have bombed the cities of Tripoli and Benghazi in Libya, and the terrorist dictatorship of General Omar Qadaffi has been punished for its terrorist attacks in Europe, as well as its assault on two US Air Force planes in 1981—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Regan and McFarlane are talking to a young Marine, CO OLIVER NORTH.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: (low, deadly) | So, Colonel North—why do I feel like you’re not telling me the whole story?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER NORTH
dialogues.text: (a mask of Marine obedience) Sorry, sir?

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: (fuming) We sent 40 missiles to Iran, and we got Father Jenco out. Then we had another kidnapping. We sent over another 100 missiles, and we got 3 more kidnappings, and a killing.

dialogues.speaker: NORTH
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now Bud, here, tells me the Iranians want another pallet of missile parts and what? Pause. North’s cheeks begin to redden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “ A chocolate cake. 194

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McFarlane and Regan turn to each other, sarcastically:

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: A chocolate cake. A chocolate cake. (pause) Well, that’s fine. That’s fantastic. That just blows my little mind. Regan turns back to North, pushing his index finger into North’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, Colonel North. When this thing blows up in our faces—which it will-I’m not going to be the scapegoat. I’m not, not! You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Shelby watching Reagan on a small office TV, along with a FEW OTHER REPORTERS:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN ON TV
dialogues.text: .Now, every nickel-and-dime dictator the world over knows that if he tangles with the Unites State of America, he will pay a price...

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: You can’t stop terrorism by killing 150 innocent Libyan civilians.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: So what? The President’s numbers have never been higher.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Yeah. The Iranians walked all over Jimmy Carter. Now we’re finally getting some of our own back.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: You’re all a bunch of goddam idiots. Shelby kicks his desk, and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: BETHESDA NAVAL HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: INT. NANCY’S ONCOLOGIST’S OFFICE - DAY Nancy sitting in Dr. Hutton’s office. This time, it’s abo her. Dr. Hutton is reviewing Nancy’s x-rays. 195 ea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a small calcification in your left breast. It’s not large. It’s small. You could go for a lumpectomy, and follow it up with chemo and radiation. You’d be out of the action maybe 6 months.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Six months?

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: It's better than a radical mastectomy. Nancy shakes her head. She’s mortified, talking about thi

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No. You don’t understand, Doctor Hutton. I can’t be sick for six months.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: Sometimes we don’t have any choice about these things...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I do. I have a choice. I can be sick, or not sick. I will not be sick. My husband needs me. (pause) I'll take the mastectomy. Hutton stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUTTON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Reagan--you don’t need a mastectomy. With a lumpectomy there are no guarantees, but the chances are overwhelming that you’d be fine—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No. No. I need to.be with my husband. I’1l1 take the mastectomy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaver steps out of the elevator, and starts toward Nancy room. 196  INT. NANCY’S HOSPITAL ROOM ~- CONTINUING Nancy lying in bed, full of IVs, unconscious. Her chest a mass of bandages and tubing. Reagan sits next to her, holding her hand. NURSES come an go, checking Nancy’s signs, IVs, etc., but Reagan never notices them--his eyes stay on her face, watching her. Hurting almost as much as she is. Deaver stands in the doorway, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan with Mike Deaver, talking:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: In some ways, Nancy and I are one human being..When one of us is happy, the other is happy. When one of us hurts, the other hurts... He breaks off. Deaver searches for words but can’t find them. They stand together, in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan is heading down the corridor to his office, when George Shultz catches up to him, elated, waving a letter.

dialogues.speaker: SHULTZ
dialogues.text: Mr. President..Mr. President..wait.. Reagan is so far inside his sadness, that he can hardly register Shultz’s elation:

dialogues.speaker: SHULTZ
dialogues.text: I got a letter from Gorbachev. The Soviets have blinked. They’ve blinked.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SHULTZ
dialogues.text: They’ re willing to sign a treaty..Gorbachev wants to discuss dismantling the Soviet nuclear missile-system! 197 ‘eae  Suddenly they’re surrounded by Staff..the secretaries... Everyone is laughing, shouting, shaking hands, patting ea other on the back. Reagan is in the middle of it all, scratching his head, grinning like an 18-year-old kid. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - WHITE HOUSE - DAY Nancy sitting up ina chair, beside the window. Reagan bursts into the room:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s done. Gorbachev wants to sign.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh Ronnie... He goes to her, kneels in front of her, they hold each other.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You did it. You did it.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: God did it. It’s why God saved me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: HAIL TO THE CHIEF as Reagan and Gorbachev are sitting at Lincoln’s desk, which is covered with velvet. They're signing the INF treaty. Nancy and Raisa are in th front row. Behind, the ENTIRE U.S. CONGRESS.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE
dialogues.text: (quietly narrating) first General Secretary Gorbachev will sign..and then President Reagan..This is truly a historic moment. This is the first U.S.-Soviet treaty of any kind to provide for the destruction of nuclear weapons... As Reagan and Gorbachev stand up, APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: We have listened to the wisdom of an old Russian maxim. Doverey, no proverey—trust but verify.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: You repeat that at every meeting. LAUGHTER. 198

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I like it. MORE LAUGHTER. Everyone is shaking hands. Nancy beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Shelby alone in the White House Press Office, typing on his computer. The UPI printer starts to hum. It’s printing out a story. He goes over to it, and reads. Star at it, unable to believe his eyes. He tears the story off the printer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Shelby catches up with Deaver in the hall, urgently:

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: Hey, Deaver! Deaver! (Deaver stops) What’s with Bud McFarlane going to Iran to negotiate for the hostages? Deaver is blind-sided, stares at him:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: The story just came out on the wire. Some magazine in Lebanon says that Bud McFarlane has been negotiating with Iran, selling them weapons in return for the hostages— Deaver feels sick, instinctively tries to stonewall him:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: No-what? No..That’s impossible—

dialogues.speaker: BILL SHELBY
dialogues.text: And the Iranian prime minister says it, too-he says that secret negotiations have been going on for more than a year— Deaver turns, hurries away. Shelby stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: SHELBY
dialogues.text: Deaver? Deaver!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 199  Don Regan coming off the elevator, being confronted by a

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Mr. Regan, doesn’t the United States still have an embargo against Iran?

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: No comment .

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Do we have a deal going with Iran of some sort?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: How can we be selling weapons to Iran? Aren't we supposed to be supporting Iraq? Regan pushes his way through the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: No comment. This is nothing but wild speculation. We have not been negotiating with anybody to free the hostages, we have no communications with Iran whatsoever—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No longer the Great Communicator. He’s angry, defensive.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: «Our government has a firm policy not to capitulate to terrorist demands. That no- concessions policy remains in force, in spite of the wildly speculative and false stories about arms-for-hostages, and alleged ransom payments. We did not, repeat, not trade weapons or anything else for hostages, nor will we. INT. DEAVER’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT | Mike Deaver with his WIFE and DAUGHTER, watching Reagan ) tv. Deaver shakes his head, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: He’s just lost all credibility. He's finished. He's finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 200 Ed Meese, Attorney General, looking grim, riding up in t elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan and Regan sit nervously, as Ed Meese confronts the with the bad news:

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: The Iranians were charged 30 million dollars for 12 million dollars worth of missiles. There’s 18 million missing. The blood drains from Reagan’s face. He croaks:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Missing? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ED MEESE
dialogues.text: It’s been siphoned off.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand..By whom? How?

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: The money was collected by a Marine, Colonel Oliver North. It was funneled through a Swiss bank account, and from there, some of it went to the Nicaraguan Contras. Of course, that only accounts for 4 million dollars. The books were..well, they were cooked. Reagan can only stammer. Regan looks shocked, too.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I..I..I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: DON REGAN
dialogues.text: But that's impossible. You don’t screw around with federal funds. This is government money. Meese gives Regan an incredulous look, turns to Reagan.

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: I think, sir..we need an investigation.

dialogues.speaker: DON REGAN
dialogues.text: (echoing) That’s right. That’s what we need. An investigation. We’ve got to tell Congress. 201

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can’t hide important information like this--right, Mr. President? Reagan is still too stunned to speak. Regan continues:

dialogues.speaker: DON REGAN
dialogues.text: Maybe we should set up a board of inquiry-—make it bipartisan, yes, that’s what we'll do-get all the information out. Everything has to be above board, don’t you think, Mr. President? Reagan has grabbed the arm of the sofa, as if to keep himself from falling over.

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: Mr. President..what we need is an independent counsel..somebody separate from me..because my involvement with you could be seen as a conflict of interest.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (faintly) Okay. Well. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. That’s good. Pause. Meese stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MEESE
dialogues.text: Senator John Tower is possible. He’s a Republican, he’s always been loyal to you.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ed. Thank you. Meese leaves.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I thought we were trying to save the hostages. I really did.

dialogues.speaker: REGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Of course sir. That’s what we were all trying to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan sits behind his desk, looking tired and worn, but doing his best to appear confident. TWO LAWYERS sit on either side of him (DAVID ABSHIRE and PETER WALLISON) . Opposite sits Senator John Tower and 3 others (RHETT DAWSON, BRENT SCOWCROFT, and SENATOR ED MUSKIE)-—the Towe Commission.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: Mr. President..this Commission wants to thank you for meeting with us today. We're going to ask you a series of questions concerning the shipment of arms to Iran. (pause) First. Do you remember Robert McFarlane ever telling you anything about money being diverted to the Contras? Reagan pauses.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: Never? Pause. Reagan speaks slowly, searching his memory:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Well, it seems to me that maybe I do...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: If you’d like, you can check your diaries... and your memory..more carefully... Reagan’s brow furrows. He’s really trying to remember.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: No, I don’t remember Robert McFarlane telling me anything. INT. REAGANS’‘ LIVING ROOM - WHITE HOUSE - DAY Nancy is having tea with Mike Deaver. 203

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: His approval ratings dropped again. Only 17% of the people believe his story about the Iran Initiative. She winces. It’s as if he’s stuck a knife into her.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I talked to my special friend, this morning...”Dire events in the first few months of 1987...” That's what she said.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Nancy, you’ve got to get rid of Don Regan.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I've talked to Ronnie until I’m blue in the face.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: Do something. Make it happen. Or else he’1l drag the President and the whole Administration down with him. Nancy hears him. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leaves are falling, as Nancy and Reagan leave their residence, walking slowly into the woods, hand-in-hand. A few Secret Service follow, at a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy and Reagan walk slowly. It’s a beautiful afternoon. But they’re tired, tense.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I used to think he could be a good Chief of Staff, that he could grow into the job. But he’s not Chief of Staff£, anymore—he doesn’t care about protecting you, all he cares about is himself..And he doesn’t watch the shop. He surrounds himself with yes-men... (pleading) He’s weak, Ronnie. He’s weak. Reagan shoves his hands deep into his pockets. 204

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I’1l be goddamned if I’1l throw somebody to the wolves, just to save my own butt. He resumes walking. She hurries after him, still tired an in pain from Reagan turns He stares at her mastectomy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're in a crisis. This is a crisis. If it’s not handled well, everything you've done for the last 6 years will be gone. The Geneva summit..destroying nuclear weapons..de-militarizing Europe..ending the cold war..it will all be gone. What happened to Richard Nixon will happen to you-- on her, hotly:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I never, never traded arms for hostages.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Is that true? (off his look) That’s not what I mean, Ronnie. I believe you, but are you right? Lying is bad enough. But when you tell what you believe is the truth, and it’s not..then you’re really in trouble. her, knowing she’s right.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: This whole thing is blown up out of proportion, it will blow over, you’ll see—

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It’s not going to blow over. Ronnie, John Tower is investigating you--

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to investigate! I didn’t break the law—I didn’t— She grabs his arm, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ronnie, stop it. Stop it. You don’t know everything that’s been done..People have been doing things behind your back. Don 205 Nei”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regan has been doing things behind your back. (then) If you don’t fire Don Regan, he’11l drag you down with him. He will. They're standing, staring at each other—angry, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: THRU WINDOW
dialogues.text: Reagan talking to Don Regan, uncomfortable, avoiding..Reg listens, stunned, then suddenly explodes, stands up, puts his hands on Reagan's desk, snarling at him. Reagan sits back, himself stunned. INT. MCFARLANE’S BEDROOM - MARYLAND - NIGHT McFarlane in his pajamas, in front of his computer, holdi the phone to his ear. AN ANONYMOUS MAN’S VOICE IS TALKING MAN’S VOICE (TELEPHONE) It’s bad, Bud. It’s really bad. A lot of heads are going to roll.

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: (faintly, into phone) Yes..thank you..thank you for telling me. I’1l take care of it. MAN’S VOICE (TELEPHONE) No, Bud..you don’t understand..Once Tower gets hold of you, you're going to be screwed.

dialogues.speaker: MCFARLANE
dialogues.text: (again) I understand. Really. I do. McFarlane slowly hangs up. In the b.g., MCFARLANE'S WIFE visible in the next room, watching tv. McFarlane goes to the bed, and sits down. He sits there a moment, shaking. Opens the drawer in his bedside table an takes out a bottle of prescription pills. Slowly shakes a the pills into his hand. He throws half of them into his mouth, swallows them with water. He throws the other half into his mouth, swallows them, too. Then he crawls under the covers, and prepares to die. 206 INT. BILL CASEY’S OUTER OFFICE - CIA HEADQUARTERS - NIGH CASEY'S office looks like it’s been hit by a hurricane. Papers everywhere. HIS ASSISTANT is packing papers, in a panic. CASEY’S ASSISTANT Mr. Casey, sir, what about these files on the Iranian Parliament, sir..and Rafsanjani... He hears a cry coming from Casey’s office, turns:

dialogues.speaker: CASEY'S ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Six? Through the open door, he can see Casey falling to the floor. He rushes in: CASEY’S ASSISTANT Mr. Casey! Mr, Casey! Casey on the floor, going into convulsions. INT. REAGANS’ BREAKFAST ROOM - WHITE HOUSE - MORNING Reagan and Nancy sit in front of their breakfast. They can’t eat. Can’t drink. They’re numb.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: It’s Armageddon..that’s what it is. Armageddon. The Leader from the West will be revealed as the anti-Christ, and then God will strike him down. That’s me. I am the anti-Christ.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, Ronnie...

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (overriding) And the Lord will strike down all of civilization, in order to make way for the new order..a new Heaven and. a new Earth... Nancy reaches out, grabs his hand, strongly.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Hold on. You’ve got. to hold on, Ronnie. Reagan's eyes are filling with tears. He can’t help it. He’s crumbling. 207 Sasa”

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I saved 77 lives in 7 years, Nancy..But I couldn’t save those people in Lebanon. Nancy gets up, puts her arms around him. She rocks him slowly, silently, back and forth. INT. MCFARLANE’S HOSPITAL ROOM - CONTINUING McFarlane in bed, with IVs in his arms, crying. He cries and cries. His wife sits beside him, holding his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BETHESDA NAVY HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: INT. BILL CASEY’S HOSPITAL ROOM - CONTINUING Bill Casey lying in bed, with his head bandaged, and IVs his arms. He’s dying. John Tower stands beside him, looki down at him. He pats Casey’s hand, sadly. They all leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPEAT OF THE OPENING OF NIGHT TWO: Reagan in his chair wearing his pajamas and bathrobe. He looks old. Mike Deav sits next to him. Tower is opposite, leaning forward, intensely.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TOWER
dialogues.text: Mr. President, as head of the Presidential Commission to investigate Iran-Contra..I’m here to tell you our findings. One year ago, you personally approved the sale of 2,004 antitank missiles to Iran for the express purpose of exchanging arms for hostages...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reagan is sitting behind his desk, as the MAKE-UP WOMAN works on him. His speech lies before him. The room is crawling with TECHNICIANS, as they set up for broadcast. Nancy is on the other side of the room, with young Ron. H holds her hand. She looks utterly desperate. 208

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute to the President. Somebody comes up to Reagan with a glass of water, holds to his lips. He sips. The glass is whisked away.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Nobody noticed this desk is darker. It’s been restored. Silence envelopes the room. The silence seems to spread across the entire country. Reagan suddenly pulls a handkerchief out of his pocket, a blows his nose. It’s a huge blast. A wave of laughter goe around the room—he grins—he did it to deflate the tension

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: Do I have time to make a phone call? More laughter. Reagan shrinks into himself, bows his head and stares into the surface of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (alarmed) What’s the matter? What’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: He’s concentrating.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Five.43.2enden Reagan has come out of his shell, he’s now performing as “himself”..grim, but honest..utterly well-meaning:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: (to the camera) A few months ago I told the American people I did not trade arms for hostages... ~My heart and my best intentions still tell me that’s true, but the facts and the evidence tell me it is not... INT. MICHAEL’S LIVING ROOM - CONTINUING Michael and Colleen watching, as the kids wrestle. 209

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: As the Tower Board reported...

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: what began as a strategic opening to Iran deteriorated, in its implementation, into trading arms for hostages... INT. MAUREEN’S KITCHENETTE ~ CONTINUING Maureen with her husband, Dennis..watching TV:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: This runs counter to my own beliefs, to administration policy, and to the original strategy we had in mind... INT. PATTI’S LIVING ROOM — LOS ANGELES - CONTINUING Patti’s so close to the tv, she can touch her father’s fa with her fingers. Paul watches from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: There are reasons why it happened, but no excuses. It was a mistake...

dialogues.speaker: PATTI
dialogues.text: (whispering, over) Oh, Daddy, Daddy..I‘m so sorry..I’m so sorry, sorry, SOrry.. INT. REAGAN BEDROOM — NIGHT Reagan is asleep. Nancy is on the phone with Mike Deaver, who’s in HIS KITCHEN:

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: The figures just came in, Nancy..His approval rating just jumped 9 points. Nine points. Nancy wants to be relieved.but she’s not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mike..Thank you so much... 210

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he’s got ‘to do is keep his chin up, and stick it out..he’s going to be okay. And you're going to be okay, too. She's too drained to answer.

dialogues.speaker: DEAVER
dialogues.text: You get some sleep, now.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You, too, Mike. She hangs up, looks over at Reagan. In his sleep, he reaches out for her. She crawls into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wintry day in Washington D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “LAST DAY IN THE WHITE HOUSE: JANUARY, 1989” APPLAUSE from the staffers who fill the room. Reagan is smiling, sad. The Presidency has taken its toll.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: There are no words that can properly tell you how bittersweet these days are... He glances at Nancy, a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: I think both of us have been aware, every minute we're here..that we’re surrounded by you, by others who may not be here today... and it couldn’t have been done without you. And I like to think maybe it’s kind of close to what happened 200 years ago..We were all revolutionaries, and the revolution has been a success..but there just aren’t any..aren’t enough words to thank you for all that you’ve meant to us... and how hard it is to say goodbye..to all of you. The only thing that makes it bearable at all, is to remember all that you did, and how..how much of a team we did become. Thank you..and God bless you all. 211  Applause. As he motions to Nancy to come forward, in the back of the room, the ARMY BAND starts to play “AULD LANG SYNE”. Confusion, laughter. The music stops.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My husband said I should say something, but I’ll never get through it..see? Tears are running down her face. All she can say is:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Applause. The band starts again: “AULD LANG SYNE”. Everybody is holding hands, beginning to sing:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN, NANCY, STAFFERS
dialogues.text: (singing) “Should auld acquaintance be forgot And never brought to mind... Should auld acquaintance be forgot And days of auld lang syne...” AS THE SINGING CONTINUES..SOUND OF A HELICOPTER LANDING.. INT. REAGANS’ SITTING ROOM - EAST WING - DAY Reagan stands in the sitting room, beside the window, watching the helicopter land outside. The song echoes:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN, NANCY, STAFFERS
dialogues.text: ‘For auld lang syne, my dear For auld lang syne... We’ll drink a cup of kindness yet And days of auld lang syne...” The room is devoid of all personal possessions. It looks like a museum, which is what it is.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Are you ready? I’m almost finished in here..just checking a few things... INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM/BATHROOM - CONTINUING Everything has been packed. Nancy’s kneeling beside the bed, looking under it. Nothing here. She goes into the bathroom. Checks the medicine cabinet. Nothing here. 212

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to hurry. The Bushes and the Quayles will be downstairs, waiting for us...

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW NANCY THRU THE BEDROOM OUT TO THE SITTING ROOM
dialogues.text: She stops, sees Reagan still standing beside the window.. million miles away. As she goes to him, he whispers:

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: How in the ever-loving world did we get here?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: ~It doesn’t matter. We’re going home. She takes him in her arms. He turns to her, and begins to dance-slowly, awkwardly, stumbles, stops.

dialogues.speaker: REAGAN
dialogues.text: What kind of dance is this? I can’t remember...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter, darling. You lead. I’11 follow. He begins again. Moving in silence. She steps neatly into him with every turn, following his every move. MUSIC FADE UP. MAYBE IT’S SOMETHING FROM CIRO’S..THE FIRST TIME THEY DANCED TOGETHER. Piece by piece, he puts the dance together in his mind, a she follows. She was always a good dancer. She still is.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: 213 casi!
